title: Logicalis - School of Magic [Academy Building]
author: logicalsystem
description:
They told Marcus Logicali he had a future—just not as a wizard.

Both academies rejected him. Not because he lacked talent, but because his magical capacity sat exactly at the minimum threshold. Technically enough, but they wanted comfortable margins. They never even watched him cast.

Marcus had spent eight years perfecting his mother's spell—the only magic he could manage. Raising earth two inches. Just enough to trip someone. A parlor trick that embarrassed his merchant father and mocked her memory.

Most people would accept their limitations and move on.

Marcus stole his father's coin purse and ran.

Armed with a claymore, five years of combat training, and one integrated spell that worked differently than it should, he set out for the most prestigious academy in the world. The one place that might actually let him prove himself.

He had no plan. No idea what he was doing. Just stubborn determination and a refusal to let a number define his future.

Nobody knew that one desperate student's rejection would spark something far larger—a challenge to centuries of magical law and the birth of an entirely new kind of institution.

Logicalis is a fantasy novel about the dangerous space between what you're told you are and what you refuse to stop reaching for.

chapters.content_text:
Prologue

Three Months Ago

The testing chamber at the Royal Academy smelled like old parchment and expectations.

I stood in the center of a runic circle inscribed in white stone, one hand pressed against the standard testing crystal. The enchanted sphere was warm under my palm, pulsing with a rhythm that matched my heartbeat. The administrator had the kind of face that had seen a thousand hopeful students. She watched the crystal's glow with professional detachment.

My father stood near the door. I could feel him watching. Hoping.

The crystal's light intensified, cycling through colors. Blue, then violet, then settling into a steady amber glow that held for three long seconds before stabilizing. Runic numerals flickered into view on the crystal's surface: 45.

The administrator noted the result in her ledger. "Forty-five Mi," she said. Her tone was the same one merchants used when discussing cargo that had arrived damaged but technically intact. "Exactly."

My chest went tight. Exactly. Right at the Om Point. Wizard Om had proven that forty-five Mi was enough to crystallize Mana—the minimum threshold to become a wizard. The number everyone talked about. The line between possible and impossible.

"So I qualify," I said.

"Technically. But students at the minimum struggle. Your core would crystallize too slowly to keep pace with our curriculum."

"I can already cast," I said. "Terra Form. I've been practicing for eight years—"

She pulled a pre-written form from a stack. The academy seal at the top. "The Royal Academy appreciates your interest. However, after careful consideration of your Mi value—"

"I can demonstrate it right now." The desperation in my voice made me sound younger than fifteen. "Let me show you—"

"That won't be necessary." She slid the form across her desk. The word DECLINED was stamped in red at the bottom. "We require comfortable margins above the Om Point. I'm sorry."

My father's hand landed on my shoulder. Heavy. Final. "Thank you for your time," he said to the administrator. Then to me, voice low: "Come on, Marcus. Let's go home."

I didn't move. "What margin? Forty-six Mi? Forty-seven? Where's the line?"

"Each applicant is evaluated individually." She gestured at the form. "But students below fifty Mi struggle. You'd be fighting an uphill battle."

"Then let me fight it. I can—"

"It wouldn't be fair to you." Her tone had shifted to dismissal.

"Academia Midur accepts students at forty-five Mi," I heard myself say.

Something flickered across her face. Amusement? Pity? "I wish you luck with that, then." She stood, indicating the meeting was over. She glanced at the application form. "But I'd suggest having a backup plan. Your family is in the merchant trade—warehousing, it says here. That's a respectable future."

My father pulled me toward the door before I could say something that would make this worse.

The walk through the Royal Academy's halls felt longer than it had on the way in. Polished marble floors. Tapestries showing famous Archmages. Display cases with enchanted artifacts. Everything I'd imagined being part of.

"It's not over," I said when we reached the courtyard. "Merchant's College in Fluminis. They accept students at forty-five Mi. I checked."

My father stopped walking. "Marcus—"

"They're newer. More practical. Less focused on theoretical magic." The words came fast, desperate. "Their tuition is lower. I could—"

"You want to travel to Fluminis and do this again?" His voice was tired. "Get rejected again?"

"You don't know they'll reject me."

He looked at me for a long moment. Black eyes like mine, weathered by years building a merchant empire from my grandfather's single warehouse. The same eyes that had watched my mother die eight years ago.

"If that's what you need," he said finally. "We'll go to Fluminis."

~~~

Merchant's College sat on the edge of Fluminis, a riverside city two days' ride northwest of Conducere. The buildings were newer than Royal Academy's ancient stone—practical brick and timber construction that looked more like a counting house than a citadel of magic.

The testing chamber was smaller. The administrator was younger—maybe thirty, wearing robes that had seen actual work instead of just ceremonies.

The testing crystal pulsed under my hand. Same rhythm. Same colors. Same amber glow settling into the same steady light. The runic numerals appeared: 45.

"Forty-five Mi." He didn't sound disappointed. Just matter-of-fact. "Right at the Om Point."

Hope sparked in my chest. "So—"

"Unfortunately, that's still below our practical range." He leaned forward, earnest. "Look, I'll be honest. At forty-five Mi, your core will crystallize too slowly. While other students are learning to cast, you'd still be building Mana just to practice."

I opened my mouth to argue, but what was the point? He'd already made his decision.

"Our training assumes you're starting from zero," he continued. "You'd be paying for a foundation you can't build at the pace we teach."

My father stood silent this time. Letting me handle it.

"What about the trade track?" I tried. "I could—"

"The trade track doesn't include spell casting instruction." His expression shifted—kind, but final. "That's for enchanting support, alchemy assistance. Jobs that work alongside mages."

The words landed. Not being a mage. Working alongside them.

"Have you considered Qi development instead?" he continued. "You're young, strong—Sage training might be a better fit."

The words landed like a punch.

"Thank you for your time," I managed. Stood before my father could pull me away this time. "I appreciate you seeing us."

Outside, the river wind was cold despite the early autumn sun. Merchantmen moved up and down the waterway, hauling cargo, loading boats. The kind of life my father wanted for me.

"I'm sorry," my father said quietly.

"Don't." I couldn't look at him. "Just... don't."

We rode back to Conducere in silence. Two days of watching the road pass, my father occasionally trying to start conversations that died before they began, me counting everything I'd given up for forty-five Mi that wasn't enough.

Exactly enough to know I could crystallize Mana.

Exactly not enough for anyone to care.

~~~

Three Months Later

"Again."

Ricardo's practice blade came in before I'd fully reset my stance. I barely got my practice sword up in time, the impact jarring my wrists. The blunted claymore was the exact weight and balance of my real one—custom-made as a matched pair—but the edges wouldn't cut. Just bruise if you were stupid enough to let them connect. He didn't give me space to recover—just kept pressing, forcing me back across the training yard's packed earth.

The morning sun was murder. Solis—the day before my name day—which meant everyone else was busy with preparations and no one was around to witness me getting my ass handed to me by a man whose Qi mastery had given him a lifespan most couldn't imagine.

I parried, retreated, looked for an opening that wasn't there. Ricardo's wooden sword was just practice weight, but the man behind it had been Head of City Guard in Conducere before he retired. Decades of keeping the capital safe, training warriors, commanding the watch. Bald head gleaming with sweat that somehow never seemed to actually tire him, that ridiculous mustache bouncing with every strike like the universe's joke at my expense.

Five years of this. Five years of bruises and blisters and that absurd mustache mocking me.

"You're thinking too much," he said, not even breathing hard.

"I'm thinking about survival."

"Same problem."

His next strike came low. I blocked, shifted my weight, and—there. The earth rose beneath his lead foot. Just two inches, barely visible, but his balance broke for a heartbeat. I stepped in and put my blade to his throat.

"Better." Ricardo didn't move. "How long did that take?"

"What?"

"From recognizing the opening to casting. How long?"

I lowered my sword. "I don't know. A second?"

"Try again. And this time, I want it instant."

We reset. He came at me harder this time—no testing, no probing, just immediate violence. The kind that gets you killed if you hesitate. I gave ground, parried twice, felt the rhythm of the Wind-Cutting form taking over, and when the opening came I didn't think. Just cast.

The earth rose. Ricardo's foot caught, his balance failed, and I swept his legs with the flat of my blade. He went down but rolled clear before I could follow up.

"Good." He stood, brushed dust from his trousers. "Again. Three times this round."

"Ricardo—"

"Three times. Beginning, middle, end. Don't think. Just flow."

The first Terra Form was instinct—muscle memory from eight years of practice. My mother had taught me the spell when I was seven, her hands guiding mine through the gesture while the smell of turned earth filled my lungs. "Feel the ground, Marcus. It's not separate from you." Her voice had been warm, patient. She'd let me help reshape the garden beds, laughing when I made the soil rise in uneven lumps. Back when I still thought forty-five Mi would be enough. Back when she was still alive.

Ricardo adjusted to the rise but I'd already shifted angles. Second exchange, blade work only, testing each other. Then he committed to a high strike and I dropped low, sword up to redirect, and the second rise erupted right where he was pivoting.

His wooden blade still caught my shoulder. Going to bruise.

But his balance was broken and I was inside his guard. Third rise as his back foot planted. He stumbled. I shoved. He sat down hard on the ground.

For a moment neither of us moved. Then Ricardo started laughing.

"Five years," he said, still sitting there. "Five years of you complaining about every drill, every form, every hour in this yard. And that's the first time you've used Terra Form like it's actually part of you instead of something separate you have to remember to do."

I lowered my sword. "What's your point?"

"My point—" He stood, slower than usual. Was he actually winded? "—is that you keep thinking magic and fighting are different things. They're not. Not for you."

"Easy for you to say. You can use Qi enhancement whenever you want."

"And you can reshape the ground while swinging a sword." He walked to the water barrel. "Most mages can't cast and move. Most warriors can't cast at all. You're doing both and you don't even realize it."

I jammed my practice blade into the weapon rack. "Doesn't matter. They care about Mi values and how many spells you know and whether your family name opens the right doors."

Ricardo drank, then handed me the ladle. "You've been practicing Terra Form every morning before our sessions. Alone. In the dark." He leaned against the barrel. "You think I don't notice when my student is running the same spell over and over like he's trying to memorize his own bones?"

"It's the only spell I can cast."

"It's the only spell your mother taught you." His voice went quiet. "The one she used for the gardens. The one she was teaching you the day before..."

"Don't."

He nodded. Didn't push. That was one thing I could say for Ricardo—he knew when to shut up.

I looked at my hands. Calloused. Scarred from that time I'd tried to inscribe practice runes and slipped. Permanently stained with dirt from a hundred solo training sessions. These weren't a merchant's hands. Weren't a wizard's either.

"Your father thought you'd finally accepted it," Ricardo said finally. His eyes narrowed. "But something changed." He studied my face. "Tomorrow's your name day. Day after that—where are you going?"

My jaw clenched. "Nowhere."

"Don't lie to me." Ricardo's tone cut through my deflection. "I've known you since the day you were born. So where? One of the coastal academies? Storm's Tower in Vallis?"

I held his gaze. Said nothing.

"Mali," Ricardo said quietly, reading my silence. "Academia Midur. Of course."

"Mali's the most prestigious academy in the world," Ricardo said. "Why would they accept you when Mercari's academies didn't?"

"They test casting, not just Mi values." I set the ladle down. "The book said they require at least three spell demonstrations. I only have one, but they'll actually watch me try. That's more than Royal Academy did."

"Three spells. You have one." Ricardo's voice was flat. "And a couple months of travel to somehow learn two more."

"I know the odds."

"Do you?" He gripped my shoulder. "You're running toward the place most likely to reject you. So I'll ask again—what are you really running from?"

"I'm not running from anything. I'm—"

"You're attending your name day celebration tomorrow." He picked up his practice sword. "Then the day after, you're going to disappear. So what are you really running from?"

Something in his expression shifted—something distant and grieving. He'd lost his own son decades ago, a Beast hunter named Veer. Maybe he saw him in me. Another young man walking toward danger.

My jaw clenched. "You going to tell my father?"

"Would it stop you?"

"No."

"Then what would be the point?" He moved to the center of the yard, took a ready stance. "One more round. But this time I want you to fight like you mean it. No holding back. No thinking. Just you, your sword, and whatever magic you've got."

I pulled my practice blade from the rack. The blunted claymore felt right in my hands—same weight as my real sword, same balance, same reach. Five years of drilling with this exact weapon until every movement was muscle memory.

"And if I actually cut you?" I asked. "Wait, wrong sword for that."

"Then I'll have an excuse for why a fifteen-year-old with a blunted sword beat me." That damned mustache twitched. "Come on. Show me what you're taking to Mali. Show me what you think is going to change their minds."

I didn't give him time to finish the sentence.

The fight was different this time. Faster. Harder. Every form I'd drilled for five years, every trick I'd learned, every desperate hour I'd spent trying to make Terra Form work while moving. The earth rose and fell like the yard was breathing. Ricardo's blade found me twice—shoulder, ribs—but mine found his guard three times and his balance four.

We ended with both our swords at each other's throats, both of us breathing hard for the first time I could remember.

Well, I was breathing hard. Ricardo just looked mildly exerted, which was more than I'd ever gotten from him before.

"That," Ricardo said quietly, "is not bad for someone 'not enough.'"

I lowered my blade first. He did the same. Then something occurred to me—something that should have been obvious five years ago.

"You were matching my Qi level."

"Of course I was. I've been matching it for five years." He smiled. "Good training means calibrating the difficulty."

He is nearly a Sage. He could jump over this courtyard wall without breaking stride, move faster than I could track. But he'd been fighting at my level. Teaching me properly.

"I held my own for three minutes," I said slowly, "against someone with more decades of combat experience than I've been alive. Using sword work and one utility spell."

"You did." He gripped my shoulder. "You've learned to use everything you have instead of wishing for what you don't. That's rarer than you think."

We stood there in the morning sun, sweat dripping, neither quite willing to break the moment.

"You're not running from your father," he said finally. "Or the academies."

"Then what am I running from?"

"The person you'll become if you accept this." His grip on my shoulder was firm. "Your mother taught you one spell. That wasn't an accident."

I shook my head. "She was teaching me more. Before she—"

"But she made sure you had one they couldn't take away." His voice went quiet. "I've known you since birth, helped your father raise you. Now, I'm watching you leave."

"Ricardo—"

"Being stuck between warrior and mage is only a weakness if you keep trying to be one or the other." He glanced back. "Remember that."

Then he was gone.

I stood alone in the empty training yard with my sword, my one spell, and the truth we both knew but hadn't said out loud.

The morning sun was already climbing. Soon Catherine would call me in for breakfast. Soon I'd have to face my father and pretend I wasn't planning to betray him. Soon I'd have to smile through a celebration knowing it was goodbye.

I picked up my practice blade one more time. Ran through the opening sequence of Wind-Cutting form—the same movements I'd drilled a thousand times under Ricardo's watching eye. My body knew every step. Terra Form rising at the second pivot, just like he'd taught me. The earth responded, a two-inch rise exactly where my opponent's foot would be.

But there was no opponent now. Just me and the empty yard and the knowledge that tomorrow, all of this would be memory.

Tomorrow was my name day—Aestus Prima, the festival day I was actually born. I'd already turned fifteen back at Initium along with everyone else in the world, but tomorrow was the personal celebration. The day my family marked as mine.

And that night, after everyone slept, I'd steal my father's coin pouch from behind my mother's painting, leave a note, and disappear before dawn to find out if the City of Magic—if Academia Midur itself—had room for someone who was exactly enough and not a drop more.

I looked down at my hands one more time. Calloused. Scarred. Stained with dirt from practicing magic alone in the dark.

Not a merchant's hands.

Not a wizard's hands either.

Not yet.

I racked the practice blade next to its twin—my real claymore, sharp-edged and waiting. That one would come with me. The practice sword would stay here, gathering dust in a training yard I didn't know if I'd see again.

I headed for the house. I had a celebration to attend, a family to say goodbye to without them knowing it was goodbye, and one day left to be the person I was before I found out what I could become.

chapters.content_text:
Chapter 1 - The Name Day Departure

"Marcus!"

Catherine found me in the courtyard mid-morning, sword oil and cleaning cloth in hand. I'd been avoiding the house since breakfast, staying with my real claymore and the familiar ritual of maintenance. The sharp one. The one I'd be taking with me when I left.

"There you are." She wiped her hands on her apron. "Guests will arrive within the hour. You need to wash up and change into something that doesn't smell like the training yard."

"Guests?" My stomach dropped. "I thought this was just family."

"Your name day celebration? Of course there are guests." She gave me that look that said I should have known better. "Your father invited the Marinos, the Castellis, and I believe young Lucia Theron is coming as well."

Great. Not just a quiet goodbye—a whole production with the children of my father's business associates. Children I'd grown up around, trained with, competed against for tutors' attention. All of them watching me celebrate turning into my father's heir instead of the wizard I'd wanted to be.

"I'll be up in a minute," I said.

"Marcus." Catherine's voice softened. "I know you don't want a fuss. But it's one afternoon. For your father. Can you manage that?"

I nodded. She studied me for a moment longer—not the way she looked when checking if I'd washed properly, but something else. Something searching. Her eyes dropped to the claymore at my feet, then back to my face.

"Just one afternoon," she said quietly, then headed back to the kitchen.

I looked down at my claymore—the real one, oiled and sharp. Still needed to pack it carefully so the edge wouldn't cut through my travel clothes. Along with the coin pouch, the note I'd written and rewritten three times.

One afternoon. I could manage one afternoon.

Then I'd be gone.

~~~

I knew I should head in and clean up like Catherine asked, but I stopped by the stable first. I hadn't taken Thunderhoof out today—too busy avoiding the house—and I needed to check on him. Make sure he was ready for tomorrow.

Kyle was there with Matthew, who'd apparently brushed Thunderhoof three times already. The seven-year-old looked up when I entered, grinning with that absolute certainty that he'd done something important.

"Is everything perfect, Papa?" Matthew asked Kyle. "For Marcus's name day?"

"Perfect enough." Kyle ruffled his son's hair. "Go get Thunderhoof an apple. One apple."

Matthew scurried off. Kyle waited until he was out of earshot, then lowered his voice. "He did what he could reach. I redid the rest when he wasn't looking."

Thunderhoof turned his head and pressed his warm muzzle against my shoulder—the same greeting he'd given me every morning for five years. Steady. Patient. Unbothered by the chaos in my head.

"He looks great," I said. "Thank you both."

Kyle nodded. "We should clean up. Catherine will have my hide if we're late."

I left them there—Matthew feeding Thunderhoof his apple, chattering about horse care, Kyle supervising with that patient tolerance only parents have.

One more thing I'd be leaving behind.

~~~

Catherine had transformed the main parlor—the room my father reserved for business guests and formal occasions—into something that was supposed to feel festive. Late afternoon sun slanted through the tall windows, casting everything in that golden light that was supposed to make gatherings feel warm and convivial. She'd set up a buffet along one wall: roasted meats, fresh bread, honey cakes, and enough wine to ensure everyone stayed longer than I wanted. The smell of roasted chicken mixed with sweet pastry and the sharp tang of wine.

I claimed a chair in the sitting area near the opposite wall—upholstered chairs and a sofa arranged around a low table. My father stood near the windows—his usual post for receiving guests. Ricardo had already claimed the doorway, cup of wine in hand, watching everything with that quiet attention he always had.

The Marinos arrived first with their twin sons, Paulo and Rafael. Their parents joined my father near the windows. The twins crossed toward me with the same easy confidence they'd had walking out of the Royal Academy testing chamber three months ago—when their testing crystal had glowed seven Mi points brighter than mine.

They settled into the chairs flanking me, then launched into their upcoming enrollment. New robes. Master enchanters. Dormitory arrangements. Every detail delivered with the confidence of people who'd never been told they weren't enough.

I gripped my wine cup and tried to smile at the appropriate moments.

Lucia Theron arrived next, sweeping into the parlor in a cloud of expensive perfume and silk. Unlike most merchant daughters, Lucia absolutely leaned into the fashion—blonde hair styled in elaborate braids woven with silver thread, emerald dress that probably cost more than Thunderhoof, jewelry that managed to look elegant rather than ostentatious.

She caught my eye from across the room, took in the twins holding court, and smiled with predatory precision.

"Paulo, Rafael!" She glided over with a brightness that seemed genuine if you didn't know her well. "I've been dying to hear about Royal Academy dormitory arrangements. The architecture alone must be fascinating."

The twins practically lit up at the new audience. Lucia perched on the arm of the sofa, positioning herself between me and them, and proceeded to ask increasingly detailed questions about matters no one actually cared about. Comparative advantages of different dormitory wings. Meal hall scheduling. The historical significance of the North Tower.

I shot her a grateful look. She gave me the slightest wink.

Then the Castellis arrived with wine and their daughter Isabella. The twins immediately abandoned Lucia—drawn to the larger audience of adults near the windows like moths to flame.

Isabella crossed to the sitting area while her parents joined the cluster near the windows. She'd tested at thirty-eight Mi and accepted it with more grace than I'd managed—no desperate trips to second academies, no silent rides home, just a practical pivot to her mother's textile business. Now she was learning to inscribe preservation runes on expensive fabrics. Practical magic for practical people.

Dark hair in a simple braid, practical dress, callused fingers from textile work. She'd given up on elaborate fashion when she accepted her Mi score—said it got in the way of actual work.

She settled into one of the chairs the twins had vacated with the directness that made her either refreshing or unsettling. Lucia slid into the other, completing our small circle.

"You look miserable," Isabella said quietly while our fathers discussed shipping schedules across the room.

"That obvious?"

"You're gripping that cup like you want to strangle it." She sipped her wine. The red liquid caught the afternoon light. "And I saw the twins holding court when I came in. Let me guess—they were getting to you."

"The twins are fine."

"The twins are insufferable," Lucia said, examining her nails.

Isabella smiled at her, then turned back to me. "We both know you're one more 'Royal Academy this' and 'enchantment classes that' away from doing something you'd regret. Besides, it's your name day. You're allowed to have an actual conversation without those two performing their acceptance letters at you."

I managed a real smile. "You always did see through bullshit."

Isabella set down her cup. "So what are you going to do? Your father keeps telling mine you'll be starting at his main warehouse next month."

"Does he."

"But you're not, are you?" Her eyes were sharp. "You've got that look again. Like before the runic exhibition. What are you planning?"

I glanced across the room. My father was laughing at something old Castelli had said, his face relaxed in a way I hadn't seen in months. Since the rejections. Since the silent ride back from Fluminis. Since I'd stopped arguing about trying other academies. Ricardo caught my eye from across the room—just a brief look, a slight nod. He knew. Of course he knew.

"There is no plan," I lied.

"Marcus Logicali, you are a terrible liar." Lucia followed my gaze. "He just wants you safe, you know. After your mother—"

"I know what he wants."

"But it's not what you want." Isabella said.

"No," I admitted. "It's not."

Isabella and Lucia had been my closest friends since we were children. Where Isabella was blunt practicality and Lucia was calculated charm, I'd ended up as the stubborn idealist between them.

"We saw you come back from Royal Academy," Lucia said quietly. "You wouldn't talk for days. Then Fluminis." She didn't finish. Didn't need to.

I'd been quiet for weeks after that. Just training. Practicing Terra Form in the dark. Existing in the space between what I wanted and what I was allowed to have.

Until I'd started researching Academia Midur.

"You've got a plan," Isabella said. It wasn't a question.

I looked at both of them. Friends who'd watched me get rejected twice while others succeeded. Who'd both accepted what they were, and watched me fail to.

"I don't know yet," I lied.

Isabella pressed, "You mentioned Mali once. Before you went quiet."

"And I saw Historia Mali on your desk last week," Lucia added. "You weren't subtle."

"Academia Midur," Isabella said. "That's where you're going."

I didn't answer. Didn't need to.

Isabella leaned forward. "I thought you might be planning this." She pulled a sealed letter from her sleeve and pressed it into my hand. "I wrote this last night. My aunt lives in Portare. She runs a boarding house near the docks—the Tidewatch. Sailors, merchants, travelers. This is an introduction."

I stared at the letter. "Isabella—"

"Her aunt knows people," Lucia added, reaching into her silk purse and pulling out a small coin purse. "Ship captains. Merchants who trade with Regalis."

She thrust the purse into my other hand. "Ten gold. It's not much, but it'll help you get there."

I looked down at both hands—letter in one, coin in the other. "I can't take this."

"You can and you will." Isabella's voice was firm. "My aunt will help. The letter says you're pursuing magical education. True enough."

"Why are you helping me?"

Isabella squeezed the hand holding the letter. "Because you haven't given up. And we're not letting you do this alone."

Before I could respond, my father called me over to meet Master Vittorio, his senior warehouse manager.

The rest of the afternoon blurred into performance. Smiling at my father's business associates. Accepting congratulations on "becoming a man" and "joining the family business." Catching Isabella's and Lucia's eyes across the room, seeing their understanding reflected back.

My father looked happier than I'd seen him in months. Relaxed. Hopeful. Every smile I forced made the betrayal feel heavier.

~~~

The guests departed as the sun set. Catherine served dinner—just family now. Her, Kyle, Matthew, my father, and me around the table in the dining room that suddenly felt too large.

"Open it," Kyle said, pushing a wrapped package across the table.

Inside was a wooden carving. Me. Carved in flamboyant Archmage robes with flowing sleeves and intricate runic patterns. A spell staff in one hand. A book hanging from my belt. The detail was exceptional—you could see the individual pages of the book, the grain of the wooden staff, even the way the robes seemed to move in an invisible wind. Kyle had real talent.

And he'd carved me as the wizard I wanted to be.

My throat went tight.

"It's beautiful," I managed.

"Thought you'd like having something that shows... well, what you wanted." Kyle glanced at my father, then back to me. "Even if things didn't work out the way you planned. You can keep it on your desk. Reminder that we believe in you, whatever path you take."

My father's expression was complicated as he looked at the carving. Then he pushed another wrapped package across the table—larger, heavier. "From me. For the warehouses."

Inside was a merchant's satchel. Fine leather, well-crafted, with multiple compartments and brass buckles. The kind senior merchants carried. Practical. Expensive. Everything a warehouse manager would need.

"Quality materials," my father said. "Built to last. You'll be traveling between warehouses, managing shipments. This will serve you well." He paused. "Your grandfather carried one like it. Lasted him thirty years."

I looked between the two gifts. Kyle's wizard in elaborate robes, staff raised as if mid-spell. My father's practical leather satchel, built for a merchant's life of ledgers and cargo manifests.

Two futures. Two paths. Both given with love.

"Thank you," I managed, my voice rough. "Both of you. These are... thank you."

Matthew was already half-asleep, tired from helping his parents prepare all day. Kyle carried him off to their cottage. Catherine started clearing dishes.

My father poured two glasses of wine. His hands were steady—the same hands that had built a merchant empire from my grandfather's single warehouse. The same hands that had gripped my shoulder in the Royal Academy testing chamber three months ago. And again at Merchant's College. Black eyes like mine met mine across the table as he pushed a glass toward me.

"I know this isn't what you wanted," he said after Catherine had left us alone. "Any of this."

I stared at my wine.

"I took you to both academies, Marcus. Stood beside you in those testing chambers." His voice went rough. "I watched them stamp DECLINED without even asking what you could do."

The two-day ride to Fluminis. The silent ride home.

"I know," I said.

"Do you?" He leaned forward. "Because I still see you in that training yard every morning. Practicing that spell like—" He stopped. "I can't watch you keep tearing yourself apart over Mi points you'll never have."

"I just want to learn."

"You've already learned." He took a drink. "Your mother taught you Terra Form. She'd be proud of that." His knuckles were white around his cup. "But the academies said no. Both of them."

The words hung between us.

"The warehouses," he continued quietly. "There's dignity in that work. Security. A future you can actually build."

Everything I wanted to say piled up in my throat—that there was a third option, that Mali might be different, that Academia Midur valued skill not just numbers, that I'd rather fail trying than succeed at something I didn't want.

But he'd already lost my mother. And tomorrow I'd be gone, and he'd lose me too.

"I know, father," I said instead. "I'll think about it."

He smiled. Relieved. "Good. That's all I ask. Think about it. Give the warehouses a chance. If in a year or two you still want to pursue magic, we can discuss other options. Private tutors, perhaps. There are mages who teach individually."

I nodded. Let him believe the lie.

We finished our wine in silence. He went to bed. I waited another hour, listening to the house settle into silence.

Then I went to his study.

The door was unlocked. It always was—my father never expected theft from within his own house. I stood in the doorway, listening to make sure no one else was awake. The house was silent. Catherine and her family asleep in their quarters. My father in his bed down the hall.

I crossed to the painting of my mother on the far wall.

"Sorry," I whispered to her portrait.

Her smile didn't change. She'd painted this herself, years before I was born. Her voice came back unbidden—warm, patient. Magic isn't about how much power you have, Marcus. It's about what you do with it.

I'd been seven years old, hands still small in hers, learning to feel the earth's pulse in our garden. The smell of turned soil. Her fingers, always faintly earth-scented, guiding mine through the gesture. I'd made the soil rise in uneven lumps and she'd laughed, that bright sound that seemed to make the whole garden lighter.

Promise me you'll never stop trying.

I'd promised. And she'd smiled—the same smile captured in oils on the canvas now.

She didn't answer now. Dead people never do. But the promise remained.

I lifted the painting carefully from its hooks. The wall compartment behind it was obvious once you knew to look—a hand-width square of stone that pressed inward, revealing a space just large enough for a leather pouch. My father thought he was clever. Merchants always did.

The pouch was heavy. I didn't count the coins—didn't want to know exactly how much I was stealing. Enough for passage to Portare. Enough for the ship to Regalis. Enough to survive in Mali while I figured out how to convince them to accept a student with exactly forty-five Mi and nothing more.

I hung the painting back up, adjusting it until her smile was level. Then I left his chamber exactly as I'd found it. My father would discover the theft when he did his weekly counting. By then I'd be gone, and he'd have to decide if a wayward son was worth chasing.

Back in my chamber, I pulled out the pack I'd hidden under my bed.

Travel clothes. The claymore. The coin pouch—still warm from where I'd tucked it inside my shirt. And the note I needed to write.

I looked at the two gifts on my desk. Kyle's carving—me as a wizard, staff raised. My father's satchel—fine leather, built to last thirty years like my grandfather's.

The carving went into my pack, wrapped carefully in a spare shirt. Too precious to leave behind, even if it hurt to look at. The satchel... I picked it up, tested the weight, opened the compartments. Practical. Well-made. Perfect for carrying documents, coins, supplies on the road.

I'd use my father's gift to chase my mother's dream.

I sat at my desk and pulled out a paper. The words I'd been composing in my head for weeks took only minutes to write:

Father,

I'm sorry. I know this isn't what you want. I know you're afraid of losing me like you lost Mother. But I can't become the person you want me to be without trying to become the person she believed I could be.

I'm going to Mali. I'm going to find a way. And when I come back, it will be as a mage, not a warehouse manager.

Don't come after me. I'm fifteen—a legal adult. This is my choice.

I'm sorry.

- Marcus

I read it one more time, then placed it on my pillow where he'd find it—probably tomorrow noon when he came looking for me. Maybe sooner if Catherine told him about my mood.

I shouldered my pack.

The house was silent. I crept down the stairs, out through the kitchen, across the courtyard where I'd fought Ricardo just yesterday.

The training yard was dark and empty. The practice blade still rested in the rack where I'd left it. Matched pair—one sharp, one blunted. Ricardo had commissioned both five years ago when he'd started training me.

I left the practice sword where it was.

The stable was quiet. Thunderhoof—my gray gelding—nickered softly when I approached, probably expecting our usual morning ride. I saddled him in the dark, moving by memory and habit.

In my pack: everything I'd stolen, everything I'd been given, and the belief that maybe I wasn't as alone as I'd thought.

I led Thunderhoof quietly through the estate gate, not looking back at the house where I'd grown up.

The ride through Conducere's empty streets took an hour. I kept to the shadows, avoiding the night watch, my heart hammering every time I heard footsteps. By the time I reached the northern gate, the sky was just beginning to pale.

~~~

The caravan gathered at Conducere's northern gate as the first light touched the horizon. Six wagons, a dozen guards, and maybe twenty passengers all heading north to Portare on Bahia's coast—seven days travel if weather held. Loren Wolf—the caravan master—was checking manifests when I approached with Thunderhoof.

"Name?" he asked without looking up.

"Marcus. Passage for one, plus the horse."

"Destination?"

"Portare."

"That'll be three gold." He finally looked at me. "You look young for solo travel. Your parents know you're here?"

"I'm fifteen. Legal age."

"Fifteen looks different on different people." He studied me, taking in the sword, the quality of my horse, the pack that probably cost more than most passengers owned. "Rich kid running away?"

"Rich kid traveling," I corrected.

"Uh-huh." He held out his hand. "Three gold. Two for passage, one for the horse. We leave in ten minutes. You cause trouble, you walk. We get attacked by bandits, you help defend or you pay double. Questions?"

I handed him three coins. "Where do I—"

"Rear wagon. There's a kid about your age already there. Talks too much but he paid on time." Loren turned to the next passenger. "Next!"

I led Thunderhoof to the rear of the caravan. A young man sat mounted on a worn pony, maybe nineteen or twenty, dark hair messy, grin too wide for the early hour. Older than me, but not by much.

"You the other solo traveler?" he asked. "Loren said I'd have company. Gustin Green." He stuck out his hand.

"Marcus." I shook it.

"First time on the northern route?"

"First time leaving Conducere," I admitted.

"Ah, city kid." He said it without judgment, just observation. "I'm from Planus—little village west of here. Took me five days just to get to Conducere." He patted his pony's neck. "Been saving for this trip since I was twelve."

The caravan lurched into motion. I swung onto Thunderhoof's saddle. Gustin fell in beside me as we started north.

"So," he said after we'd cleared the gates. "Where are you heading after Portare?"

"Haven't decided yet."

He laughed. "Right. Well, I'm taking the ship to Regalis. Then Mali." He glanced at me. "Academia Midur. Figured I'd see if this was worth the three years I spent saving for the journey."

I was quiet for a moment, weighing whether to admit it.

"Same route?" he asked.

"Maybe."

"That's a yes." He grinned and pulled folded paper from his jacket. "Got my conditional acceptance two months ago. Provisional enrollment, pending testing on arrival."

My stomach dropped. "Conditional acceptance?"

"Yeah. They want me to demonstrate spell mastery when I get there." He waved the letter. "My surrogate father wrote them—he's an alumni. Helped, I think."

"How many spells?"

"Seven." He said it casually. "What about you? You got your letter yet?"

The answer stuck in my throat. "What's your Mi value?"

"Forty-eight. You?"

"Forty-five."

His eyebrows rose. "Right at the Point. That's... optimistic."

I didn't answer. Didn't need to. The gap between us was already clear—three Mi points, seven spells, a conditional acceptance letter, an alumni connection.

And I had one spell, no letter, and a desperate hope that Academia Midur would care.

We rode in silence for a while. Conducere's walls shrank behind us, the rising sun turning the eastern sky copper and gold.

"So no acceptance letter?" Gustin asked finally.

"No."

"But you're going anyway."

"I'm going anyway."

He was quiet for a moment. Then: "That's either really brave or really stupid."

"Probably both."

"Fair enough." He tucked the letter away. "Well, if they reject you on arrival, at least you'll have seen the City of Magic. That's worth something, right?"

I thought about Isabella and Lucia back in Conducere. The letter tucked in my pack felt heavier than it should. They'd helped me. Believed in me. Given me resources and connections when they could have told my father instead.

About the twins and their insufferable confidence. About my father reading my note. About Ricardo's words in the training yard.

You're not running toward magic. You're running toward the work of becoming something no one expects.

"Yeah," I said, touching the pocket where Isabella's letter rested. "It's worth something."

The road stretched ahead—days of travel, then the sea crossing, then Mali. And whatever came after that.

Gustin started talking—about his village in Planus, about the chief who'd tested him, about the seven spells he'd learned from the old mage before leaving. I listened and answered, watching Conducere's towers catch the morning sun behind us.

Somewhere in that sprawling city, my father would be discovering I was gone. Catherine would find the note. Ricardo would see the empty training yard. Matthew would ask where I'd gone. Isabella and Lucia would know I'd left without saying goodbye.

Everything I'd known—the estate, the training yard, my mother's grave, the comfortable cage of a predetermined life—shrank with each step until distance swallowed it all.

I didn't look back again.

Ahead, the road stretched toward everything I'd gambled my life on.
