chapters.content_text:
Chapter 2 - The Road to Portare

The first night on the road, I couldn't sleep.

We'd made camp in a clearing just off the main route, six wagons circled for protection, a fire burning in the center. The horses—including Thunderhoof—were picketed on the far side of the circle, close enough to guard but far enough not to spook if something approached. Gustin had fallen asleep mid-sentence, curled up in his bedroll near the warmth. A few other passengers slept around the fire; most preferred the shelter of the wagons.

The guards rotated watches. I sat with my back against a wheel, watching the stars.

"Can't sleep either?"

I looked over. One of the wagon drivers—a woman maybe thirty years old, weathered from years on the road—settled down near the fire across from me.

"First time traveling?" she asked.

"That obvious?"

"Keep touching your pack. Checking it's still there." She poured herself tea from a pot hanging over the fire. "Either first journey or carrying something you can't afford to lose."

"Both."

She smiled. "Helena. Been driving for Loren six years now. You?"

"Marcus. Been running away for about twelve hours."

That got a laugh. "Honest. I like that." She sipped her tea. "Let me guess—heading to one of the academies? Parents don't approve?"

"Parent. Singular. And no, he doesn't."

"But going anyway."

"I'm going anyway."

Helena was quiet for a moment, steam rising from her cup. "Tested at thirty-two when I was sixteen."

I knew that number. Below the threshold. Below even mine.

She sipped her tea. "Mother cried for a week. Kept saying maybe the test was wrong, maybe I'd grow into it."

"And your father?"

"More practical. Suggested runic array etching—figured if I couldn't cast spells, at least I could help make 'em." She smiled slightly. "Spent two years apprenticed to an enchanter in Conducere."

"In Conducere?" I leaned forward. "Which one?"

"Master Aldwin's shop. Near the eastern market." She traced the rim of her cup. "Learned to etch arrays onto scrolls, tools, focus stones. Good work. Steady."

"But you're driving wagons now."

"Yeah." She stared into her tea for a long moment. Somewhere in the darkness, one of the horses nickered softly. "Turns out spending every day etching arrays for spells you'll never cast... that's its own kind of torture."

I thought about my father's warehouses. The life he wanted me to accept.

"Watching mages come in," she continued, "pick up your work, walk out and do things you never will." She shrugged, but there was weight in the gesture. "After two years I couldn't take it anymore. Quit. Found Loren. Been driving ever since." She gestured at the wagon. "Been all over Rivus now. Seen things most folk only hear about in stories."

"Do you regret it?" I asked. "Leaving the arrays?"

"Sometimes. I was good at it. Real good." She considered. "But mostly? No. Found my path. Maybe wasn't the one I wanted at sixteen, but it's mine. And I sleep better not being reminded every day of what I can't do."

I looked back at the stars. "What if you can't accept any other path? What if the one you want is the only one you'll walk, even if it's impossible?"

She was quiet for a moment. "Then you walk it until you can't anymore. Or until you prove it wasn't impossible after all." She stood, stretched. "So what's your Mi value?"

I hesitated. "Forty-five."

She nodded slowly. "Right at the Point. Got your acceptance letter?"

I looked away. She didn't need to hear me say no.

"They'll use that against you. Not worth the risk, they'll say. Safer to teach you to accept your limits than let you try and fail." She sipped her tea. "That's how they think. Academies ain't kind to disappointment."

She headed back to her wagon, leaving me with the fire and the stars and the weight of everything I'd left behind.

I wondered if Catherine had found my note yet. If Matthew had asked where I'd gone. If Ricardo already knew I'd left the practice sword behind, and what he thought it meant.

Two days until Lorisfort. Four more after that to Portare. Then the ocean, Regalis, and Mali.

And somewhere in there, I'd have to figure out what came after they rejected me.

Because they would reject me. Helena was right. Forty-five Mi was optimistic at best, delusional at worst.

But I was already here. Already gone. Already committed.

So I'd see it through.

I finally drifted off sometime before dawn, dreaming of my mother's garden and earth rising at my command.

~~~

After two nights of sleeping under the stars, Lorisfort appeared on the third day like a promise of civilization.

The fortress city sat astride the main trade route, walls twice the height of any village we'd passed. Guard towers at each corner, the banner of Mercari flying above the gates—red and gold snapping in the wind. The smells hit us before we entered: forge smoke, horse dung, roasting meat, and underneath it all, the acrid tang of magic from the tower district. Inside, the sounds of commerce and life echoed—smiths hammering, merchants hawking, the organized chaos of a city that existed to serve the road.

"We're stopping here for the night," Loren announced as we approached. "Resupply, let the horses rest. Anyone wants to stay longer, you're on your own. We leave at dawn for Portare."

The caravan rolled through the gates, wheels clattering on cobblestones worn smooth by centuries of traffic. Inside, Lorisfort was everything the villages hadn't been—crowded, loud, alive. Guild contracts were pinned to public boards. Taverns spilled patrons onto the streets, their laughter mixing with the cries of vendors. Merchants sold everything from daggers to enchanted trinkets, their stalls crowding the main thoroughfare so tightly we had to slow to a walk.

"Look at that," Gustin said, pointing to a building with a sign reading "Guardians Guild." A massive Sher warrior emerged—battle axe across their back, golden fur catching the afternoon sun. Silver Guardians Guild badge on their chest.

"Long way from home," Gustin muttered, watching them disappear into the crowd. "Wonder what contract brought them east."

I'd seen Sher in Conducere—merchant guards, mostly. But never one wearing a Guild badge. "Hunting something dangerous, probably."

"Glad we haven't run into bandits," Gustin said.

"Give it time," I said dryly. "We've got four more days to Portare."

~~~

That night, I bought Gustin and myself rooms at a proper inn. The Nobel Inn—two silver each, not cheap, but I could manage it. After days sleeping on hard ground, an actual bed seemed worth the cost.

The common room was loud when we entered. Travelers, locals, a few guards from the city watch. The smell of roasted meat and ale mixed with woodsmoke and sweat. We found seats near the back and ordered beef and weak ale.

The food arrived quickly—steaming beef, dark bread, butter that was probably a day from turning. "Finally, real food," Gustin said, already tearing into the bread.

I was about to agree when a voice cut through the ambient noise—loud, slightly slurred, carrying the particular confidence of someone three drinks past sober.

"—took down eight of 'em. Eight! And Bauros wasn't even wearing full plate." The speaker was a human man, maybe thirty, wearing travel-stained leathers with a Guild medallion on his chest. Silver rank. Guardian Guild. "Just that massive axe and his honor. Red Canyon bandits thought they had an easy mark. One Sher traveling alone."

His companions laughed. Another Guardian—younger, maybe bronze rank—leaned forward. "What happened?"

"What d'you think happened?" The older Guardian—Kerrick, someone had called him—grinned. "Bauros introduced 'em to Narasimha's judgment. By the time the merchant caravan caught up, there were eight bodies and one very annoyed lion-folk cleaning blood off his fur."

"Impressive," the younger Guardian said.

"Impressive?" Kerrick's voice rose. "It's legendary! That route's been safe two months since. Every bandit from here to Vallis knows what happens when you threaten Guardian-protected cargo. The Sher's honor holds."

"Or," a new voice cut in, sharp and condescending, "one combat mage could have neutralized the threat without the theatrics."

I looked over. A young man—early twenties, dark hair pulled back, expensive robes with Lorisfort's mage tower insignia—sat at a nearby table with a book open in front of him. Long, pale fingers turned pages with deliberate precision. He hadn't looked up from whatever he was reading.

Kerrick's grin vanished. "What was that?"

"I said," the apprentice—Evander, I'd heard someone call him earlier—finally looked up, "that a moderately skilled mage could have neutralized eight bandits with a single Blast spell. Or a Confusion charm. Or even a properly placed Barrier. Your friend's accomplishment is… quaint. But hardly efficient."

The tavern got quieter. Not silent—conversation continued—but people were paying attention now.

"Quaint." Kerrick's jaw worked. "Bauros saved that caravan. Twelve merchants, their families, guards. All alive 'cause he was there."

"And I am certain they are grateful." The apprentice closed his book, sitting rigidly upright. "But let us be honest. Qi warriors such as your Bauros are solving problems the difficult way. Magic is demonstrably superior in every practical measure."

"Superior?" The younger Guardian spoke up now. "When's the last time a wizard protected a trade route?"

"When was the last time such protection proved necessary?" The apprentice stood, warming to his argument. "Guardian Guilds exist because magic remains uncommon. If more individuals possessed proper Mi values and training, your profession would become obsolete. You are, essentially, stopgaps. Necessary, perhaps, but hardly admirable."

"Stopgaps?" Kerrick was on his feet too. "We're stopgaps? Who supplies your precious Beast cores for research? Hunter Guilds. Who protects the merchants that feed your cities? Guardian Guilds. But sure, wave your hands and pretend you're superior while we do the actual work."

"The actual work?" The apprentice laughed. "Swinging swords at bandits is labor a trained dog could perform. Magic requires years of study, precise understanding of runic arrays, mental discipline—"

"And seven, eight seconds to cast while glowing like a forge," Kerrick shot back. "Your Blast's real impressive when you're dead before the spell completes. You start building that array, every bandit sees the shimmer, feels the heat. They scatter or fill you with arrows."

A few people laughed. Others nodded. The apprentice's face reddened.

"If you possessed proper Mi values, you wouldn't require such primitive Qi enhancement. You're making a virtue of limitation."

"And you're making a religion of privilege." Kerrick stepped closer. "Not everyone tests high enough for your fancy academies. Some of us develop Qi instead. Serve our communities. Protect people. But I guess that ain't noble enough for wizard-folk."

"It is not a matter of nobility. It is a matter of capability." The apprentice's voice dripped condescension. "Qi users are valuable—I never suggested otherwise. But let us not pretend you are equals. A properly trained mage will always prove more effective."

"More effective at running when things get real," someone from Kerrick's table muttered.

"More effective at solving problems efficiently," the apprentice countered. "Your Bauros spent what—ten minutes? Fifteen?—fighting eight men with an axe. One Blast spell. Eight seconds of casting, every bandit at the campfire burning. Problem resolved."

"IF you can cast it before they kill you. IF you got the Mana. IF you're actually there instead of hiding in your tower reading books." Kerrick's hands clenched. "Guardians show up. We do the job. Every time. That's why merchants hire us instead of waiting for some wizard to maybe feel like helping."

"Merchants hire you because you are cheap."

The temperature in the tavern dropped. Even the people who'd been ignoring the argument turned to watch.

Kerrick's voice went very quiet. "Say that again."

"I said you are cheap. Affordable. The budget option for those who cannot afford actual magical protection." The apprentice smiled. "Which, again, is valuable. Society requires affordable services. But do not mistake affordability for superiority."

For a second, I thought Kerrick would throw a punch. His Qi was probably enhanced enough to hit like a sledgehammer. The apprentice's hands moved to gesture positions—preparing a shield spell, maybe.

"Enough." The tavern keeper—a barrel-chested Dwarf with a voice like grinding stone—stepped between them. "You want to fight, take it outside. You want to drink, sit down and shut up. Choose."

Kerrick glared at the apprentice. The apprentice stared back, smug and certain.

"Not worth it," Kerrick finally said. He dropped coins on his table. "Come on. This place smells like failed potential anyway." He and his companions headed for the door, Guild medallions catching lamplight.

The apprentice sat back down. His hands shook slightly as he opened his book, but within a minute he was reading again, pretending nothing had happened.

Conversation resumed slowly. The tension bled out. Within minutes, it was just another night at a busy tavern.

I realized my hands were clenched around my fork.

"Well," Gustin said lightly, "that was unpleasant."

I forced myself to relax. "Yeah."

"That got ugly fast." Gustin took a drink, looking uncomfortable. He hesitated. "I mean, what the apprentice said about efficiency—that's what they teach, right? Magic is more effective than Qi for most problems." He stared at his cup. "But the way he said it. Calling them 'cheap'... that was cruel."

Something in my chest tightened. "The Guardian made some points too."

The tale has been stolen; if detected on Amazon, report the violation.

"He did." Gustin nodded slowly. "The thing about wizards hiding in towers while Guardians do the actual protecting—that hit home." He smiled, but it was uncertain. "Look, I respect what Guardian Guilds do. Honestly. But we're going to Mali to become mages, and I want that." He trailed off.

"Ricardo—my sword instructor—developed Qi," I heard myself say. "He's one of the most capable people I know."

"I'm sure he is. For what he does." Gustin shrugged. "But he's not a wizard, right? Can't cast Fireball. Can't manipulate Mana. He's developed within his limitations. That's admirable. But it's still limitation."

I thought about Ricardo's practice blade coming at me in the training yard. The way he moved—fast enough that my Terra Form was the only thing giving me a chance. The fact that he'd been teaching me for five years, and I still couldn't beat him.

The fact that his "limitations" had made him more dangerous than most people I'd seen.

"You're quiet," Gustin observed.

"Just thinking."

"About?"

I set down my fork, the weight of the realization settling in my chest like a stone.

About how the apprentice had looked at Kerrick the way academy administrators looked at my Mi score. The same dismissive assessment. The same certainty that numbers—forty-five Mi, Qi enhancement instead of Mana manipulation—meant someone wasn't worth serious consideration.

You're making a virtue of limitation, the apprentice had said.

Forty-five Mi is technically the threshold, the academy administrator in Mercari had told my father, but practically speaking, students below fifty struggle to keep pace. We recommend he pursue other opportunities.

Different words. Same message. You're not good enough for what you want to be.

I'd been so angry at those administrators. And now here I was, listening to Gustin—my friend, someone I genuinely liked—say that Ricardo's Qi development was admirable but still limitation.

My hands clenched under the table.

Ricardo, who could move faster than my eyes could follow. Who'd spent five years teaching me technique I'd thought was pointless. Who'd known I was integrating Terra Form into his kata and never said a word about it, just kept drilling the forms until they were perfect.

Every movement should have purpose, he'd said. No wasted motion.

What if he'd seen what I was too stubborn to notice—that someone with forty-five Mi wasn't going to succeed by trying to be a conventional mage? That I needed something different, something hybrid, something that drew on both physical discipline and magical theory?

What if those five years I'd spent resenting his "practical" training were actually him preparing me for the path I'd chosen?

The thought sat uncomfortably in my chest. And underneath it, something worse: I was sitting here with stolen coins and no acceptance letter, betting everything that I could prove I belonged in the wizard category. The superior category, if I believed the apprentice. The category that looked down on Guardians as affordable labor, on Qi users as people who'd accepted their limitations.

My throat felt tight.

I wanted to be a wizard desperately enough to leave my family, steal from my father, abandon everything I'd known. But what did that make me? Someone fighting against unfair dismissal? Or someone so desperate to be part of the group that dismissed people like Ricardo—like me—that I was willing to become exactly what I hated?

If I made it to Mali and somehow survived, would I look at the next desperate kid with barely-qualifying numbers and see someone worth teaching? Or would I become the kind of mage who forgot that Ricardo's "limitations" made him more dangerous than half the certified wizards in Mercari?

Would I forget where I came from?

The guilt twisted deeper. Not just for stealing the coins or leaving my father. But for wanting so badly to belong to the group that didn't think people like me—people like Kerrick, people like Ricardo—belonged at all.

I forced myself to breathe slowly. The tavern felt too warm, too loud.

He's developed within his limitations, Gustin had said about Ricardo. That's admirable. But it's still limitation.

And I'd nodded. Hadn't defended the man who'd spent five years training me. Because part of me agreed. Part of me thought magic was superior, that if I could just prove I had what it took, I'd be better than the people who developed Qi instead.

My jaw ached. I'd been clenching it without realizing.

That made me just as bad as the smug apprentice. Maybe worse, because I knew what it felt like to be dismissed. And I was still trying to join the people who did the dismissing.

"Nothing important," I said finally, the words feeling hollow. "Just... that got uglier than it needed to."

"Agreed." Gustin pushed his empty plate aside. The tavern noise had returned to normal—dice rolling at a corner table, someone laughing near the bar. "So. Explain the speed thing with Terra Form again. You said less than a second?"

"Roughly half a second, maybe a bit faster." I leaned back, the chair creaking. "There's still a fraction between intention and effect. But in combat, it feels nearly instant—fast enough that I don't think about casting anymore, just about moving."

Gustin leaned back, thoughtful. "See, that's what I don't understand. Practice improves control—range, precision, power efficiency. But not speed, not really."

"Why not?"

"Because the array structure is fixed." He picked up his cup, realized it was empty, set it down. "Ignite's been optimized for centuries—I've been casting it for three years, and it still takes two seconds. Same as the theoretical minimum."

"Maybe Terra Form is just simpler?"

"It's not." Gustin shook his head. "Terra Form has six to eight rune modifications depending on complexity. Ignite only has three. Terra Form should be slower, not faster."

A serving girl passed our table, collecting empty plates. Gustin waited until she moved on.

"But you said you practice while doing sword forms?"

"Ricardo made me. Thought I was wasting time on magic, wanted me focused on fighting."

"But what if he was onto something?" Gustin's eyes lit up with that look people get when they're chasing an idea. "What if the movement helps somehow?"

I frowned. "How?"

"Like—okay, hear me out—" He leaned forward, hands gesturing. "Your body learns to cast while moving, so maybe the spell becomes part of the motion? Instead of something you stop to do?"

I'd never thought about it that way. "Traditional mages stand still when they cast."

"Exactly. They can move, but they don't." Gustin nodded. "Movement makes mistakes more likely. And mistakes..." He grimaced. "With utility spells, you just fizzle. With combat spells, you explode."

"Comforting."

"So everyone learns to stand still for precision. But you don't." He grinned. "Half a second is way faster than the three to five seconds most texts describe for Terra Form. Even faster than my Ignite."

"So you think I found an optimization?"

"If you've gotten it down to half a second..." He shook his head. "That's actually brilliant. Probably only works for simple spells integrated into physical movement, but for something like Terra Form in combat? That's a real advantage."

"An advantage that still only gets me one spell."

"One spell with an eighty percent reduction in cast time." Gustin's expression turned serious. "Marcus, mages have built entire careers on optimizations like that. If you can teach it to others, document the technique..." He paused. "That's the kind of discovery that gets you noticed. Maybe even published."

I thought about that. Published. Noticed. All things that required being inside the system I was trying to break into.

"First I have to get to Mali," I said.

"Right." He stood, swaying slightly from the ale. "Come on. We should sleep. Tomorrow's another day of watching Loren argue with every village elder between here and Portare."

We made our way upstairs. Separate rooms—small luxury, but worth it for the privacy.

I lay in the narrow bed, listening to the city outside. Lorisfort. I'd been to Fluminis before with my father, but always under his watch, staying in merchant quarters he'd arranged. This was different. First night sleeping somewhere entirely on my own terms, in a city my father wouldn't find me.

My pack sat beside the bed, Isabella's letter tucked inside my father's leather satchel. Tomorrow we'd keep moving. Four more days to Portare, then I'd use that letter, meet her aunt, figure out the next step.

One day at a time.

One step closer to Mali.

I fell asleep thinking about earth rising beneath my feet, and whether movement really did make magic faster, and what it would mean if Gustin was right.

~~~

The days after Lorisfort fell into the same rhythm we'd established since leaving Conducere. Wake at dawn, run through Ricardo's kata while the others packed camp. Ride north with Gustin talking about magical theory and his village in Planus. Practice sword forms in the evening while the guards set up the perimeter. Camp under stars. Repeat.

My legs ached from days in the saddle. Thunderhoof handled it better than I did—steady as always while I shifted position every hour trying to find comfort that didn't exist. The sun turned my neck red and my lips cracked despite drinking from the water skins.

Twice the guards spotted what they suspected were bandits—distant figures watching from tree lines—but they never attacked. Six wagons with a dozen armed guards was too much trouble for easy pickings.

On the second day out from Lorisfort, we stopped at a village around noon for water and supplies. The village elder insisted on inspecting every wagon for contraband, poking through grain sacks and asking questions about destinations. He found nothing but wasted an hour of daylight anyway.

While the inspection dragged on, a blacksmith's daughter sold us meat pies from a basket, her hands permanently stained with soot. Gustin bought two. I bought three—one for later. A one-eyed innkeeper tried charging double for baths. "Because I can," he said with a gap-toothed grin. We didn't pay. Loren got the caravan moving before anyone could waste more coin on the luxury of hot water.

Gustin and I fell into easy companionship. We argued about whether Mi values could be improved through training (he said no, I said maybe, neither of us knew for certain).

~~~

On the third day out from Lorisfort, Gustin asked about my family.

We were riding side by side, the morning sun warm on our backs, when he said, "You never talk about them. Your father—he's a merchant, right? Warehouses in Conducere?"

I kept my eyes on the road ahead. "Four warehouses. Import goods from across Rivus."

"Successful, then."

"Very."

Silence stretched between us. Gustin shifted in his saddle. "And your mother?"

"Died when I was seven." The words came out flat, automatic. I'd said them so many times they'd lost their weight.

"I'm sorry." He meant it—I could hear it in his voice. "Was she... did she have magic? Is that where your Terra Form comes from?"

"She taught me the array. Showed me how to shape earth." I watched Thunderhoof's ears flick forward and back. "She was the one who believed I could be a mage. Taught me when I was seven, a few months before she died. Everyone just... assumed I'd be fine. That if I could cast that young, I'd have enough Mi to make it work." I paused. "Then I got tested three months ago. Forty-five. Right at the threshold. The academies in Mercari weren't interested."

"And your father doesn't believe that."

It wasn't a question. I didn't answer it anyway.

"Marcus—"

"He's practical," I said, cutting him off before he could dig deeper. "He builds things. Manages people. Plans for the future. And in his plans, I inherit the business, marry well, produce heirs, and carry on the family legacy his father built from nothing." I heard the bitterness in my own voice and tried to soften it. "He's not wrong to want that. It's a good life. Secure. Useful."

"But not what you want."

"No." I looked at him finally. "Not what I want."

Gustin was quiet for a moment, studying me with that analytical expression he got when he was working through a problem. "Chief Aldric—my surrogate father who adopted me after my parents died—threw himself into helping me when Old man Corvin said I should apply to Academia Midur."

"Old man Corvin?"

"My teacher. Retired mage, settled in Arvum." Gustin shifted in his saddle. "The village needs capable people, and sending me to Mali meant the whole community had to pool resources."

I thought about my father's wealth. The coins I'd stolen. "That's a lot of pressure."

He smiled slightly. "Chief Aldric spent a week running the numbers, weighing the village's needs against my potential. But he graduated from Academia Midur himself—studied there before he came back to lead Arvum."

"So he understood what it would take?"

"More than anyone." Gustin's expression softened. "Once he committed, he did everything. Helped me crystallize my Mana before I left."

"Before you left? That's early."

"Yeah. And he wrote this incredibly detailed letter to the Academy documenting every spell I'd mastered. That's what got me the conditional acceptance."

"That's... that's really good of him."

"Yeah." Gustin looked away. The road stretched ahead, empty except for a distant merchant cart. "Makes the pressure worse, though. He sacrificed a lot to give me this chance. The whole village did."

"What do they expect?"

"Someone from Arvum becoming a certified mage?" He shrugged. "That's status. Connections. Maybe magical support when crops fail or Beasts threaten the livestock. So he understands why I'm going. But the weight of all those expectations..." He trailed off.

"My father understands why I'm going," I said. "He just thinks I'm making a mistake. That I'm throwing away certainty for a dream that'll break me."

"And maybe he's right."

I looked at him sharply.

"Not about the dream being wrong," Gustin said quickly. "But about it breaking you. Mali's not going to be easy, Marcus. Forty-five Mi, no acceptance letter, no connections inside the academy..." He met my eyes. "It could break you. Or make you into something your father never imagined."

The words sat between us for a long moment.

"I guess we'll find out," I said finally.

We rode in silence after that, but it was a different kind of silence. Comfortable. Like something had been acknowledged that didn't need further discussion.

~~~

On the fourth and final day out from Lorisfort, we stopped for the midday meal at a clearing where other travelers had clearly rested before—fire pit ringed with smoke-blackened stones, logs worn smooth from countless bodies, space for the horses to graze on new-green grass.

I finished eating before the others and found myself moving through Ricardo's training forms without thinking about it. The first sequence—low guard to high, weight shifting, imagining an opponent's strike. I'd been running through them every morning and evening when the caravan stopped—muscle memory demanding the practice even without Ricardo there to correct my stance. Most of the travelers ignored me. The guards occasionally watched with professional interest, but nobody had asked about it yet.

"You do that a lot."

I turned. Gustin was watching from where he sat on one of the logs, his own meal finished.

"Old habit," I said. "Ricardo—my sword instructor—drilled these into me for five years."

"The same Ricardo who thought you were wasting time on magic?"

I nodded, returning to the form. Low guard. High strike. Step and turn. "For years he wanted me focused on something practical. Then after I got tested three months ago and the academies rejected me, he said maybe magic wasn't the path for someone at the Om Point. That I should consider Qi development instead."

"But you practiced anyway."

"Had to do both." I moved through the next sequence, feeling the familiar burn in my shoulders. "Sword forms in the morning, magic practice at night. Ricardo didn't like it, but he couldn't stop me from casting on my own time."

Gustin stood and walked closer, watching my movements with that same analytical expression. "You're doing it now."

"Doing what?"

"Casting. Or preparing to cast." He gestured at my feet. "Your weight distribution—that's not just sword work. You're setting up for Terra Form."

I stopped mid-movement. Looked down at my stance. He was right. I hadn't even realized I was doing it—my body had started shifting into the stance I used when I wanted to raise earth quickly.

"Huh."

"It's integrated," Gustin said slowly, like he was working through the idea as he spoke. "The sword forms and the spell. You don't separate them in your mind anymore, do you?"

"I... no. I guess I don't." I thought about it, wiping sweat from my forehead. The sun was getting high. "Ricardo always said every movement should have purpose. No wasted motion."

"Smart."

"When I started practicing Terra Form during the forms, it felt wrong at first—like I was doing both things badly. But after a few months..." I shrugged. "It started feeling natural. Like the movement and the magic were part of the same thing."

"That's why it's so fast." Gustin's eyes were bright with excitement now. "You're not stopping to cast."

"I'm not?"

"No—you're casting while you move, and your body already knows the motion so well that there's no hesitation, no second-guessing." He was pacing now, working through it. "The spell becomes part of the physical technique."

"Maybe." I wiped sweat from my forehead. "Ricardo never talked about it like that. He just kept drilling the forms until I could do them in my sleep."

"Did he know? That you were practicing magic during his training?"

"Probably. Ricardo notices everything." I smiled slightly, remembering that ridiculous mustache bouncing as he corrected my stance for the thousandth time. "He never said anything about it, though. Just kept making me repeat the sequences until they were perfect."

Gustin sat back down on the log. Behind him, I could see Loren talking to one of the other wagon drivers. We'd be moving soon.

"Five years of integrated practice," Gustin said. "No wonder your casting speed breaks the normal patterns."

"You think it's that simple?"

He shook his head. "This is the kind of thing that could actually be studied. Written up."

"Maybe."

"If you could teach it to others..."

"First I have to survive Mali," I said, cutting him off. "Then maybe we can worry about whether anyone wants to learn from someone with forty-five Mi."

"They will." Gustin's voice had surprising certainty. "If you can prove it works—really works, not just for you but as a teachable technique—they'll want to learn."

"Even the ones who think people like me are beneath them?"

He grinned. "Especially them. Nothing gets a mage's attention like someone doing something they think is impossible."

I wanted to believe him. Wanted to think that my years of resentful sword practice and stubborn magic training had added up to something valuable.

But standing there in a dusty clearing on the road to Portare, still weeks away from Mali and months away from proving anything, I couldn't quite let myself hope that far ahead.

"Come on," I said instead. "Loren's packing up. We should get moving."

But as I climbed back into Thunderhoof's saddle, I caught myself smiling.

Maybe Gustin was right. Maybe this thing I'd stumbled into—this weird fusion of Ricardo's training and my mother's magic—was something worth studying.

Maybe it was something that could matter.

After the meal, we climbed back into our saddles and continued north. By afternoon, the land started to change.

"Smell that?" Gustin asked.

Salt. The ocean. We'd been climbing gradual hills for hours, and now at the crest, I could see it.

Thunderhoof's ears swiveled forward, nostrils flaring at the unfamiliar scent. He shifted beneath me, uneasy with something he'd never encountered.

Portare.

The city sprawled along the coast like something out of a painting. Buildings stacked against hillsides, the harbor below packed with ships of every size. Masts like a forest of wood and canvas. The ocean beyond stretching to the horizon, blue and vast.

I'd never seen the ocean before. Neither had Thunderhoof.

Ricardo had described it once, comparing sword stance to the way sailors balanced on ships. But nothing prepared me for the scale. The way it just... ended at the sky, a line so distant the horizon seemed more concept than place. The smell of salt mixed with fish and tar and something else I couldn't name—something alive and old and vast.

"Big, isn't it?" Gustin said quietly.

My chest felt tight. "Yeah."

The caravan descended toward the city gates. Larger than Lorisfort. Larger than Conducere, even—grown wild from centuries of unplanned trade, every merchant nation on Rivus sending ships here, the city expanding in layers like a shell built by uncountable hands. Bahia's capital port, gateway to the world, where ships left daily for every coast and continent.

Somewhere down there was Isabella's aunt. A room. Connections.

And a ship that would take me across that impossible blue expanse to Regalis.

The guards at Portare's gates waved the caravan through with barely a glance. Inside, the city swallowed us—sounds and smells and people from every race and nation. Thunderhoof's steps became more careful, picking through the crowded streets with the caution of a horse unused to cities this size. The salt air thickened with humanity: unwashed bodies, spiced cooking from a dozen cultures, rotting fish guts in the gutters, perfume from passing merchants, and underneath it all the constant smell of tar from the shipyards. Humans, yes, but also Dwarves with their elaborate beards, a few Bandar merchants chattering in that rapid way they had, even a Naga near the waterfront coiled on a platform built for their serpentine bodies.

"This is it," Loren called out as the caravan reached a large square. "End of the line for those going to Portare. Anyone continuing north to Varesh in Vallis, we depart day after tomorrow. Same spot, dawn."

Passengers began disembarking. Merchants checking their goods. Travelers heading off in different directions.

I slid off Thunderhoof's saddle, legs stiff and protesting after seven days of riding. The cobblestones felt strange under my feet after so long in the saddle—solid, unmoving, final.

This was it. The edge of everything I'd known. Beyond this city lay an ocean I'd never crossed, a nation I'd never been, and an academy that had no idea I was coming.

Gustin dismounted beside me, looking around with the same mixture of awe and uncertainty I felt. "Well," he said. "Here we are."

"Here we are," I echoed.

The city sprawled in every direction—ships and warehouses and people from a dozen nations all moving with purpose I couldn't fathom. Somewhere in this chaos was Isabella's aunt. A room. Connections that might lead to passage across that impossible expanse of water.

And somehow, between here and Mali, I had to figure out how to become the person who deserved to be there.

"Good luck," Gustin said, shouldering his pack. "Maybe I'll see you at Academia Midur. If we both make it."

I watched him start to turn away, then heard myself say: "Wait."

He looked back.

The words came before I'd fully formed the thought. But standing here at the edge of the known world, watching the only person who'd shown genuine interest in my theories about to walk away—I couldn't let that happen. Not when I had so much to learn and so little time to learn it.

"I have a proposition," I said.

chapters.content_text:
Chapter 3 - Portare

We moved away from the caravan square toward a quieter side street. The market chaos faded to background noise—merchants shouting prices, horses being led to stables, the distant cries of gulls circling the harbor.

I needed to say this right. Gustin had been generous with his time and knowledge during the journey. I couldn't just assume he'd agree to more.

"A proposition," I said, meeting his eyes. "About passage to Regalis."

Gustin raised an eyebrow. "What do you mean?"

"Ship passage to Regalis won't be cheap," I said. The words came faster now, like I was trying to convince myself as much as him. "I've got coin. You've got knowledge I need."

He tilted his head, curious. "What kind of knowledge?"

"Spell arrays. Two of them—something fundamental." I shifted my pack higher on my shoulder. "Teach me the theory during the voyage, and I'll pay for your passage to Regalis."

Gustin stared at me. For a long moment, the only sound was the bustle around us—merchants haggling, horses being led away, the distant cry of gulls.

"Marcus," he said finally. "You know that knowing an array won't let you cast the spell, right? You still need the Mi capacity, a crystallized Mana core—"

"I know."

"—and even if you had enough Mana, you'd need years of practice to stabilize the array properly, and that's assuming you don't—"

"I know," I said again. "But after what you said about movement and casting speed..." I met his eyes. "Maybe I can't use conventional spells now. But I want to understand how they work. The structure. The theory. How the runes interact."

"Why?" He wasn't being dismissive—genuinely curious. "If you can't cast them, what's the point?"

I thought about Ricardo's training. Five years of sword forms I'd resented because they weren't magic. Five years that had somehow made my Terra Form faster than any academy text said was possible. Five years of learning things I didn't understand the value of until much later.

"Because I don't know what I'll need to know," I said. "And maybe understanding how standard spells work will help me figure out... something else. Something that works for someone like me."

Gustin was quiet, studying me with that same analytical look he got when we discussed magical theory. "You're serious about this. About finding a way forward even without traditional training."

"I'm going to Mali either way. With or without an acceptance letter. With or without enough Mi to satisfy their standards." I heard the stubbornness in my own voice. "I'd rather go knowing more than I do now."

"Ship passage to Regalis..." He rubbed his jaw, calculating. "Decent berths run twenty, maybe thirty gold per person. You sure you can manage that?"

"I only promised to pay for your passage," I said. "Who said it has to be decent?"

That got a laugh. "Fair point." He considered for a moment. "Learning arrays you can't cast yet. That's either brilliant or insane. Maybe both."

"Knowledge is never useless." I meant it. "And I think you're curious enough to see where this goes. You said it yourself—my Terra Form speed doesn't match the theoretical models. What if there are other rules that don't work the way the academies think they do?"

Gustin's eyes lit up with that look people get when they're chasing an idea. "You think this is something you could teach someone else? Not just something that works for you?"

"I don't know. Maybe." I shrugged. "But I won't figure it out by pretending I don't need help. You know things I don't. I can pay for that knowledge. And honestly?" I smiled slightly. "I'd rather spend the voyage learning something useful than staring at water and panicking about what happens when we dock."

He studied me for a long moment. Then a slow grin spread across his face. "Ignite and Barrier."

"Two spells?"

"Two completely different foundational approaches." His enthusiasm was building now. "Heat generation versus force shaping. Between them, you'll understand how spell construction actually works—how to read runic arrays, why elements interact the way they do."

"That's... more than I expected."

"Well, if I'm going to teach you, I'm going to do it properly." He extended his hand. "Deal. I teach you spell theory, you get me to Regalis. We'll find the cheapest passage we can and make do."

We shook on it. His grip was firm, his smile genuine.

"So I'm paying for ship passage to learn spells I can't actually use," I said. "My father would be proud of my business sense."

Gustin laughed. "Look at it this way—you'll have the theory down perfectly before you can embarrass yourself trying to cast them."

"That's... actually not comforting."

He smiled, but the expression faded quickly. We both knew what was at stake.

"One more thing," I said. "My contact here—Isabella's aunt, she runs a boarding house. Might know about ship captains, reliable passage. Instead of both of us hunting separately for lodging and information..." I hesitated. "Want to come with me? Meet her?"

"You barely know me."

"I know you spent three days explaining magical theory to someone with forty-five Mi. I know you think I might have found an actual optimization instead of just dismissing it as luck." I shifted my pack. "That's more than I know about most people."

Gustin considered this, then nodded. "Alright. Let's meet your contact. What's her name?"

"Maria. Maria Castelli. Runs a place called Tidewatch."

"Tidewatch." He grinned. "At least it sounds maritime. That's got to be a good sign."

We gathered our things and headed into Portare proper, leading our mounts through streets that smelled of salt and fish and possibility.

~~~

Finding Tidewatch took longer than I'd expected.

Isabella's letter had mentioned the boarding house was "near the harbor, three streets up from Merchant's Row," but Portare had at least five different areas that could qualify as "near the harbor."

"Try asking someone?" Gustin suggested after we'd wandered the third wrong street.

A fishmonger with ink-stained fingers pointed us in the right direction. "Tidewatch? Maria's place? Aye, maritime quarter, that way. Look for the lighthouse on the sign—can't miss it."

We found it twenty minutes later—a three-story building with whitewashed walls and blue shutters, a painted sign showing a stylized lighthouse hanging above the door. Clean. Well-maintained. The kind of place that charged fair rates and didn't ask too many questions.

We tied our mounts to the post outside—Thunderhoof and Gustin's sturdy pony side by side. I pulled Isabella's letter from my pack. The paper was worn from a week of travel, the ink slightly smudged but still legible.

"Ready?" I asked.

Gustin adjusted his pack. "Lead the way."

Inside, the common room was busy with late afternoon activity. A merchant sat in the corner reviewing shipping manifests. Two sailors played cards at a table near the window. An older woman was knitting by the fireplace, occasionally glancing at the harbor view. The smell of cooking fish drifted from what I assumed was the kitchen.

Behind the front desk, a woman checked her ledger while simultaneously directing her assistant with hand gestures toward a table that needed clearing—the same multitasking efficiency my father used when managing three conversations at once. She looked up as we entered, and I recognized the sharp assessment immediately. Merchant stock, like Isabella had said. Perhaps a decade older than my father, with the same practical bearing that came from running a business where every decision mattered.

"Can I help you?"

I stepped forward. "We're looking for Maria Castelli? Isabella sent me—said her aunt runs this boarding house?"

"I'm Maria." She held out her hand for the letter I was clearly holding, the gesture so matter-of-fact it would've been rude to refuse. "Let me see it."

I handed it over. She unfolded it and read, her eyes moving across the words with the same geometric precision my father used reviewing ledgers. Then her expression softened—just slightly, but enough to notice. "Isabella's friend." She looked me over, not unkindly. "She says you're heading to Mali to test for Academia Midur. That you'll need help with lodging and ship passage." Her eyes shifted to Gustin. "Both of you testing?"

"Yes, ma'am," Gustin said. "I'm Gustin Green. From a village near Voskavall. I have my acceptance letter if you need to—"

"No need." She waved a hand, setting Isabella's letter aside. "Any friend of Isabella's is welcome here. She speaks highly of you, Marcus—says you're dedicated and determined. Also mentions your father wanted you in the family business instead of letting you pursue magic." She smiled knowingly. "Family matters—I understand. Sometimes parents have trouble letting their children pursue their own paths."

I nodded, throat tight. "Thank you for understanding."

"Do you have two rooms available?" Gustin asked. "We can pay separately."

"Second floor. Third and fourth doors on the right. Two silver a night per room, three meals included. No guests after sunset, no noise after tenth bell." She gestured toward the stairs. "Stable's around back for your mounts. Tell the hand I sent you."

We found the stable around back. A young stable hand looked up from mucking a stall.

"Maria sent us," I said.

He nodded, wiping his hands. "Fresh arrivals? I'll get 'em settled." He took Thunderhoof's reins, then Gustin's pony, leading them to empty stalls. The stable was clean, well-organized. Thunderhoof seemed relieved to be out of the city chaos, and the pony immediately found the water trough.

"Your horse has a name?" Gustin asked as we headed back inside.

"Thunderhoof. One of our household staff has a young son—Matthew. He named it when he was learning to talk. The name stuck."

"Mine doesn't. The village just calls it 'the pony.'" He smiled ruefully. "It belonged to Old man Corvin before he gave it to me for the journey. Said I'd need it more than he would."

We claimed our rooms—small but clean, each with a bed, desk, washbasin, and window overlooking the harbor. I could hear Gustin moving around in the room next to mine, unpacking, settling in.

I sat on the bed and pulled out my father's satchel. The leather was already showing signs of use—scuffs from a week of travel, the compartments well-organized with coins, letters, and small necessities. I had to force myself to look at the contents.

Seventy-nine gold, four silver remaining. I'd started with eighty after paying the caravan master. The Lorisfort inn and meals had cost six silver.

Ship passage would be expensive. And I had no idea what Regalis prices would be like, or Mali lodging, or how long my coin would really last.

I sat there for a moment, staring at the closed satchel, listening to Gustin moving around in the room next door. We were here. Actually in Portare. Tomorrow we'd need to find a ship, figure out pricing, make decisions that would determine whether we even made it to Mali.

I stood and knocked on Gustin's door. "Want to ask Maria about the docks before we settle in? Get an idea what we're dealing with?"

"Good thinking," he called back. A moment later his door opened. "Better to know tonight than waste tomorrow wandering blind."

~~~

We headed back downstairs and found Maria in the common room overseeing the dinner preparations. The evening crowd was starting to gather—a few early diners, boarders claiming their usual tables. The smell of cooking fish was stronger now, mixing with fresh bread.

"Excuse me," I said. "We need to find ships to Regalis tomorrow. Where should we look?"

She wiped her hands on her apron without looking up from directing her assistant. "Merchant's Row, southern harbor. Look for the Regalis flags—gold tree on green field." She made a note in her ledger, then met my eyes. "Come find me before you book. I can tell you which captains to avoid."

"Thank you," I said.

She studied us both. "Isabella says in her letter that you're determined. That quality will serve you well at the academies." Her expression was genuinely kind. "At the docks, too."

My throat went tight. "I'll do my best."

"I'm sure you will. Both of you." She gestured toward the stairs. "Dinner's in an hour. Get some rest. You both look exhausted from the road. Tomorrow you can tackle the docks with clear heads."

I counted out four silver coins for my room. Gustin paid his own. She tucked the coins into her ledger without comment.

We headed upstairs. Gustin paused at his door. "She seems kind."

"Isabella's family." I shifted my pack. "Merchant stock. They know how to read people and situations."

"Think she suspects you don't have an acceptance letter?"

I'd been trying not to think about that. "Probably. But she's helping anyway. That's what matters." I shifted my pack higher. "Besides, at this point I'm collecting favors from people who think I'm going to fail. It's almost a skill."

He laughed quietly. "At least you're realistic about it."

"I'm realistic about everything except the part where I keep going anyway."

He nodded and closed his door. I heard him settle in for the evening.

I did the same, trying not to think about tomorrow, or the sea voyage ahead, or how much coin I was about to spend on something that might end in rejection anyway.

That evening, the common room was packed for dinner. Maria and a younger woman I assumed was her assistant moved between tables, serving fish stew from a massive pot. The smell was incredible—garlic, herbs, fresh bread on the side.

Gustin and I found seats at a table near the back. The stew tasted better than anything we'd had on the road. Around us, the boarding house buzzed with conversation. Dock workers arguing about tomorrow's loading schedule. A merchant couple discussing prices for Vallis wool. The two sailors from earlier still playing cards, now with coin on the table. A family with three children trying to keep the youngest from spilling his bowl.

"Tomorrow we find a ship," Gustin said quietly. "And deal with the horses."

"Never been on a ship before," I admitted. "No idea what to even ask for."

"Me neither." He looked around the common room. "Should we ask someone?"

I glanced at the sailors playing cards nearby—the older one had weathered hands and a scar across his cheek, the younger one lean and sun-darkened. Both looked like they'd spent years at sea.

"Excuse me," I said. "We need to book passage to Regalis. Any advice on finding a good ship?"

The older one set down his cards, looking us over. "First voyage?"

"Does it show?"

"You both got that landlubber stink." He jerked his head toward the empty chairs. "Sit down. Where you headed, then?"

"Regalis. Academia Midur."

"Navale's the port," the older sailor said. He took a drink. "From there ya catch river barges up to Mali."

"How long does the voyage take?" Gustin asked.

"Two weeks with fair winds," the younger sailor cut in. "Three if weather turns nasty."

"Four if it really hates ya," the older one added. He studied us. "Academy folk? Smart bookin' early. Ships fill fast this time o' year."

"We need space to study," I said. "Spell theory. What would you recommend?"

The younger sailor snorted. "Hammocks, they're stuffed with dock workers who snore like—"

"Then ya want a cabin, not hammock space," the older one talked over him. He gestured with his mug. "Hammocks run five to eight gold a head—cheap, but you're crushed in with thirty other bastards, someone always snorin', stinks to hell."

"And cabins?"

"Shared cabins with two berths run twenty-five to thirty gold per person," the younger sailor said. "Singles are forty-five to sixty per person."

The older one took a drink. "Expensive. But ya get privacy, can study without some drunk pissin' on your books."
