"Most ships only got a few cabins," the younger sailor added. "Sell out quick. If ya can't afford berths, hammocks'll get ya there."

"Which ships would you trust?" Gustin asked.

"Dawnbreaker." Both sailors said it at the same time, then the older one continued. "Captain Ross don't tolerate slack."

"Seafire's decent too," the younger one said. "But Ross is better."

"Skip the Eastern Promise," the older sailor warned. "Cheap means cheap, if ya know what I mean."

"Where do we find them?"

"Merchant's Row come morning." The older sailor picked up his cards. "Captains'll be there loaded down with cargo."

The younger one grinned. "Good luck with the Academy. You'll be needin' it."

"Thank you," I said.

He waved it off and returned to his game.

We finished our meal and headed upstairs. Through my window, I could see ships in the harbor, their masts like a forest against the darkening sky.

Tomorrow. Tomorrow we'd figure out which ship would take us across that impossible expanse of water.

~~~

The next morning, we left our heavier gear in our rooms and headed out. My claymore would draw too many stares—better to travel light with just our coin purses.

We'd asked Maria at breakfast about livestock traders, and she'd directed us to the merchant quarter where traders dealt in everything from donkeys to warhorses. The man we found had a weathered face and calculating eyes—someone who'd made a living off other people's necessities.

He examined Thunderhoof first, walking around him, checking his teeth, running hands down his legs. "Port horse. Good breeding, but too old for racing, not built for hauling. I'll give ya six gold."

"Six?" I stared at him. "He's worth at least fifteen."

"Port's choking with horses. Supply and demand, kid."

"What about taking him on the ship?"

The trader snorted. "Ship transport? You're lookin' at twenty, thirty gold easy. Horse is worth maybe half that. Plus they get sick as hell on the water—most don't make it." He shrugged. "Most folk sell cheap or send 'em home with the caravans. Six gold. That's the offer."

Thunderhoof turned his head and looked at me with dark, patient eyes. The same way he'd stood every morning while Matthew groomed him—the seven-year-old trying so hard to help his father Kyle do everything perfect.

"I'll leave it," I said.

The trader moved to Gustin's pony next, giving it the same assessment. "Four gold. Decent work animal but nothing special."

"Four gold," Gustin repeated slowly. He looked at his pony—the mount Old man Corvin had given him, the horse that had carried him all the way from his village through Conducere to here.

"I'll take it," he said quietly.

The trader counted out four gold coins. Gustin pocketed them, gave the pony one final pat, and stepped back.

I watched the trader lead the pony away. Gustin stood very still, not looking at me.

"The village needs the coin," he said finally. "Can't afford sentiment. That's the difference between us, I think. You have the luxury of choice. I don't."

I didn't know what to say to that. He was right.

We walked back toward the Tidewatch in silence. After a few streets, Gustin spoke again.

"What about yours? Thunderhoof." He glanced at me. "Six gold is six gold."

"I know." Six gold from my father's satchel. Eight to send Thunderhoof home to a boy who'd named him and loved him. The math was insane—Gustin sold his pony because he had no choice. I was spending stolen coin to preserve a connection to a home I'd run from.

"But Matthew..." I trailed off.

"The kid who named him."

"Yeah." I looked at Thunderhoof tied to the post. "I don't have to make this choice. That's the difference."

We walked the rest of the way without speaking. But it was a different kind of silence now—not awkward, just two people trying to figure out impossible decisions.

We found Maria back at the Tidewatch. She was reviewing her ledger, but looked up when we entered. Her eyes flicked toward the window where Thunderhoof was still visible, tied to the post outside.

"Only one horse out there now," she observed. "Sold the other one?"

"Yes," Gustin said quietly. "Four gold."

"And yours?" She looked at me.

"The trader offered six. I couldn't." The words felt inadequate. "But I can't take him on a ship either."

She considered that. "There's a merchant caravan heading back to Mercari in three days. I could arrange for your horse to travel with them. Cost you eight gold for transport, but the horse would get home safe."

Eight gold. More than the sale price. But Thunderhoof would go home to Matthew. To the stable where he belonged. To the boy who'd named him and groomed him and loved him.

I counted out the coins.

Maria tucked them away with a knowing look. "You're spending money you can't afford on sentiment. That's either very stupid or very human." She smiled slightly. "Usually both." She pulled out a ledger. "I'll need the address in Conducere. Where should the caravan deliver him?"

"Logicali household. Merchant district, third warehouse row." I recited the address I'd grown up with. "Kyle is the groundskeeper. He'll know what to do."

She wrote it down with precise script. "And you'll want to send a letter explaining the arrangement. The caravan master will deliver it with the horse."

I borrowed paper and ink from her. The blank page stared back at me. What could I say? That I was sorry? That I'd had to leave?

I started writing three times. Crossed it out twice. Finally settled on something that felt less like lying.

Father,

I'm in Portare. Thunderhoof is coming home with the merchant caravan. Should arrive in two weeks.

Tell Matthew he took good care of him. Tell Catherine and Kyle thank you.

I'll write when I reach Regalis.

- Marcus

I folded it before I could second-guess myself. My hand was shaking slightly. Everything I wanted to say—apologies, explanations, justifications—stayed trapped in my chest where it belonged.

The letter was inadequate. But anything more would be worse.

Maria tucked the note away with the coins. "He'll get home safe."

"Thank you." I paused. "Eight gold to send home a horse I could've sold for six. Pretty sure this is the opposite of sound merchant practice."

Maria's knowing look didn't change. "Or it proves you know what matters."

Gustin and I walked back toward our rooms. He'd gained four gold. I'd lost eight. The difference felt larger than twelve coins—it felt like the difference between someone who had choices and someone who didn't.

"Thank you," Gustin said suddenly.

"For what?"

"For the ship passage." He paused at his door. "For... treating this like it matters."

I didn't know what to say to that. So I just nodded.

"Let's find a ship," I said.

~~~

We grabbed our midday meal from the kitchen and headed back out. My feet already ached from walking on cobblestones all morning, and I was aware of how much we'd crammed into a few hours—finding the trader, watching Gustin sell his pony, making the decision about Thunderhoof, writing the letter.

The sun was past its peak now. We still had to find a ship before the day ended.

"Ready for this?" Gustin asked as we approached the harbor district.

"Not remotely."

The smell hit first—salt and rotting fish mixing with tar from fresh-sealed hulls and wood smoke from food stalls. Then the noise. Portare's southern harbor was chaos.

Ships lined the docks in rows—merchant vessels, fishing boats, naval frigates with Bahia's blue-and-white colors, massive cargo haulers. Sailors shouted in three different languages I couldn't identify. Someone was singing a work song while loading cargo. A crane squealed overhead, swinging a massive cargo net that cast a moving shadow across the dock. The smell was overwhelming—salt and fish and tar and cooking smoke from food stalls wedged between warehouses.

"First time at sea?" A woman leaning against a dock post grinned at us. She wore sailor's clothes and had a knife at her belt that looked well-used.

"That obvious?" I asked.

"You're both starin' at the water like it owed ya money." She pushed off the post. "Lookin' for a ship?"

"To Navale, Regalis," Gustin said.

"Three rows down. Merchant's Row. Fair warnin'—it's two weeks if the weather's kind to ya. Three if it ain't. And it ain't never kind." She laughed at our faces. "You'll live. Most do."

We found Merchant's Row by following the crowd. A dozen ships were loading cargo, captains and first mates shouting prices and departure times.

"So," Gustin said as we approached the docks. "Two cabins if we can get them, double berth if not?"

"That's what the sailor said was best. And he was right about needing privacy for teaching." I looked at the chaos ahead. "Let's split up. You check the northern ships, I'll take the southern rows. Meet back in an hour?"

"Sounds good. Looking for the Dawnbreaker or Seafire, right?"

"Those, or anything that looks clean and well-maintained."

We separated into the chaos.

I checked several ships. The Seafire first—pristine white sails, fresh varnish smell, but sixty gold per person for a single cabin and shared berths already sold out. The Pearl Wind looked worn but functional, sailors efficiently loading cargo, eight gold per head for hammock space. The Eastern Promise sat lower in the water, patched sails and the smell of rotting rope, deck stained with what looked like years of neglect. I kept moving.

The Dawnbreaker caught my attention. Clean lines, well-maintained rigging, professional crew working with practiced efficiency. The smell of fresh tar and the sharp orders from officers suggested a ship run tight and proper.

"Help ya?" The First Mate barely glanced at me, busy checking cargo manifests.

"Looking for passage to Navale, Regalis. Two passengers. Any berths available?"

She consulted her ledger, flipping pages with practiced efficiency. "All berths sold. Shared cabins went this morning, singles yesterday."

My stomach dropped. "Hammocks?"

"Six gold per head. Twelve total for two." She started to turn away, already moving to the next task.

The afternoon was fading when I found Gustin near the southern docks—he'd finished checking the northern row and moved down. He'd had the same luck—everything was either sold out or looked questionable.

"Maria said to check with her before booking," I said. "We should go back."

~~~

We found Maria in the late afternoon, reviewing accounts at her desk. She looked up when we entered.

"Any luck at the docks?" she asked.

"Everything's sold out," Gustin said. "Singles, doubles, everything except hammocks."

"Which ships did you check?"

I listed them—Seafire, Pearl Wind, Dawnbreaker, a few others.

Maria nodded slowly. "The Dawnbreaker. Captain Ross." She set down her pen. "That's a good ship. Professional crew, treats passengers fairly." She paused, considering. "Shared berths run twenty-five to thirty gold per person. Can you manage that?"

I did the math. Fifty to sixty gold total. "That's... most of what I have."

"Then book hammocks," she said practically. "Six to eight gold per person—you can manage that. Uncomfortable, but you'll arrive."

Gustin looked disappointed but nodded.

Maria pulled a small card from her desk drawer and began writing. "Take this too. Sometimes passengers don't show up on departure day. Ships would rather fill empty berths at a discount than sail with them vacant." She handed me the card. "I've hosted the Dawnbreaker's crew before—Captain Ross knows me. If any cabins open up when you board tomorrow, show this to the First Mate. It won't guarantee anything, but it might help."

I looked at the card. Just Maria's name and a brief note in neat script.

"We should still book the hammocks tonight?" I asked.

"Absolutely. Secure your passage first. Then when you show up to board tomorrow, check if anything's opened up. Worst case, you sail in hammocks. Best case, you negotiate an upgrade."

"Thank you," Gustin said.

"Don't thank me yet. Go book those hammocks before they sell out too."

~~~

We made it back to Merchant's Row as the sun started lowering. The Dawnbreaker was still loading cargo, crew working with the same efficient purpose.

The First Mate was overseeing the final cargo loading when we approached. "Help ya?"

"Hammock space for two to Navale, Regalis," I said.

She consulted her ledger, flipping pages with practiced efficiency. "Six gold per head. Twelve total." She held out her hand.

I counted out twelve gold coins.

"Names?"

"Marcus Logicali and Gustin Green."

She marked it down. "Hammock deck, starboard side. We sail dawn tomorrow. Board by first bell or we leave without ya." She waved us off, already turning to the next customer.

We headed back toward the Tidewatch. Gustin looked disappointed but trying to hide it. "At least we're on the ship."

"And we have Maria's card," I said. "If any cabins open up tomorrow when we board..."

"Worth trying," he said. "Though I'm trying not to get my hopes up."

"Same."

We left the docks as the sun started lowering. I pulled out my coin purse as we walked, counting what remained. Seventy gold remaining, maybe a bit less. We'd see what tomorrow brought.

Lodging in Mali. Meals. Supplies. Academy fees if they even let me test. Maybe two months if I was careful. Three if I found work.

And if Academia Midur rejected me? Then what?

"Marcus—" Gustin's voice went tight.

I looked up. Three men had stepped out from an alley ahead of us, spreading across the narrow street. Another two behind. Not dock workers—wrong clothes, wrong posture. The kind of people who waited for tired travelers counting gold in the open like idiots.

"Coin purse," the lead one said. Scar across his jaw, relaxed stance that said he'd done this before. "Hand it over. No one gets hurt."

My hand was still holding the purse. Fifty-nine gold. Everything I had left.

Gustin's breathing had gone shallow beside me. His fingers started tracing patterns in the air—drawing a runic array, probably Barrier. Five, six seconds if he was fast. The thieves would notice any moment.

Ricardo's voice in my head: They've committed. Use it.

I dropped the coin purse.

The lead man's eyes tracked it down. Half a second of distraction.

I moved.

Terra Form—the earth under his lead foot shifted, just enough. He stumbled forward, balance gone. I stepped inside his guard, swept his legs with my own. He went down hard. The man to his right was reaching for a knife. I kicked his knee sideways, heard it pop, pivoted and drove my elbow into the third man's solar plexus. He folded.

The two behind us—one was already running. The other hesitated, saw his three friends on the ground, and bolted.

Total time: maybe three seconds.

I picked up my coin purse. My hands weren't even shaking.

Behind me, a faint shimmer appeared in the air. Gustin's Barrier materialized between us and the fleeing attackers—a translucent wall of force that faded as soon as he realized the fight was over.

"What—" He stared at the three men on the ground. One was groaning, clutching his knee. The leader was trying to get up, failed, stayed down. "What just happened?"

"They left." I pocketed the coins. "We should too. Before they reconsider or find friends."

"But you—" Gustin was still staring. "You moved so fast I didn't even—by the time I finished the array, they were already—"

"Ricardo's training." I started walking. "Come on."

"But—"

"Five years of sword forms I thought were pointless," I said. "Turns out they're very good for hitting people who want my coin. Valuable life skill."

"You're joking right now?"

"Would you prefer I panic? Because I can do that too. Later. When we're not standing next to three angry men."

He followed, glancing back twice. "That was... I've never seen anyone move like that. You used Terra Form, I saw it, but you were already hitting the first one before I even registered you'd cast—"

"Can we talk about this somewhere else?" My heart was starting to catch up to what had just happened. Adrenaline made my legs feel strange.

"Right. Yes. Somewhere else."

We walked faster. Behind us, the three men were still on the ground. No one came after us.

"How did you—" Gustin started.

"Not here. Let's just get back."

We moved quickly through the streets, putting distance between us and the alley. But Gustin couldn't hold back.

"I'm trying to figure out what I actually saw," he said, voice low but urgent. "You dropped the coin purse, they looked down, and then... you were already moving. I saw Terra Form—the earth shifted under his foot. But you'd already started the leg sweep before the spell even manifested."

"Ricardo drilled the movements together for five years."

"But that's not—" He glanced over his shoulder, then back to me. "Marcus, you just cast Terra Form mid-combat while simultaneously executing a sword form. That's not normal. That's not even close to normal."

The sun was sliding toward the horizon. The crowds had thinned, most people heading home for dinner.

"I don't know what to tell you," I said, keeping my voice low. "It's just how Ricardo taught me."

"Did he know? That you were doing something unusual?"

I thought about that. "Maybe. He never said it directly. But he kept pushing me to integrate faster, move smoother. Said magic and movement had to be one thing, not two."

"One thing." Gustin walked in silence for a moment, processing. "Not cast-then-move. Not move-then-cast. One action."

"Yeah." I kept walking. "Turns out five years of resenting sword practice actually prepared me for street robbery. Very practical education."

"You're joking about this."

"Would you prefer I panic now? I'm saving that for when we're safely inside."

We turned onto the street where Tidewatch stood, the painted lighthouse sign visible ahead.

By the time we reached the entrance, I was shaking—not from fear, from the aftermath. The realization of what could have gone wrong hit me all at once.

"You alright?" Gustin asked.

"Fine. Just tired." It wasn't entirely a lie.

"Tomorrow," Gustin said. "Then we're actually doing this."

"Then we're actually doing this," I agreed.

~~~

That evening, Maria brought us dinner herself—fish stew and fresh bread. She set down the bowls, then lingered. "How was your day at the docks? Find what you needed?"

"Booked passage on the Dawnbreaker," I said. "Leaves tomorrow at dawn."

"Good ship. Captain Ross is reliable." She studied us both. "Anything else happen?"

Gustin glanced at me, then back to Maria. "We... had an incident. On the way back."

"What kind of incident?"

"Five men tried to rob us," Gustin said. He was still processing it, I could tell. "Marcus was counting coins in the street—stupid, I know—and they surrounded us. Demanded the coin purse."

Maria's expression went flat. "Where?"

"Three streets from the harbor. Near the warehouses." Gustin leaned forward. "But that's not—the thing is, they were professionals. Positioned us between them, outnumbered us. I started casting Barrier the moment I saw them, but spell arrays take time to construct—five, six seconds even when you're panicking."

"And?" Maria looked at me.

I focused on my stew. "It was fine. They left."

"They left because Marcus put three of them on the ground before I even finished my spell," Gustin said. "I've never seen anyone move like that. He dropped the coin purse—distracted the leader—then it was like... I don't even know how to describe it. He used Terra Form to trip the first one, then just—" He gestured helplessly. "By the time my Barrier materialized, all three were down. One with a dislocated knee. The other two ran."

Maria was watching me now with a different kind of attention. "You've had sword training."

"Five years," I said quietly. "My instructor—Ricardo—trained me in Sahash-Dorh Kata. He integrated Terra Form into the movements. Said magic and combat had to be one thing, not two."

"And your spell—how fast?"

I met her eyes. "Sub-second. Maybe faster if I'm not thinking about it."

Maria was silent for a moment. Then she nodded slowly. "I don't know much about magic, but from what Gustin's describing—five men trying to rob you, and you put three down before he finished casting." She set down her empty tray. "Whatever you're doing, it works."

"It's just Ricardo's training," I said.

"No," Gustin said firmly. "It's not. Chief Aldric stops to cast, then moves. Old man Corvin does the same. Everyone does." He shook his head. "But you just used it in actual combat. Against multiple opponents. That's different from practice."

"Ricardo drilled it that way."

"And it worked." Gustin's voice had an edge of excitement. "It actually worked."

"Against street thieves," I said. "Let's not get ahead of ourselves. Ricardo would remind me those were amateurs who gave me every advantage. One spell and some luck doesn't make me dangerous. It makes me slightly less pathetic than five untrained muggers."

"That's not the point—"

"The point is I barely survived getting robbed and now you two are planning my revolutionary magical career." I took a drink. "Can we maybe celebrate not dying before we worry about academy politics?"

Maria glanced around the common room, then back to us, voice lower. "You should worry about that, though. Tower mages here in Portare—they get set in their ways about how things should be done." Her expression was serious. "If the academy is anything like that, showing them something different won't make you friends."

I hadn't thought about that. I'd been so focused on whether the academy would accept me that I hadn't considered what would happen if I demonstrated something they didn't expect.

"I'm not trying to prove anyone wrong," I said quietly. "I just want to learn."

"I know. But intent doesn't always matter." She straightened up. "I have something for you both." She pulled out a sealed letter from her apron. "My cousin runs a trading house in Navale. Show him this when you arrive. He owes me a favor."

She handed me the letter. I stared at it.

"Thank you," I said.

"Isabella asked me to look out for you." Her expression softened, then she glanced at Gustin. "That goes for both of you. Having connections never hurts. Especially when you're trying something difficult."

After she left, Gustin was quiet for a moment. "People keep helping us."

"I know."

"Why?"

I thought about Isabella giving me coin and letters. Maria arranging passage and contacts. Even Loren Wolf taking reduced rates for the caravan.

"Maybe because they remember what it was like," I said. "Being young and trying something impossible."

"Or maybe they just pity us."

"Maybe. But I'll take pity over nothing."

We finished dinner and headed upstairs. Tomorrow we'd sail. Tomorrow everything would change.

But tonight, I lay in bed listening to the distant sound of waves against the harbor walls and thought about everyone I'd left behind.

Ricardo's voice kept coming back: You're not running from your father. You're running from the person you'll become if you stay.

I pulled out my sword. The blade caught moonlight from the window, clean and perfectly balanced. Ricardo had commissioned the matched pair when I was ten—five years ago now, though it felt like a lifetime.

Either I'd found something the academies missed, or I'd spent five years perfecting a trick that wouldn't matter. Tomorrow I'd start finding out which.

I set the sword down. Through the window, I could see a lamppost on the street below—a crystal atop the post glowing with steady light. Light runes carved into the crystal, drawing ambient Urja to illuminate the street. Common magic, so routine no one even noticed it anymore.

That's what I wanted. Not to be extraordinary—just to be normal enough that magic was a tool, not a dream I'd never reach.

I tried to sleep.

~~~

The Dawnbreaker was ready to sail at dawn.

Gustin and I arrived together, packs on our backs. The deck was chaos—passengers boarding, crew loading last-minute cargo, officers shouting orders. We found the First Mate checking off names from her manifest.

"Logicali and Green," I said. "Hammock passage."

She ran her finger down the list, found our names. "Hammock deck's that way—" She started to point, then I pulled out Maria's card.

"Maria Castelli asked me to show you this. She mentioned checking for cabin openings?"

The First Mate stopped, read the card. Her expression shifted—recognition, then calculation. She checked her manifest again, ran her finger down a different column. "Huh." She tapped a line. "Family of four. Booked the shared cabin weeks ago. Didn't show." She looked at us, then back at the card. "You're Maria's people?"

"Yes, ma'am."

She considered for a moment, glancing at the empty gangway where the family should have been. "Can't let it sail empty—captain loses money. And Maria's vouching for you means I don't have to worry about trouble." She made a note. "Fifteen gold per person. Thirty total. You already paid twelve for hammocks, so that's eighteen more. I can move you to the cabin."

I glanced at Gustin. Eighteen gold more than we'd planned. But privacy for teaching, and we'd still save twenty compared to full price.

He nodded.

I counted out eighteen gold coins. Forty-one gold left—not much for surviving Mali, but enough to start.

She marked the change in her ledger. "Cabin twelve, second deck. Down that way. Stow your gear fast—we sail in twenty minutes."

"Thank you," I said.

She waved us off, already calling the next name.

Gustin exhaled as we headed below deck. "I can't believe that actually worked."

"Maria's card saved us twenty gold," I said. "Still expensive, but we get privacy."

"Thirty gold for teaching space instead of twelve for hammocks." He shook his head. "But if your Ignite attempts go badly, now only one of us will get burned instead of the whole hammock deck."

"That's... probably safer for everyone."

We found Cabin 12—barely larger than a closet, with bunk beds and a narrow shelf. We stowed our gear quickly. Gustin took the top bunk.

The crew worked with practiced efficiency, coiling lines and preparing sails. Within the hour, the ship began to move.

Portare's harbor slowly fell away behind us. The sea spread out in all directions, blue and endless and terrifying in its scale. The wind filled the sails. The ship moved northeast, beginning the long journey around Vallis toward the Deep Sea, then south to Regalis and the ancient forests and the river that would take us to Mali.

Two weeks at sea. Two weeks to learn what Gustin could teach me. Two weeks before I'd find out if running toward Mali was bravery or just another flavor of running away.

I watched the horizon and tried to believe it was the former.

chapters.title: 1.4 The Sea Voyage
chapters.content_text:
Chapter 4 - The Sea Voyage

The Dawnbreaker smelled like salt and tar and wood that had spent too many years soaking in seawater.

Portare shrank behind us, the buildings compressing into a line of color against the hillside. The harbor grew smaller. The sea grew larger. And somewhere in the transition between visible land and water stretching to every horizon, the full weight of what I'd done slammed into my chest like a stone.

I'd stolen from my father. Left my home. Spent forty gold on passage and logistics in just two days—nearly half of everything I had—chasing an academy after being rejected twice.

I gripped the rail. The water beneath the hull was deep. Deeper than I wanted to consider.

The forty-one gold in my satchel felt heavier than the sea below. Most of it stolen from my father. Ten from Lucia. The theft gnawed at my chest—not just the money, but the hiding place. His hiding place. Behind my mother's portrait where he'd thought no one would look.

There had been reasons. Good reasons that made sense in my room at midnight, counting coins by candlelight. But standing on deck with shore gone and water in every direction, I couldn't remember what they were anymore. Just the weight in my satchel and the knowledge that I'd broken something I couldn't repair.

Father would appreciate the irony—his lessons in merchant pragmatism funding my escape from merchant life. Very economical.

~~~

Movement to my left. Gustin appeared at the rail beside me, his face the sickly gray-green of someone about to vomit, sweat beading at his temples.

"Marcus." His voice was strained. "I think I'm—"

He didn't finish. Just lurched forward and vomited over the side.

I grabbed his shoulder to steady him as the ship rolled. "At least you made it to the rail."

"Small victories," he managed, then retched again. His face went paler. "What if the academy sees this? Can't even handle a boat. Some wizard I'll make."

"Seasickness has nothing to do with magical ability."

"Doesn't it?" He gripped the rail, knuckles white. "Everything's a test. Physical endurance, mental discipline. If I can't even—" He broke off to vomit again.

A sailor with a coil of rope paused nearby, barely glancing at us. "First voyage?"

"What gave it away?"

"Yer holdin' him wrong." The sailor moved behind me, repositioning my hands on Gustin's shoulders. "Get behind him—support his weight against the rail so he don't go over when the ship pitches."

I adjusted as he'd shown, bracing Gustin from behind. It worked better. The next wave of nausea hit, but he stayed upright.

"Thanks," I called after the sailor.

"Ya both get used to it," came the reply. "Or ya won't. Either way, a few weeks is plenty of time to find out."

Encouraging. Though Gustin's question stuck—did physical resilience determine magical worth? Another arbitrary threshold, like Mi values?

Though I supposed starting my journey to prove I could be a wizard by holding a sick friend over a ship's rail had a certain poetic quality. Very heroic.

Gustin straightened slowly, wiping his mouth. His cheeks were blotched red—not just from nausea.

"The academy won't care if you were seasick on the way there."

"Won't they?" He wouldn't meet my eyes. "Forty-eight Mi, barely made the cut. Village scraped together every copper. And I can't even keep breakfast down on a calm day."

"Could be worse. You could have done that in the cabin."

"That's not comforting."

"It's accurate." I hesitated, then added, "Besides, I'm at forty-five Mi and not puking. Does that make me the better wizard?"

He actually laughed—weak, but real. "Point taken."

"I hate you," he said, but with less venom.

"I know." The deck tilted beneath us. I kept my grip on his shoulder. "Want to try going below?"

"No. Fresh air helps. I think." He took a shaky breath. "Maybe."

Footsteps approached from behind. A woman's voice, professional and amused. "Cabin twelve holding up?"

I turned. The First Mate had her ledger tucked under one arm.

"So far."

She glanced at Gustin, still leaning heavily on the rail. "Yer friend's discovered why hammock passengers don't complain about the smell. Hard to notice when yer this sick."

"He's adapting."

"Slowly." She made a note in her ledger without looking down. "Meals at sixth, ninth, and fifteenth bell. Water's rationed—one cup per person per day unless we hit rain. Sick over the side, not below deck." She gestured at Gustin. "He's got that part right, at least."

"I'll make sure he remembers."

"Good. Because if ya vomit in my corridors, ya clean them with yer own shirt." She wasn't joking. "Meals come with passage—no extra coin needed. Ya pay for the cabin, ya eat with the crew. Simple."

"Understood."

"Try not to die before we get there."

"We'll do our best."

"See that ya do." She checked something in her ledger. "Captain Ross has been sailin' this route for twenty years. Never lost a ship, never lost crew. Two to three weeks to Navale if weather holds and currents are kind, three or four if they're not. Let's keep that record intact."

She left before I could respond.

"Cheerful," Gustin muttered.

"Efficient," I corrected. "There's a difference."

This was going to be a long few weeks.

~~~

We headed below for the evening meal. The mess hall was cramped. Long tables, benches bolted to the floor, the smell of salted fish that had probably perfumed this space since the ship's first voyage. Gustin sat at the far end, barely touching his stew.

I grabbed a plate and sat across from him. The ship's water ration—one cup per person per day—tasted like the barrel's entire history, every voyage it had crossed stored in that faint metallic flavor. I drank it anyway. At least it was cold. "Food's better than I expected."

"Low bar." He pushed the stew around. "Trying to decide if eating helps or makes the seasickness worse."

A woman in her thirties sat a few seats down, writing in a journal despite the ship's pitch—the kind of focus I'd seen in my father's warehouse managers, the ones who could inventory cargo while standing on a moving dock. A wooden staff leaned against the bench beside her, leather holster straps worn but carefully maintained. The kind of kit you invested in if you planned to keep using it for years. Seasoned.

Three tables over, a team moved with coordinated efficiency my father's warehouse crews never quite managed. I'd watched plenty of crews over the years—this was different. A tall man with a scarred face, an auburn-haired woman with a small fox curled at her feet, and a Dwarf with elaborate beard braids. They passed equipment between them without asking, the kind of wordless teamwork that comes from years of not dying together. Professional efficiency—the kind that jumps out at you across a room because it doesn't waste energy on coordination. No wasted movement. No wasted words.

The fox was small, alert, moving with the same coordinated precision as its handlers. Hunters, probably. The fox was a nice touch. Very competent. Very "we know what we're doing and we know you know we know."

Professional killers with perfect teamwork. At least when they failed, they'd fail together. Very inspiring.

"Three weeks of this," Gustin muttered. "Think we'll survive?"

"Ask me when we reach Navale."

He managed a weak laugh, then pushed his plate away. "Come on. Let's get back to the cabin before my stomach gives up entirely."

~~~

The common room outside was louder—sailors arguing over dice, children running between tables, the constant creak of the hull. I followed Gustin through the noise, grateful when the corridor's relative quiet wrapped around us. The ship rolled as we made our way back to Cabin 12.

We made it inside just as Gustin's face went from green to distinctly pale. He climbed to his bunk and collapsed with a groan.

"You going to survive?" I asked.

"Ask me tomorrow."

I left him to his misery and went back up on deck for fresh air, watching the horizon until the nausea settled. By evening, when I returned to check on him, Gustin had recovered enough to climb down from his bunk, though he still looked faintly nauseous. The space was cramped—stacked bunks with barely enough room to sit up on the lower one, a narrow shelf for our packs—but it was private. I'd propped my claymore against the wall near my bunk. The blade barely fit.

He settled onto the lower bunk beside me and opened his spellbook between us. "Ready to start?" he asked. "Focusing on something other than the waves might help."

I pressed against the wall to make room, our shoulders nearly touching in the confined space. "Teaching me spells I can't cast?"

"Deal was I teach you spell theory during the voyage. We just started the voyage." He smiled weakly. "Besides, it's better than lying in my bunk feeling miserable."

"Right. Can't be seasick if you're thinking about fire magic." I pulled out my journal and pencil. "Teach me how to make fire. I'm paying good money to learn spells I can't use—might as well get the full experience."

~~~

"Okay, so—Ignite is a three-rune structure," he said, sketching the array on a piece of paper. His lines were precise despite the ship's movement. "Simpler than what you're already doing, actually. Terra Form has six runes in the basic array—I mean, you've probably internalized them without realizing it."

He sketched three runes forming a triangle within a circle, connecting lines creating a circuit. His lines stayed precise despite the ship's movement.

"Heat rune first," he said, tapping the top point. "Generates thermal energy until, like, combustion happens—"

"Until combustion," I guessed, studying the symbol. "Makes sense. But wouldn't the heat spread everywhere? Burn your own hand?"

"That's what Direction is for." He tapped the lower left rune of the triangle. "Aims the heat—usually your fingertip, wherever you're pointing. Without it..." He grimaced. "Bad things happen. Corvin showed me the burn scars from experimenting wrong."

"And the third is Stabilization?"

"Yeah. Same one Terra Form uses. It, uh, holds the heat concentration for a second or two so the target material has time to catch. Without it, heat just disperses too fast. Or, I mean, that's what Corvin said."

I copied the array into my journal, trying to match his proportions. A swell lifted the deck, making my lines waver. "So it's like Terra Form's structure—generate effect, direct it, stabilize it."

"Exactly. The key is—okay, so the Heat rune needs to overload. You have to force more Mana through it than it can handle. That's what causes the thermal release. Too little Mana and nothing happens. Too much and..." He grimaced. "Well, you probably burn yourself."

"How do you know how much is right?"

"Practice. Lots of practice." He flipped to another page in his spellbook. "Most mages spend weeks learning to sense the threshold. You channel Mana gradually, feeling for the point where the rune starts to resist. That resistance is the overload point—at least, that's how Corvin explained it."

I studied the array. Three runes. Simpler than I'd expected, but the principle made sense. "Can I try drawing it?"

"On paper, sure. We're not attempting actual casting in a wooden cabin on a ship." He slid his spellbook over. "Copy it a few times. Get the proportions right. The runes need to be balanced or the circuit won't form properly."

I spent the next hour drawing circles and runes while Gustin corrected my line work. An hour of copying fire runes I'd probably never ignite. At least my lines were getting straighter. Very consoling.

The hull pitched with the waves. My stomach protested. But the geometric precision of the runic array cut through the nausea.

"Good," Gustin said finally, examining my fifth attempt. "That's actually correct. The connecting lines are straight, the runes are proportional. If you could channel Mana, this would probably work. I mean, I think it would."

"Probably?"

"I'm not an expert. I can cast Ignite, but I don't fully understand why this specific pattern creates fire. Old man Corvin—my teacher—he just said 'this is the pattern, memorize it.' Never explained the theory behind it." He flipped to a page in his spellbook where neat handwriting sat alongside the etched array. "But he did teach me the optimization chant. Want to see the finger choreography?"

I nodded. Even if I couldn't cast it, understanding the full technique felt important.

He demonstrated slowly, hands moving through precise gestures while he murmured the chant under his breath. Two-handed pattern—academic standard, apparently faster than one-handed variants. His fingers traced invisible lines in the air, each movement corresponding to a note in the rhythm. Heat, Direction, Stabilization—the three runes formed through coordinated motion.

"Corvin made me practice this for weeks before I ever channeled Mana through it," Gustin said. "Get the movements perfect first, then add power. Safer that way."

I copied the gestures awkwardly, trying to match his fluid motion. My hands felt clumsy compared to his practiced ease.

"Not bad for first try," he said. "You'll get it. Just repetition."

I looked at the array. Three simple runes. Centuries of refinement distilled into an elegant solution. "Someone had to figure this out originally. Had to be the first person to discover that this combination produces this effect."

"Right. But how?" Gustin shifted beside me on the bunk. "I mean, did they just try random combinations until something worked? That could take lifetimes."

"They studied nature," I said. My mother had taught me that runes exist naturally—in animals, plants, everything that uses Urja. Wizards observe, extract the patterns, adapt them.

My mother had taught me earth magic years ago, before she died. Now I was learning fire magic, and she wasn't here to see it.

I'd kept practicing anyway—through the empty garden years, through every rejection letter, through two failed academy tests. Apparently that habit didn't break just because I'd left home.

"So somewhere there's a creature that naturally creates fire?"

"Probably. Fire-breathing drakes. Ember serpents. Phoenix if the stories are true." I tapped the Heat rune. "Someone observed how they generate heat, found the underlying pattern, turned it into a spell."

Gustin's eyes lit up with that same intensity I'd seen during the caravan journey. "Wait, that's brilliant! Which means—okay, hear me out—theoretically, any natural effect could become a spell if you understood the runes, right?"

Forty-five Mi. The number that had closed every door—written on test results, stamped on rejection letters, the final word on whether I was worth the academies' time. "If you had high enough Mi to crystallize Mana, yeah."

The words came out sharp-edged. He winced.

"Sorry," I added. "Not your fault."

"No, you're right to be angry." He closed the spellbook. "The whole system is—I mean, you're sitting at forty-five Mi. Technically you can crystallize. But the academies act like you're worthless because you're at the minimum."

"Are you trying to make me feel better or worse?"

"Neither. Just acknowledging it's unfair." He met my eyes. "I'm at forty-eight. Three points higher. That's the only difference between me getting an acceptance letter and you having to chase a maybe. Three points. Like some committee of old wizards decided that forty-four was human, forty-five was nothing, forty-six was still nothing, and forty-eight? That's finally worth their time."

"You didn't steal money to get here."

"No, but my whole village pooled resources to pay for my testing and travel. Old man Corvin used his savings for my ship passage—" He stopped himself. "Well, he tried to. That money's probably going back to him now that you paid for this cabin."

I hadn't thought about that. "Will you send it back?"

"If we make it to Mali and I actually get accepted, yeah. If I fail..." He trailed off. "Then I'll need every copper I have left."

The floor shifted beneath us. We both braced ourselves against the bunk frame.

"Aldric commissioned this spellbook for me." Gustin pulled out the worn leather journal I'd seen before. "Blank parchment—the good kind, beast skin, not cheap paper. Had to buy different grades for different spells. Corvin figured out which ones I'd need." He traced the worn cover. "Every array in here, I etched myself. Every single one. Because that's how you prove you've actually learned the spell, not just copied someone else's work." His finger paused on a particular worn spot. "Cost more than the village could afford, really. But they needed me to have it before I left. So they scraped together the coin anyway."

He opened to a page near the middle—a perfectly etched runic array surrounded by Corvin's original drawings on paper, the master version his teacher had drawn for reference. "This is Ignite. Took me three weeks to get confident enough to etch it on the parchment. Because once you etch, that's it—you waste expensive beast skin if you mess up." He looked up. "All because I hit forty-eight on the Mi scale instead of forty-five. Forty-eight. Like that's the difference between legitimate wizard and fraud."

The observation landed sideways. I stared at the spellbook, the calculation shifting in my head: Forty-one gold in my satchel. Gustin had sold his pony for four.

"At least you had money to take," he said quietly. "You paid for a shared cabin on this ship. When I run out of coin, I don't have a father's warehouses to draw from. I've got nothing except what people scraped together."

The words hit harder than they should have. I'd spent more on this cabin upgrade than his entire horse was worth. The math was simple, even if I didn't want to look at it.

Money. Resources. A safety net, even if I'd cut myself off from it. I'd gambled on myself with better odds than Gustin could afford.

"I'm sorry," I said. "I didn't mean to—"

"I'm not trying to make you feel guilty." He held up a hand. "I'm just saying we're both carrying weight. Mine is what I owe. Yours is what you had and walked away from." His smile was tired. "Different kinds of heavy. Different kinds of stupid, maybe."

"So we both need to succeed," I said after a moment. "You because your village is counting on you. Me because apparently I need to prove I'm not delusional about ignition spells and hand gestures."

"Seems about right." The ship rolled again. "Want to know the worst part? I'm terrified I'll get to Mali and fail anyway. That forty-eight Mi won't be enough either. That they'll test me and find out I'm barely better than anyone else who scraped past Om Point. That all this—" He gestured at the spellbook, his hands, the whole cramped cabin, "—all of this was for nothing."

"If you fail," I said when the world stabilized, "at least you'll fail with an acceptance letter. I'm going in without even that much. Which means if I fail, I fail alone."

"That's either really brave or really stupid."

"Someone already told me that exact thing in Portare. I'm still not sure which it is."

"Probably both."

We sat in silence for a moment, the ship creaking around us, the sea endless beyond the tiny porthole. Two failures in training, one with official credentials and one without. One carrying the weight of his village. One carrying the weight of his father's money.

"Tomorrow," Gustin said finally. "We'll practice the finger choreography for Ignite. Get you ready to attempt the array drawing with Mana instead of just ink."

"Even though I probably can't cast it?"

"Even though. You said you wanted to understand how standard spells work. This is how you learn." He stood, steadying himself against the wall. "Besides, maybe you'll surprise us."

I doubted it. But I appreciated the thought.

The lamp swung overhead as the ship rolled. Outside our porthole, the sea stretched dark and endless.

Weeks of this. Learning spells I couldn't cast, sailing toward an academy that would probably reject me, spending my father's stolen money on desperate hope.

At least the cabin didn't move as much as the hammocks below.

Small victories.

Chapter 5 - The Discovery

By the third day at sea, the ship's roll no longer made my muscles brace. My stomach had stopped heaving. My balance adjusted without conscious thought. Gustin never adjusted. He spent half his time looking vaguely ill and the other half forcing himself to focus on magical theory.

I'd woken before dawn again to practice Kata on deck near the bow. Ricardo had drilled the habit into me—twice daily, morning and evening, no exceptions. Yesterday morning I'd practiced alone, the sailors giving me curious space as I moved through the forms with my sheathed claymore. Today, someone was watching.

The sailors still kept their distance. The sword was heavy, the deck moved unpredictably, and I had to adapt every stance to compensate for the ship's roll. But the discipline helped. Kept my body sharp. Reminded me who I was beneath the desperation and uncertainty.

The ship's navigator worked at the bow most mornings—a Dwarf woman with weathered hands moving through spell patterns over a mounted crystal sphere. Detection magic, the kind that read weather and currents. The crew gave her space without being told, the kind of deference reserved for those whose work keeps a ship alive. She never interrupted my practice, just worked steadily at whatever calculations or observations occupied her. Professional magic I couldn't access, performed casually enough to be routine. Inspiring. I filed the technique away. Might need something like that someday—assuming I ever got past academia gates to learn it.

"Sahash-Dorh Kata."

I turned, finishing the form before lowering my blade. The tall man with the scar—one of the Hunters I'd seen in the mess hall—stood a respectful distance away, arms crossed, the mark catching the dawn light.

"Kael," he said, extending a hand. "Saw you practicing. That's Sahash-Dorh Kata."

"Marcus Logicali." I shook his hand, surprised by the grip—firm but not testing. "Five years under Ricardo."

"Good foundation." He gestured toward two figures at different points on deck—an auburn-haired woman near the mast with a fox at her side, and another Dwarf examining equipment near the hold. "My team. Hunters." He turned back to me. "Keep practicing. Form's solid."

"How did you recognize the Kata?" I asked.

"The way you move. Integration's there. Still young." He nodded toward my claymore. "Fifteen, twenty pounds? Daily practice?" It wasn't a question. "Good for Qi reserves. Body grows into it."

I hadn't thought about it that way. "Ricardo just said to practice twice daily. Never explained why the weight mattered."

"Most students wait. Use lighter blades. Bodies set before they start real weight." He gestured at my stance. "You started young. Qi deepens as you grow." He nodded approvingly. "Stronger than you'll notice. Give it years."

He turned to leave, then paused. "Your instructor—Ricardo—he still teaching?"

"In Conducere, Mercari." I hesitated.

"I'll remember that." Kael's expression was unreadable. "Keep at it. Foundation's there. Give it years."

He walked away. I stood there, the claymore balanced naturally in my grip for the first time in weeks.

Five years of Ricardo beating technique into me, and a stranger with a scar recognized it in three minutes. Either Kael was exceptionally observant or I was more obvious than I'd thought. Probably both.

A professional Hunter who'd probably never set foot in Conducere just validated my training. The training I'd resented. The training I'd left behind to chase academy dreams. Very poetic.

My shoulders ached from the practice, but the good kind of ache—the kind that said muscles were building, not breaking.

After morning practice, I found Gustin emerging from our cabin. His face had that same greenish cast. He moved carefully, like each step tested his balance. He wanted to show me the difference between theory and execution.

"Ready to practice magic?" I asked.

"I mean, if it gets me out of that cabin, yes. Might help with the nausea—focusing on something other than the waves."

Nothing cures seasickness like setting things on fire. But I kept that observation to myself.

~~~

The morning sun had cleared the masts, warming the deck.

The First Mate was checking rigging nearby. Near the mainmast, crew had stacked several burlap sacks of ballast earth—soil and rocks the ship carried for stability. A few sacks were open, earth spilling onto the deck where sailors had been redistributing weight earlier.

She glanced at us, curious, but didn't stop us as we found a clear spot near the open ballast sacks.

A few other passengers stopped to watch—bored enough that two young men doing anything qualified as entertainment.

"I'll demonstrate Ignite first," Gustin said, pulling out his spellbook for reference even though he clearly didn't need it. He produced a small candle from his pocket. "Watch the timing."

He positioned the candle at arm's length, steadying it against the ship's movement. Then he took a breath, closed his eyes, and began.

His right hand moved through the gestures deliberately—index finger tracing upward, middle finger extending to point at the wick, ring finger circling smoothly. His lips moved in the incantation. I couldn't hear the words over the wind and waves, but I could see the concentration. The focus. The methodical execution of every step.

Three seconds. Maybe four.

The array completed and heat exploded from his fingertip—a sudden thermal burst that made the air shimmer. The candle wick ignited instantly, flame springing to life as if struck by lightning rather than gradually kindled.

Gustin opened his eyes, breathing harder than the effort should have required. "That's it. That's as fast as I can cast. I've been practicing Ignite for three years and it's always three to four seconds. Never faster. Barrier takes me five or six—more runes, more complex."

"Show me again. Slower this time."

He did. This time I watched his hands, his stance, the way his whole body committed to the casting. His right hand rose—index finger tracing upward. Middle finger extended, pointing. Ring finger circled smoothly. His lips moved as he cast, murmuring syllables in rhythm with each gesture: "Ta... se... ki."

Three seconds again. The candle wick ignited.

"What were you saying?" I asked. "During the casting."

"Ta-se-ki." He held up his right hand, wiggling his fingers in sequence. "It's a mnemonic—helps me remember the finger choreography. Each syllable tells me which finger to move and how."

I stared at him. "Like... spell words?"

"No spell words. Just a learning tool." He demonstrated again without casting, moving his fingers slowly. "'Ta' for when my index finger draws the Heat rune—vertical stroke, like this. 'Se' when my middle finger points for the Direction rune. 'Ki' when my ring finger circles to complete Stabilization."

"You're singing the finger movements."

"Exactly. Academia Midur taught this version—other schools use different syllables for the same spell. Doesn't matter which, as long as your fingers know what to do." He gestured at my hands. "Try it. Repeat the chant while you practice the finger positions."

So Academia Midur turns spellcasting into nursery rhymes. I kept that thought to myself.

I tried to mirror his movements. Right index up—"Ta." Middle finger point—"Se." Ring finger circle—"Ki."

My fingers tangled. I lost track of which moved when.

"Again," Gustin said. "Slower. Say the syllable as you move the finger. The rhythm helps."

"Ta-se-ki." Index, middle, ring. Vertical stroke, point, circle.

It took a dozen attempts before the pattern started to feel natural, before the syllables anchored the movements in my mind.

"This is how you learned all your spells?" I asked.

"The simple ones, yes. More complex spells..." He hesitated. "There's a whole system of foundation syllables—standard sounds that map to common finger movements. But for Ignite, you don't need all that. Just these three."

"Your turn," he said, stepping back. "I mean, show me your Terra Form. I want to see if—well, if there's something about your version I'm missing."

I glanced at the watching passengers—the same small crowd who'd been bored enough to find two young men doing anything entertaining. Most were just killing time between meals.

I stepped closer to the ballast pile. Earth and small rocks spilled across the deck—real soil, not wood. Terra Form needed ground contact, needed earth to manipulate.

I was about to show off for a crowd of bored passengers. Dignified. Exactly how I'd imagined my journey to Mali going.

The ship rolled beneath me. I waited for the deck to stabilize.

Then I moved.

Not the deliberate gestures Gustin had used. Not the methodical, step-by-step process. Just... moved.

Right foot forward. Weight shifting through the step. The footwork Ricardo had drilled into me for five years—muscle memory carved so deep I couldn't think my way through it anymore.

The earth rippled.

Just a two-to-three-inch rise in the ballast pile, barely visible. Right where my weight had shifted. Right where an opponent's foot would have landed if this had been a sword fight.

Someone in the watching crowd made a sound—surprise, maybe. Or pity. Hard to tell which was worse.

I'd just demonstrated the one trick that made me slightly less useless than my Mi value suggested, and now a dozen strangers had witnessed exactly how pathetic it looked when it only moved two inches of dirt.

Gustin grinned, staring at where the earth had risen. "You didn't even stop moving. It was just... part of the motion."

The woman I'd seen writing in the mess hall—the one with the staff and journal—stepped closer, her casual interest hardening into focus. She crouched near the ballast pile, examining the risen earth. "How long did that take? The casting."

"Less than a second," Gustin said.

She shook her head slowly. "That's not possible. Standard academy casting runs three to five seconds—years of optimization, and practitioners still need three seconds minimum." She looked at me directly. "Terra Form is a six-rune array. Even simplified, it requires distinct hand positions—sequential finger choreography. You did one motion. No finger movements I could see."

"I don't know how it works," I said. "I practiced Terra Form with the same sword forms, the same footwork, over and over until I stopped thinking about it."

"You learned to cast while moving," Gustin said, his eyes wide. "You never stand still. Ricardo wouldn't let you do it any other way."

"Five years of 'cast while you move or you'll die in a real fight,'" I confirmed, the memory sharp and brief.

The First Mate, who'd been working rigging nearby, straightened up with a short laugh. "Finally, a mage who gets it. Most academy types come aboard castin' like they're standin' on solid ground. First storm rolls through, they're flat on their arses wonderin' why their fancy spellwork went sideways." She shot me an approving nod. "Ship deck's always movin'. Good trainin'."

She went back to her rigging work. Something warm settled in my chest—approval from someone who actually kept ships afloat.

The woman stared at the risen earth for another moment. "Can you do it again? I want to try something."

"Go ahead."

She unslung her staff from the leather holster across her back and crouched near the ballast pile where earth had risen. The wood was worn smooth from years of field work, two permanently etched arrays visible along its length. "I'm going to use Detect Magic—the material analysis variant. It should let me sense the Mana flow patterns when you cast." Her fingers found one of the etched sections without looking.

The staff's tip glowed softly as she activated the pre-etched array and channeled Mana through it. I felt a faint tingle in the air—like the spell was reaching out, probing. "When you're ready."

The First Mate had stopped working. She watched, one hand resting on a coiled rope, her face hard to read.

I centered my weight and moved through the form again. A different section of the ballast pile rippled, earth rising two inches before settling back.

She stayed crouched, eyes closed, staff positioned over the affected earth. After a moment she stood slowly, frowning. The glow from her staff faded as she released the spell. "The Mana flow is there—I can sense the effect propagating through the earth. But I can't trace where it originates." She shook her head. "No external array formation at all. Nothing forming in the air around your hands like standard casting. No focus item signatures either—no wand, no etched jewelry, nothing."

She couldn't see it because I wasn't doing what she thought I was doing. Which would be great—mysterious, even impressive—if I actually understood what I was doing. Instead, I was just the idiot who'd stumbled into something he couldn't explain.

She tucked the staff under one arm and made a quick sketch in her journal. "The movement—you're not casting a spell and then moving. You're casting through the movement."

"Wait, that's it!" Gustin's eyes went wide. "The physical motion is part of the array structure itself. That's what makes it work—I mean, that has to be it, right?"

The woman shook her head slowly. "That's not just unusual. That's impossible. Spells require arrays. Always." She stared at her notes. "I don't understand the mechanism. Without knowing HOW you're doing this, I can't assess whether it's specific to Terra Form or could apply to other spells. That would require controlled testing I'm not equipped to do here." She looked up. "But what you're doing contradicts fifteen years of my training."

She paused, studying the ballast earth. "Can you cast the full spell? Standard Terra Form should raise earth two to four feet with proper Mana channeling."

The question hung there. I looked at the two-inch mound I'd raised.

"This is the full spell," I said. "Two, maybe three inches. That's all I can manage."

"I haven't crystallized Mana yet," I added, defensive. "Forty-five Mi means I'm at the Om Point, but..." I trailed off. The excuse felt hollow even as I said it.

"Is that why the output's so small?" Gustin asked, looking at the woman. "Because he hasn't crystallized yet?"

The woman's expression shifted—not quite sympathy, but understanding. "Partly, yes. Without crystallization, you're channeling Urja directly, converting it to Mana in real-time. No reservoir to draw from. Crystallization should provide some storage, yes. Whether that's enough to improve output significantly at 45 Mi..." She paused, considering. "That depends on your natural equilibrium." She tucked her journal away. "But the speed is still revolutionary. The mechanism contradicts everything I know about spell arrays. If you can demonstrate this at an academy, they'll want to study it." She met my eyes. "Whether it's enough to overcome other concerns, I can't say."

Revolutionary casting speed. Two-inch earth rises. Academia Midur would care about the first until they saw the second. Then they'd care about neither. Very impressive. Very "congratulations on optimizing a parlor trick." What good was optimization if I couldn't move enough earth to matter?

But Gustin was nodding, thoughtful. "For combat casting? For quick defensive maneuvers or creating terrain advantages? Instant Terra Form is better than any four-second version. Even if it's only two inches, you can place it exactly when you need it."

"It's a start," he added, gripping my shoulder. "And it's more than most people show up with."

The deck lurched beneath us. Gustin and I both staggered, the moment breaking.

The woman looked at me directly. "How did you learn this?"

"Sword instructor. He made me practice casting while moving."

She made a note. "For combat application?"

"He said magic in a real fight doesn't wait for you to stand still."

"That's..." She paused, considering. "Unconventional. Academies separate combat training from casting entirely." She glanced at her notes, then back at me. "I don't understand what you're doing." She extended a hand. "Yara. Researcher. Hired on for the voyage by Hunters."

"Marcus." I shook her hand. "This is Gustin."

"I gathered." She gestured at her journal. "Fifteen years studying spell mechanics. This doesn't fit any model I know." She paused, tapping her pencil against the page. "But it clearly works. When you get to Mali—if they let you demonstrate this for the academy researchers—do it. It's worth studying."

"If they let me demonstrate," I repeated. The words hung heavy. "That's the problem, isn't it? They have to let me in the door first."

Yara's expression shifted—sympathy, maybe. Or recognition. "Right. The Mi threshold." She hesitated. "I can't promise they'll be reasonable about that."

"Nobody has been yet." At least I was collecting data points. Very thorough of me.

She didn't argue. Just tucked her journal away, shifted the staff back to her hand, and walked off, still frowning at her notes.

Footsteps approached from amidships—measured, deliberate. I turned. A woman in a captain's coat stood a few paces away, arms crossed, gray-streaked hair pulled back in a tight braid. She looked at the ballast earth scattered across the deck, then at me.

"Done playing with my ship's ballast?"

"Yes, ma'am. Sorry."

"Better be." She walked over, examined the displaced ballast earth. "Fix this back to pristine condition, or I'll have ya both thrown overboard. Ballast weight keeps my ship stable—I won't have passengers messin' with it."

I looked at the ballast pile. The two demonstrations had left earth slightly raised and unsettled, disrupting the carefully distributed weight.

"I can fix it."

"See that ya do. Now." She didn't move, just watched.

I went through both affected areas methodically, using Terra Form to smooth the raised sections back down, packing the earth level with the rest of the ballast. The captain inspected each spot with her boot, testing for proper compaction.

"Acceptable." She gave me a hard look. "No more messin' with ship's ballast. Practice yer magic somewhere that won't cost me stability."

"Understood."

She walked off without another word.

The First Mate, still watching from her rigging work, gave a low chuckle. "Don't take it personal, lad. Captain's just protective of her record—twenty years without losin' a ship or crew. Ballast shifts wrong, whole vessel goes belly-up." She coiled her rope with practiced efficiency. "But that trick of yours? Packin' earth back down in seconds? That's useful. Crew takes half an hour with shovels to do what ya just did."

She went back to her work. I found myself standing straighter. Gustin and I stepped aside as crew resumed their tasks, giving them space around the ballast.

I stood there, unsure how to process that. A Hunter who recognized my Kata. A First Mate who saw practical value in two-inch earth manipulation. A researcher baffled by impossible casting speed.

Maybe I'd been measuring the wrong thing. Power mattered to academies. But out here, useful mattered more.

Gustin was grinning at me. "See? Not everyone judges by Mi value."

~~~

The next day and a half passed in the rhythm I was starting to recognize. Morning Kata with the sailors watching. Meals at the bells. Gustin teaching me Ignite theory in our cabin while fighting his seasickness, showing me the finger choreography and mnemonic chant (Ta-se-ki) over and over until my hands knew the pattern and the syllables anchored the movements, even if I'd never channel Mana through it. The ship's endless roll. The navigator at the bow with her crystal sphere, working her detection spells with the same steady focus I'd seen that first morning.

By the fourth evening, my coin balance remained untouched at 41 gold. The ship provided meals with passage—no daily expenses beyond what I'd already burned through. Water ration, meals three times daily, shelter in a cabin the size of a storage closet. Everything accounted for. Everything paid.

That evening, after the sixth bell meal, I stayed on deck while Gustin returned to the cabin. The demonstration kept replaying. Yara's baffled investigation. Kael's recognition of something Ricardo had built into me. The First Mate's practical approval—packing earth with magic being "useful" in ways that had nothing to do with Mi values or academy standards.

None of them understood what I was doing. Hell, I barely understood it myself.

Which brought me back to the only two people who might have: my mother, who'd taught me the spell before she knew I'd be stuck at 45 Mi. And Ricardo, who'd challenged me to cast it while moving without realizing he was asking the impossible.

The fourth night at sea, I couldn't sleep.

Yara's confusion. Kael's recognition. The First Mate looking at me like I'd solved a practical problem. Five years of sword forms drilled into me. A seven-year-old's lesson in the garden before she died.

As if they'd both known I'd need this. As if they were building toward something neither of us understood yet.

Our cabin was cramped, but at least it was private. I sat on my bunk while Gustin snored softly in the upper berth above me, and let myself return to the memory I'd avoided for eight years. The day she taught me Terra Form. The spring sun on dirt. Her hands guiding mine.

I'd stolen from my father to be here. Left my home. And Ricardo and my mother had prepared me for this anyway.

The ship creaked. The lamp swung overhead, casting shadows that moved like wind through leaves. Like the garden in spring. Like the day she taught me.

Suddenly I was seven again, kneeling in dirt under spring sun.

~~~

Spring. The garden behind our house. Dirt under my knees, my mother's hands guiding mine through gestures I didn't understand—slow, patient, warm. Very mystical. Very "this will definitely work out well for the seven-year-old."

"This is Terra Form," she'd said. "Every wizard learns it because it's useful and simple. But simple doesn't mean weak."

The earth had risen under her direction. Just a small mound, but it moved like water, like the soil obeyed her. I'd thought it was like how I obeyed Father in the warehouses—simple, automatic. Turns out magic required more than just following orders. Who knew?

"This will be yours," she'd told me, her hand on my shoulder. "Your connection to the earth. Your magic."

Three months later she was gone. Very considerate timing.

~~~

The lamp steadied. The cabin's smell—salt, tar, close air—snapped me back. I was fifteen again, sitting in a cramped cabin with a journal full of runes I'd drawn ten thousand times.

I remembered the garden after. Empty except for me and the vegetables she'd planted. Kneeling in the same dirt, hands moving through the same gestures, trying to maintain what she'd started. Pathetic, really—a seven-year-old thinking he could cast his mother back to life with perfect tomato rows.

Raising tiny mounds. Helping the plants grow. Keeping something of her alive. Or at least keeping myself busy enough not to think about the alternative.

I'd done that until I was ten. Every day. Every spare moment. Like if I maintained the garden perfectly, maybe she'd come back and see it. Because that's definitely how death works—impress the corpse with your gardening skills.

She never did come back. Funny how a seven-year-old thinks magic works. Keep the garden perfect, follow the rituals exactly, and the universe will notice and give you what you need. Very logical. Very "I haven't learned that life doesn't care about your perfect vegetables yet."

Then Ricardo had shown up.

~~~

"Can you do that while moving?"

I'd looked up from the garden, dirt on my hands, confused. Ricardo stood at the garden gate watching me raise earth over and over. Because apparently that's what passed for entertainment in Conducere—watching a grieving ten-year-old play with dirt.

"What?"

"Cast it while you're moving. While you're doing sword forms."

I'd stared at him. "I've always stood still when I cast."

"Then try it moving."

Very helpful. Very "I'm definitely not going to explain why this matters."

~~~

I hadn't understood why it mattered. Hadn't seen the point of integrating magic into footwork, into combat movement, into forms I'd never use in an actual fight.

Ricardo had never explained. Just drilled it into me. Twice daily. Morning and evening. Five years of frustration because I couldn't see what he was building toward.

I'd never know what inspired him. Maybe he'd just looked at me, saw a kid with too much anger and not enough magic, and thought: why not try something impossible? Or maybe it was simpler than that. Those old tales of warrior-mages—the ones every grandfather read to grandchildren. Heroes who were both Archmage and Sage, back when the stories didn't care about realistic Mi values.

Ricardo was a Qi master, not a wizard. He wouldn't have known academies said it was impossible. He'd have just thought: stories say it works, so why not try?

Very Ricardo. Very "let's see what happens if we ignore what everyone knows is true."

He hadn't been preparing me for combat. He'd been preparing me for the moment when I'd need every advantage I could find. For the moment when standard methods wouldn't work and I'd need something different just to survive.

I opened the journal and sketched my Terra Form array from memory. Six runes instead of three. More complex than Ignite, but I'd internalized it so completely I could draw it in my sleep.

And somewhere in that integration of movement and casting, in the ten thousand repetitions over five years with Ricardo, I'd found something that might actually matter.

If the academies would let me prove it.

The lamp swung as the ship rolled. Gustin shifted in his sleep above me.

Tomorrow we'd practice more. Learn more theory I couldn't use. Sail further toward an academy that would probably reject me.

But tonight, I let myself feel something I'd been avoiding.

Gratitude.

For my mother's last gift. For Ricardo's impossible training. For five years that had felt like punishment but might actually have been preparation.

I closed the journal and lay back on my bunk.

Outside the porthole, the sea stretched dark and endless.

Four days at sea. Two or three weeks still ahead.

Maybe that would be enough time to figure out what came next.
