chapters.title: 1.6 Ignite Attempts
chapters.content_text:
Chapter 6 - Ignite Attempts

By the fifth day, I'd drawn the Ignite array maybe fifty times on paper and could sing Ta-se-ki in my sleep. Mastering spells I couldn't cast was becoming a specialty.

"Ready to try Ignite with actual Mana?" Gustin asked.

We were on deck again. Same spot near the stern. The sea stretched endlessly in all directions, the northern route taking us through cold waters that smelled different than the harbor—clean and vast and slightly terrifying.

Gustin had brought a candle stub—ship-issue tallow—and set it on the deck rail between us.

"I've practiced the finger choreography," I said. "I understand the theory."

"But?"

"But I don't know if it's enough to cast it," I said.

Gustin nodded. "Only one way to find out."

He walked me through the positions again. Index finger for the Heat rune. Middle finger for Direction. Ring finger for Stabilization. The pattern formed a circuit—you had to trace it in sequence, each finger drawing its rune in the air while channeling Mana through the paths.

"Start slow," Gustin advised. "Focus on forming the array correctly. Don't worry about speed yet."

I took a breath and began. Focused on the candle.

Index finger—trace the Heat rune. Vertical upward stroke, like ascending flame. Something in the movement resisted—faint, like drawing through water.

Middle finger—Direction rune. Point toward the target, guiding the heat. This one felt clearer. I'd used Direction in Terra Form for years.

Ring finger—Stabilization. Circle to bind the array, the same gesture from my Terra Form. This one I could draw without thinking.

Six seconds. The array formed in the air in front of me—a faint shimmer, barely there unless I held perfectly still.

I pushed Mana into it. The circuit completed. The Heat rune pulled—hungry, demanding—

Nothing happened.

No flame. No heat. Not even a warm feeling in my fingertips.

"Again," Gustin said. "But this time, try to force more Mana into the Heat rune. Overload it."

I tried again, focusing on the candle wick. Five, maybe six seconds—slightly faster as the movements became more familiar.

Array formed. Mana channeled. I pushed harder into the Heat rune, trying to force the overload Gustin had described.

Still nothing.

"Are you feeling any resistance?" Gustin asked. "Like the rune is pushing back against your Mana?"

"Like pouring water into a bucket with no bottom."

He frowned. "Try one more time. Full power. Everything you've got."

Third attempt. I stared at the candle, focused everything I had. Five seconds to form the array—smoother now, but still twice as slow as Gustin's practiced precision. I drew every bit of Mana I could manage and shoved it into the Heat rune.

The array shimmered in the air. Perfect structure. Perfect form.

The rune pulled. Hungry. Demanding more than I had to give.

I pushed everything I could into it—every scrap of Mana I could access, forced through the circuit as hard as I could manage. The Heat rune kept pulling, straining, trying to reach some threshold I couldn't provide.

The array shuddered. The Heat rune flickered, sputtered—for a split second it almost cascaded into something, almost triggered—

Then everything fragmented. The structure collapsed. Mana scattered into nothing.

No flame. No heat. The candle wick remained dark and cold. Just failure.

Three attempts. Perfect array formation every time. Zero thermal output. I was achieving consistency in my incompetence. Very impressive.

I let my hands drop. "Nothing."

Gustin studied the empty air where the array had been. "The structure was perfect. I could see it form—all three runes manifested cleanly. But the Heat rune never reached overload."

"What does that mean?"

"Hold on." He disappeared below deck, returned a minute later with a worn journal—the kind with pages that had been referenced too many times. "These are my notes from old mage Corvin back in Planus. Never needed to look at the technical specs before, but..."

He flipped through pages, found what he was looking for.

"Watch."

He formed his Ignite array. Three seconds, practiced precision. Channeled Mana through the circuit—

The candle wick burst into flame.

I watched it burn. So simple for him. Just another spell, barely worth thinking about.

"That's what it should do," Gustin said, releasing the array. "Thermal overload at the target point. Enough heat to cause ignition."

Gustin had conjured a flame in three seconds. I'd spent ten minutes forming perfect arrays that did nothing. The distance between what he could do and what I couldn't felt wider than the entire northern sea.

"So why can't I do it?"

He consulted his notes. "Ignite needs two things. Four hundred M of stored Mana to feed the Heat rune." He traced down the page. "And forty Mi of channeling capacity to push it through hard enough to create the overload."

"I tested at forty-five Mi."

"That's your Mi value—blood Urja density." He tapped his chest. "But channeling capacity is different. How much you can actually push through a spell array at once."

I thought about that desperate straining. The way the Heat rune had pulled and pulled but I couldn't force enough through. "They're not the same thing."

"No. Institutes measure Mi value—tells them if you can crystallize Mana in your heart. But it doesn't measure how hard you can channel during actual casting." He looked at his notes again. "When you tried, how did it feel?"

"Like trying to move cargo through a door that's just slightly too narrow. No matter how hard I push, the door won't budge."

He nodded. "The Heat rune needs forty Mi channeling intensity to trigger overload. Below that threshold..." He gestured at my failed attempt. "Nothing."

"And I probably don't have four hundred M stored anyway."

"You don't have any stored." He said it matter-of-factly. "You haven't crystallized Mana yet. Right at forty-five Mi..." He consulted his notes. "Corvin wrote that people at the Om Point can convert Urja to Mana when they cast, but it doesn't crystallize. No storage. You're making Mana in real-time and using it immediately."

"So I'll never have enough for Ignite."

"Not until you crystallize, no. And that..." He trailed off, uncomfortable.

And that required being above the Om Point. Or somehow getting my Mi value to rise, which I had no idea how to do. Or waiting and hoping for natural crystallization that might never happen at exactly forty-five Mi.

Two failures. No storage. Can't push hard enough.

Perfect array structure. Zero output.

I stared at my hands. Five seconds to form a perfect Ignite array—faster than most beginners could manage after just days of practice. Technical progress that should matter. And zero output because I couldn't meet the threshold requirements.

My father would be proud of my business sense—paying for ship passage to learn spells I couldn't actually use.

The academies had judged me insufficient. Was this proof they were right? Perfect structure meant nothing without the capacity to execute. But then why test array formation at all? Why not just measure Mi values and send everyone home? Maybe they didn't know either. Maybe they were just as confused by edge cases like me. Technically qualified. Completely ineffective.

"Teach me anyway," I said after a moment.

"What?"

"You said you'd teach me Ignite and Barrier theory. I can't cast Ignite, but I want to know it. Want to understand how it works." I met his eyes. "Maybe someday I'll figure out how to make it work for someone like me. Or at least I'll be able to explain what I'm missing with impressive technical accuracy."

Gustin studied me for a long moment. Then nodded. "Alright. Let's keep going. You've learned the array and the basic mechanics. Now let me teach you the variations—I mean, what I know of them."

And he did. For the next hour, he walked me through everything he knew about Ignite. How to adjust the Direction rune to spread heat across an area instead of focusing it at a point. How some mages modified the Stabilization rune to maintain heat for longer—at the cost of higher Mana consumption, Corvin said. How the chant, while not strictly necessary, helped coordinate the finger movements and build muscle memory for consistent array formation.

I took notes in my journal. Filled three pages with annotations and diagrams and theoretical variations I'd probably never cast.

But I learned it. Understood it. Could explain it to someone else if I needed to.

This story is posted elsewhere by the author. Help them out by reading the authentic version.

And if nothing else, at least I'd know what I was missing.

Eighteen gold for a cabin to learn spells I couldn't cast. Forty gold, nine silver, ten copper remaining. Every expense I hadn't anticipated cutting into funds I'd need for Mali.

Father would call it throwing money at pride. He'd probably be right.

~~~

We returned to the cabin as the sixth bell rang. Gustin collapsed on his bunk, exhausted from fighting seasickness and teaching simultaneously. I spent the evening reviewing my notes, filling pages with arrays I might never cast.

The sixth day passed in similar rhythm—morning practice on deck, failed Ignite attempts, Gustin's patient instruction filling the gaps where my capacity fell short. The weather stayed cold as we crossed Frost Bay and crested around Vallis's northern coast. The ship turned south, hugging the shoreline as we left the coldest waters behind. Still cold—this was northern Vallis—but the navigator said we'd see warmer weather within a week.

All stone and timber buildings hunched against the perpetual wind. No trees. No color. Just functional architecture designed to survive, not to inspire.

"Cheerful place," Gustin muttered as we descended the gangplank. His breath fogged in the cold air.

"I think it's designed to make sailors appreciate being at sea."

"It's working."

The port was small—maybe six buildings total clustered around a sheltered harbor that barely qualified as protection from the northern winds. A tavern. A supply house. A harbormaster's shack. And three buildings whose purposes I couldn't immediately identify but assumed involved fish, salt, or both.

"Six hours, ya got," the First Mate had announced. "Resupply stop. Be back 'fore the evenin' bell or we sail without ya."

Six hours in Saltcrest. The highlight of our voyage so far.

Gustin and I found the tavern—optimistically named "The Warm Harbor"—and discovered it was neither particularly warm nor reminiscent of any harbor I'd want to visit.

But it had spiced cider.

"Two copper," the proprietor said, eyeing us with the universal skepticism tavern owners reserve for young travelers. "Each."

I handed over four copper coins. Not much, but every coin mattered now. Forty gold, nine silver, six copper remaining—dwindling faster than I'd planned.

The cider arrived in wooden mugs that looked older than the building. It was hot, heavily spiced with what I suspected was mostly cinnamon and hope, and tasted like someone had dissolved a candle in apple juice.

"This is terrible," Gustin said after his first sip.

"I know."

"Why are we still drinking it?"

"Because it's hot and we've been cold for three days."

"Fair point."

We sat in silence for a moment, letting the warmth seep into our hands. The tavern was mostly empty—a few weathered sailors at one table, a merchant who looked like he'd made poor life choices, and a woman in the corner who might have been asleep or dead. Hard to tell.

"You know what I miss?" Gustin said suddenly. "Real food. Not ship rations. Not whatever this is." He gestured at his cider. "Just... normal food that doesn't taste like it's been preserved in salt for six months."

"Catherine's meat pies," I said without thinking. "She makes them with this gravy that's—" I stopped. My chest tightened. Talking about home risked making it real.

"Sounds good."

"It was."

Another silence. The kind that's comfortable because you're both too cold and tired to fill it with meaningless words.

"Want to test your Terra Form on unfamiliar terrain?" Gustin asked eventually. "Scientific curiosity."

"You mean you want to see if it works on ice and frozen rock."

"That's what I said. Scientific curiosity."

We finished our terrible cider and went outside.

The cold hit immediately—sharp northern wind that cut through my cloak like it wasn't there. We found a relatively sheltered spot behind the supply house, out of sight of casual observers.

"Alright," Gustin said, wrapping his arms around himself. "Show me."

I looked at the ground. Rocky earth, patches of ice, nothing that looked particularly cooperative.

Settled my feet, testing the unstable ground beneath. The movement flowed through me—Ricardo's training automatic even on ice. My weight shifted, and the array followed.

The rock rippled. Barely an inch and a half—less than usual on the harder substrate. But it moved.

"Works on ice-covered northern rock," Gustin confirmed, shivering. "Very scientific. Can we get back to the ship now before we freeze?"

We headed back to the ship as the evening bell rang. Once aboard, I ran through Wind-Cutting Form twice, shaking off Saltcrest's gray mood. The discipline helped. Ricardo had always said practice steadied the mind when results disappointed.

The deck was crowded with passengers taking evening air. I'd found a clear space near the stern, away from the merchant groups clustered amidships. The northern wind had softened as we turned south, but I needed movement more than warmth.

Then something small and furry darted between my feet.

I stumbled mid-strike, barely catching my balance. The claymore's sheathed tip hit the deck with a thunk. Very graceful. Ricardo would be so proud.

The creature stopped a few feet away. A fox sat there, looking entirely too pleased with itself. Russet-red fur with ember-orange highlights, bright amber eyes, tail swishing like it had just won a game I hadn't known we were playing.

"What—" I started.

The fox pounced forward, grabbed the leather cord wrapped around my claymore's sheath in its teeth, and pulled.

"Hey!" I tugged back gently, trying not to actually hurt the thing. "That's not a toy."

The fox made a sound somewhere between a yip and a laugh—if foxes could laugh—and yanked harder. Its tail was wagging with the kind of shameless enthusiasm I'd stopped allowing myself years ago. Apparently foxes didn't need high Mi values to enjoy life.

"Ash!" A woman's voice called from across the deck. "Ash, get back here!"

The auburn-haired Hunter from Kael's team appeared, jogging over with an expression caught between exasperation and amusement. She reached us, slightly out of breath, and scooped up the fox, who released my sword cord with obvious reluctance.

"I am so sorry," she said, tucking the squirming fox under one arm. "She's been cooped up in our cabin for days and apparently decided you looked like entertainment."

"It's fine." My mouth twitched upward despite my best efforts to maintain grim determination. The fox was staring at me with those bright eyes, tongue lolling out like this was the best game ever. "She's got good instincts. I was getting too serious about the form anyway."

"That's generous of you." The woman shifted the fox to a more secure hold. Ash immediately tried to climb onto her shoulder. "I'm Senna. Beast specialist with Kael's team. This troublemaker is Ash."

"Marcus." I used the strap to shift the claymore to my back, out of fox reach. "She's your partner?"

"For three years now. Red fox, fire-affinity. She's better at tracking than most Hunters twice her size." Senna scratched behind Ash's ears. The fox leaned into it, making a soft cooing sound. "Also better at causing mischief, apparently. She's usually more professional than this."

Ash yipped and tried to jump toward me again. Senna held her back with practiced ease.

"Fire-affinity?" I hadn't heard the term before.

"Some develop elemental attunements. Ash can generate small flames, track heat signatures, resist cold better than normal foxes." She smiled at my interest. "Not all Beasts are dangerous. Some are just... different. Magical."

Gustin had emerged from below deck during the conversation, leaning against the rail a few paces away. His shoulders were rigid at first—the usual wariness around Beasts—but he leaned forward when Ash yipped.

"How does a Beast develop magic?" The question came before I could stop myself. "I thought only beings above Om Point could crystallize Mana."

"Different biology entirely. Beasts don't work like we do—they're born with cores, or develop them naturally as they grow. Different species, different rules." She tilted her head. "You ask good questions. Most people just want to know if Ash bites."

"Does she?"

"Only people who deserve it."

I laughed. The sound felt foreign after days of grim practice and perfect failures. "What kind of Beasts does your team hunt?"

"We don't hunt—we retrieve. Specific specimens for research institutions, usually alive." Senna scratched behind Ash's ears. "Though most of our contracts aren't as dramatic as Ash makes them sound."

Ash yipped indignantly.

"Senna." Yara's voice came from behind me. I turned to see the researcher approaching, staff in hand. She nodded to me, then Gustin. "Evening feeding time. The specimen's getting restless."

"Already?" Senna shifted Ash to her shoulder. "Alright, I'm coming."

"Wait—you have a specimen aboard?" Gustin asked, glancing between them. "What kind?"

Senna glanced at Yara, something amused in her expression. "Frost Marten from the Snow Isles. Rare ice-affinity. We've been caring for it for three months."

A rare ice-affinity Beast. I couldn't help myself. "Could we see it?"

Yara studied us for a moment, then looked at Senna. Senna shrugged. "They asked good questions earlier. And Marcus isn't easily spooked."

"You're not squeamish?" Yara asked.

"I've gutted fish," I said.

"Not quite the same." Yara's expression softened slightly. "But close enough. Come on. Just don't touch anything, and if it gets stressed, you leave immediately."

She led the way to a hatchway amidships. Senna followed with Ash, and Gustin trailed after us, curiosity overcoming his usual caution around Beasts. We descended the narrow ladder into the cargo hold's dimness, the smell of tar and stored goods replacing the salt air.

Crates secured with heavy netting filled most of the hold—standard warehouse practice, the kind my father's crews used for fragile goods. The hanging lamps swayed with the ship's movement, casting shifting shadows. Transporting live specimens apparently required the same logistics as expensive glassware. Very comforting.

In the far corner sat the cage—maybe four feet on each side, reinforced iron with intricate engravings. Cold-dampening runes—similar to the preservation arrays in Father's warehouse, but more sophisticated. My father's cargo security looked amateur by comparison. Very reassuring that keeping this creature calm required more magical engineering than my father's entire warehouse security. Inside, a silver-white creature lay curled on what looked like a bed of frost.

"That's Silver," Senna said quietly, her whole demeanor shifting to something gentler. "Official designation: Frost Marten, specimen one."

Ash immediately hopped down from Senna's shoulder and padded around the cage with exaggerated confidence—chest puffed, steps high and deliberate. Small sparks flickered along her tail as she circled, like she was putting on a show. She sat down primly at the front, her tail tip glowing faintly orange, and looked back at us as if to say See? I found this one.

The Frost Marten cracked one eye open, looked at Ash with profound disinterest, and closed it again.

Ash huffed—an actual huffy sound—and strutted back toward Senna with wounded dignity.

I laughed despite everything. Apparently it took an indignant fox to remind me how.

"She tracked him for three weeks through northern forests," Senna explained, scooping up her indignant partner. "Fire-affinity foxes detect temperature—she followed where the heat wasn't. Every feeding, same routine. He ignores her every time."

The Beast was beautiful. Sleek mustelid body, maybe the size of a large cat, with fur that shimmered in the lamplight. Frost patterns traced along its spine—crystalline blue-white markings that caught the light.

An ice weasel in a reinforced cage. Very relevant to my inability to light candles. My education was progressing exactly as planned.

Yara moved to a bucket of seawater near the cage, setting her staff within arm's reach as she knelt. Her fingers began moving through precise gestures—tracing a runic array in the air above the water. I recognized Direction and Concentration from Gustin's teaching. The array formed in maybe three seconds, then Yara channeled Mana through it, maintaining the flow. Ice crystals spread outward from beneath her palm. "Keeps him calm during transport. Weeks at sea would stress any Beast from frozen environments."

Weeks of ice generation for the entire voyage. My eighteen gold for cabin passage suddenly seemed reasonable—at least I wasn't responsible for keeping an ice weasel comfortable in northern summer.

She lifted the ice block—maybe twenty pounds—and slid it through a gap in the cage bars. It landed near the Frost Marten with a soft thump. The Beast stirred slightly, shifted closer to the cold, then settled again.

"He's very calm," I said, watching the creature's slow, lethargic movements. "Considering he's in a cage."

Yara stood, dusting off her hands. "Alchemical sedative. Dosage adjusted for body weight—too much damages the specimen, too little and it's stressed." She nodded toward Senna. "She monitors him closely. Morning and evening feeding with sedative mixed in the food."

Senna pulled frozen fish from a pouch, slid it through the cage bars. The Frost Marten stirred, took it with careful movements, ate slowly.

The precision reminded me of my father's warehouse managers—same meticulous tracking, same schedule discipline. Different cargo, same logistics. Though I doubted my father's fish shipments required weeks of twice-daily ice generation.

I crouched near the cage, examining the frost patterns along the Frost Marten's spine. They were beautiful—natural crystalline structures that seemed almost deliberately artistic. "Those markings. Do they mean something?"

"That's what we're trying to figure out." Yara pulled out her journal, flipped to a sketch of the patterns. "They appeared naturally—not injury scars or artificial marks. I suspect they indicate core location. Some Beasts crystallize along their spines instead of internally. If this specimen is one of them..." She trailed off, clearly excited. "It would validate alternate core structure theories."

"Beasts can have cores in different locations?" Gustin asked.

"Different species, different biology." Yara gestured at the Frost Marten. "Sentient races crystallize in hearts because that's where our Urja circulation converges. But Beasts—their biology is completely different. Cores can form in hearts, heads, along spines, even in limbs for some species."

Different biology, different rules. Very flexible. Apparently the universe reserved all its structural creativity for Beasts and left sentient races with 'heart or nothing.'

I stared at the frost patterns. At the way they traced the spine in deliberate lines.

Cores didn't have to be in hearts. Different biology allowed different structures.

I filed that thought away, not sure what to do with it yet.

"Thanks for showing us," I said to Senna.

"You're welcome. Just... don't mention it to other passengers. Most people get nervous about Beasts on ships." She smiled. "Even sedated ones."

We climbed back up to the deck, leaving the Frost Marten to its cold, sedated rest.

Somewhere in that hold, a Beast was crystallizing Mana along its spine instead of its heart. Different biology. Different location. Same function.

I didn't have answers yet. But I had observations.

And maybe that was enough to start with.

chapters.title: 1.7 Warmer Waters
chapters.content_text:
"So, about Barrier," Gustin said on the eighth day. We were back in our cabin, papers spread on the lower bunk between us. The ship had found warmer waters, making the cramped space almost comfortable.

I looked up from my journal. Two days of practicing Ignite variations I couldn't actually cast. My enthusiasm for theoretical knowledge was wearing thin.

"It should work for you," he continued. "Unlike Ignite."

"Because I have so much success with spells."

"No, I mean—Barrier's different. Ignite is an overload spell. It needs to hit that threshold or it doesn't trigger at all. All-or-nothing." He pulled out his notes. "But Barrier is a channeled spell. Like your Terra Form."

I waited.

"With Terra Form, you're feeding Mana into the array continuously, right? Maintaining the effect as long as you channel. There's no threshold to hit, no overload to trigger." He gestured at the space between us. "Barrier works the same way. You channel Mana through the array to maintain the shield. Even a little Mana should produce something."

"Something small."

"Yeah. Like your Terra Form—smaller effect, but functional." He shrugged. "Two-inch earth rises. Maybe a smaller shield. Not impressive, but better than nothing."

Better than nothing. My new standard for success.

"Alright," I said. "Teach me."

"It's going to be more complex," he warned. "Fifteen to eighteen runes depending on which academy variant you learn."

I stared at him. "That's three times Terra Form's size."

"Yeah. It's why most academies don't teach it first year."

"Perfect. I can barely cast the simple spell. Let's learn the complicated one." I pulled paper toward me. "What could go wrong?"

He pulled out his spellbook, flipping to a page dense with runic diagrams. "But everyone learns it eventually. And if you're going to understand how complex spell construction works, Barrier is, like, a perfect example. It has everything—force generation, shape definition, duration management, feedback loops."

"I thought you said you didn't understand the theory behind your spells."

"I don't understand why specific runes create specific effects. But I can teach you the structure, how the runes connect, what each section does functionally. I mean, that's what Corvin taught me." He tapped the diagram. "Chief Aldric brought Academia Midur's methods back to Arvum. Taught Corvin the finer points, Corvin taught me. I'm teaching you. It's the same pattern they've been using for a thousand years."

I pulled the paper closer, studying the array. It was beautiful in its complexity—four distinct sections arranged in a geometric pattern, each section containing multiple runes that fed into the next.

"How do you even memorize this?"

"Section by section. Nobody learns the whole thing at once." He grabbed a blank sheet and started sketching. "Section One is, uh, Force generation. This is where you create the actual barrier energy—the thing that stops physical objects."

He drew three runes: Force, Amplification, Anchor.

"Okay, so—Force creates the base energy," he explained. "But Corvin said Force alone is weak. Barely stops a thrown stone. So you add Amplification, which, uh, multiplies the Force output. Then Anchor—that defines where the barrier exists. Usually attached to your left arm, so it moves with you naturally."

I copied the three runes into my journal. At this rate I'd master the theory of every spell by age thirty. Actually casting them remained optional. "So this section creates amplified Force energy at a specific location."

"Right. But Force without structure is just, like, energy floating in space. It'll dissipate in seconds. I mean, that's what Section Two fixes—Shape definition."

He drew the next section: Concentration, Duration, Stabilization, Boundary.

"Concentration focuses the Force into one area instead of spreading it everywhere—defines the barrier's size and edges. Duration determines how long the Force maintains cohesion. Stabilization you already know from Terra Form—locks everything in place. And Boundary..." He tapped the fourth rune. "That's a marker that tells the array where the barrier's edges are. Works with Concentration to define the exact dimensions."

"That's seven runes already. What's next?"

"Section Three—Pressure Maintenance." He drew three more runes: Channeling, Feedback, Terminus. "This is where it gets interesting. Channeling creates the pathway for continuous Mana flow—how you feed power into the barrier. Terminus is the failsafe, lets you release the spell cleanly when you're done. And Feedback..." He paused, tapping the rune. "Feedback is what makes it a barrier instead of just a floating Force plane. It tells the array to resist physical impact. The harder something pushes against the barrier, the more the Force pushes back. I mean, that's how Corvin explained it."

"That's..." I stared at the runes. "That's actually genius. It's self-regulating."

"To a point. The Feedback rune helps the barrier resist impact efficiently—pushes back proportional to what hits it. But your initial Mana determines the size, and how much you channel determines strength." He tapped the Anchor rune from Section One. "And this matters more than people think. Anchor it to your arm, you get mobility—barrier moves with you. But the force still transfers. A charging bull might not break the barrier, but it'll shatter your arm behind it."

"So for heavy impacts..."

"Anchor to ground. Or a wall. Something that can absorb the force instead of your bones." He shrugged. "I learned to always check my footing before casting. Corvin made me practice both ways until it was instinct."

"What's Section Four?"

"Resistance Properties." He drew three runes: Enhancement, Resonance, Isolation. "Enhancement makes the barrier more efficient—more resistance per Mana spent. Resonance harmonizes the array with your personal Mana signature, so it feels natural to maintain. And Isolation prevents external Mana from interfering with the structure."

He added two final runes. "And these connect everything—Storage holds reserve Mana for the array, Release controls how it all dissipates when you're done. Without them, the barrier either drains you dry or collapses messily. At least, that's what Corvin's notes said."

I looked at all fifteen runes spread across my paper. Gorgeous. Complex. Completely theoretical for someone who couldn't push enough Mana through a three-rune array. "This is insane. How do you keep track of all of them while casting?"

"Practice. Lots and lots of practice." He pulled out another sheet. "Okay, so here's the trick—you don't think about individual runes once you've learned them. They become one complete pattern. Like..." He gestured vaguely. "Like your sword forms, probably. You don't consciously move each piece—you just do the form and your body remembers the sequence."

That made sense. Ricardo had drilled forms into me until they were automatic. Until I could execute complex attack patterns while exhausted, injured, distracted.

"How long did it take you to learn Barrier?"

"Three months. And I still cast it slowly—takes me about seven seconds on a good day." He smiled ruefully, but I caught something else in his expression—uncertainty. "Old man Corvin said that's normal for someone at forty-eight Mi. The more Mana you have, the easier it is to maintain the whole array while channeling. I mean, that's the theory anyway."

He hesitated, then: "To be honest, I'm not even sure I should be teaching you this. What if I'm explaining it wrong? Corvin taught me, but he admitted he didn't fully understand the advanced theory either. And now I'm passing that incomplete knowledge to you, acting like I know what I'm doing when..." He trailed off. "When I'm barely competent myself."

Gustin was teaching me to build shields I'd never raise. And he worried about being qualified. We were a matched set of inadequacy.

"You can cast it. That's more than I can do."

"Barely. Seven seconds is slow. Academy students probably do it in four or five. I'm teaching you something I haven't even mastered." He looked down at the spellbook. "Sometimes I wonder if I'm qualified to teach anyone anything."

"So at forty-five Mi..."

"You'll probably find it harder, yeah. But the point isn't to cast it perfectly right now. The point is to understand the structure." He tapped the paper. "Start memorizing Section One. Three runes. Get the shapes right, the proportions, how they connect. Tomorrow I'll teach you the finger choreography for actually drawing them."

I spent that evening—after my Kata practice on deck—and the next morning drawing Force, Amplification, Anchor over and over. The runes became familiar. Not automatic like Terra Form, but recognizable. Shapes I could reproduce without reference.

Over the next two days, Gustin quizzed me at meals, made me draw each rune from memory, checking my proportions against his spellbook.

"Good," he said finally on the morning of the tenth day. "That's Section One down. Three more to go."

"This is going to take the entire voyage, isn't it?"

"Probably. But hey—by the time we dock at Navale, you'll know two academy-standard spells. Even if you can't cast one of them and can barely cast the other, you'll understand the theory." He grinned. "That's first-year curriculum condensed into a few weeks at sea. Not bad."

Not bad. If I ignored the part where I'd probably never actually use any of it.

~~~

Early morning on the ninth day, I finished my Kata practice on deck.

The navigator stood at the bow with her weathered hands on a crystal sphere mounted to the railing, eyes closed, muttering something too quiet to hear. Her Dwarf features showed maybe two centuries of experience—all of it etched into the lines around her eyes.

"Sensing currents," the First Mate explained when I asked. "Water flows, wind patterns, upcoming weather. Good navigator can feel disturbances hours before they arrive. Keeps us on course and out of trouble."

"How does it work?"

"Detect Magic spell, but specialized. Thora's sensing changes in ambient Urja—how the sea moves, how the wind carries it. Takes years to learn the subtleties." She shrugged. "That's why navigators earn triple what normal crew does."

She worked for an hour. Subtle stance adjustments, course corrections called to the helmsman. The crystal sphere glowed faintly when she channeled Mana—something incredibly complex, made routine.

"Been sailing these waters two hundred years," Thora said without opening her eyes, somehow sensing my stare. "Still learn something new every voyage. That's why I'm still alive."

Two hundred years perfecting one skill. I couldn't even perfect one spell in eight days. The efficiency gap was impressive.

And I had one spell I could cast in less than a second, one spell I could form perfectly but not produce any effect, and one spell I could barely manifest as an eight-inch shimmer.

The gap between us was enormous. At least I was consistent in my limitations.

But maybe, if I was very lucky and very stubborn and didn't die trying, I could find some path forward.

Even if I didn't know what that path was yet.

~~~

Early evening on the tenth day, I was on deck finishing my evening Kata practice. The crew moved differently.

Not rushing. Not panicking. But purposeful. Urgent. The kind of movement that suggested they knew something I didn't.

The navigator—Thora Deepcurrent—was in deep conversation with Captain Ross near the helm. Both looking west toward the horizon where Vallis coastline ran. Thora's weathered hands moved in patterns I couldn't read, her centuries of experience visible in every gesture.

"Storm comin'," one of the sailors said as he hurried past with extra rope coiled over his shoulder. "Big one."

"How do you know?" I asked, looking at the sky. It was clear. Calm. The kind of evening that suggested nothing but peaceful sailing ahead.

"Navigator felt it. She's good—can sense disturbances half a day before they hit." He jerked his thumb toward Captain Ross. "Ross is movin' us away from the coast. Don't want to be near rocks when it arrives."

I looked toward the western horizon. We'd been hugging the Vallis coastline for days, keeping land visible on our port side for navigation. It was still there—a dark line against the evening sky. To the east lay the open Deep Sea. Endless water. Nothing but distance in every direction.

"How long do we have?"

"Six, maybe eight hours if we're lucky. Storm's movin' fast." He continued past. "Secure yer gear. It's gonna get rough."

Gustin emerged from our cabin, looking vaguely green already. "What's happening?"

"Storm. Big one, apparently. Navigator detected it."

"Of course she did." He gripped the rail. "Can we just... not? Can we vote against the storm?"

"I don't think weather takes votes."

"Unfortunate."

Over the next hour, Captain Ross altered our course.

The ship angled east, putting more distance between us and the coastline. The land was still visible to port—a dark line on the western horizon—but further away than it had been all voyage. I could see the logic. In calm weather, hugging the coast meant easy navigation and nearby ports if needed. But in a storm, being close to shore meant getting driven into rocks by waves you couldn't control. Deeper water to the east meant room to maneuver. Space to ride out swells without the coastline trying to kill us.

The crew worked with practiced efficiency. Sailors secured cargo with extra lines, checking every tie-down twice. Anything loose got lashed down or brought below. Canvas was furled tight against spars. Hatches were battened. Everything that could be made safe was made safe.

Passengers disappeared below deck one by one, reading signs I was only beginning to recognize. I helped where I could—which meant staying out of everyone's way.

"How bad is it going to be?" Gustin asked a passing sailor. His voice had that forced casual quality of someone trying not to sound terrified.

"Bad enough we're preparin'," the sailor said, not unkindly. "But we're in deep water now. Got room to ride it out. That's what matters. Ross knows what she's doin'. Twenty years sailin', never lost a ship."

"Encouraging," Gustin muttered.

"Best you'll get." The sailor moved on to check rigging.

I stayed on deck. The sailors moved around me—no wasted movement, no panic. Just competent people doing difficult work they'd done before. At least if we drowned, it wouldn't be from poor planning.

The wind shifted. Subtle at first, coming now from the southwest with a salt-heavy smell that tasted of distance and deep water. The waves grew incrementally—first just higher swells, then breaking crests, then walls of water that made the Dawnbreaker feel smaller than it had.

The sky darkened by degrees. Not the natural dimming of evening, but something heavier. Clouds piling on clouds, gray stacking into black, until the horizon disappeared under the weight of it. The light took on a strange green-gray quality that made everything look sickly and wrong.

"We should go below," Gustin said, but he didn't move. Neither did I. The storm approached with slow inevitability—violence you couldn't stop or change, only endure.

The wind picked up harder. The first drops of rain started falling—cold and hard, like the sky was throwing ice at us. Then more rain. Then sheets of it, horizontal in the wind, stinging exposed skin.

Around us, the last sailors finished their work and headed below. The deck cleared except for the watch crew and Captain Ross at the helm, her hands steady on the wheel.

"We should really go below," Gustin said.

I didn't move. "I know."

"Before we drown standing up."

"I know."

But we stayed a moment longer, watching the storm approach. Watching clouds darken and waves build and wind tear at everything loose. Watching something bigger than us, more powerful than us, utterly indifferent to whether we lived or drowned.

The ship's bell rang—three sharp notes. All hands below except essential crew.

"Come on," I said finally.

We went.

As we descended, I heard Captain Ross's voice cutting through the wind, calling orders to the watch. Steady. Unshaken. The kind of voice that had weathered worse than this.

I wanted to believe the record would hold.

~~~

Gustin and I made it back to our cabin just as the ship's movement got worse. The gentle roll of normal sailing had become something harder. More violent. The kind of motion that made it difficult to walk without grabbing for support.

"This is fine," Gustin said, white-knuckling the edge of his bunk. "This is completely fine."

"You're a terrible liar."

I secured our packs, made sure nothing loose could become a projectile when the real storm hit. My claymore was already lashed to its position against the wall. The narrow shelf was part of the wall's frame. Our bunks were built into the structure itself.

The ship lurched. Gustin made a sound I'd charitably call distressed.

"Want to go to the mess?" I asked. "At least there'll be other people to panic with."

"No. If I'm going to be sick, I'd rather do it here where I won't embarrass myself in front of the entire ship."

"Fair enough."

I sat on my bunk, bracing myself against the wall as the ship rolled. Outside our tiny porthole, the waves grew. Six feet. Eight. Ten. The sky fully dark now, roiling with clouds that seemed to churn with their own inner violence.

The storm was here.

And we were about to find out if Captain Ross's record would hold.

Gustin looked at me from his bunk, face pale in the swinging lamplight. "You think we'll be alright?"

"Twenty years. Never lost a ship."

"That's not comforting."

"It's accurate."

He managed a weak smile. "If we die, at least we won't have to worry about academy rejection."

"That's one way to look at it."

The ship rolled harder. The lamp swung wildly. Outside, the wind howled like something alive and angry.

"Marcus?"

"Yeah?"

"Thanks. For everything. The cabin, the teaching deal, not treating me like I'm useless when I get seasick." He gripped his bunk as the ship lurched again. "If we survive this, we're friends. Real friends. Not just travel companions."

"We're already friends, you idiot."

"Good." He closed his eyes as another wave hit. "Just wanted to make sure you knew."

The storm raged outside. The ship creaked and groaned. And somewhere above us, Captain Ross held the wheel steady, guiding us through violence we couldn't control.

The record would hold. It had to.

I believed it because there was no alternative.

Chapter 8 - Stormy Sea

The storm hit on the eleventh day at sea, just before dawn.

I woke to the cabin pitching hard enough that I rolled off my bunk and hit the floor. Gustin was already awake, gripping the edge of his bunk with white knuckles.

"What's happening?"

"Storm," he managed. His face had gone pale. "Ship's rolling too much. We should—"

A crash from somewhere above. Wood splintering. Shouts.

"Stay here," I said, already moving toward the door.

"Marcus, don't—"

But I was already in the corridor, climbing the ladder to the deck. Ricardo's training: understand the threat before it understands you.

I stumbled onto deck into chaos.

Rain lashed horizontally. Wind tore at anything loose. Sailors shouted orders—mouths moving, words lost in the roar of water and thunder. And the ship—the Dawnbreaker, which had seemed so solid in Portare's calm harbor—rolled like a toy in a bathtub.

The crew worked with grim efficiency despite the chaos. Near the bow, three men fought to secure a loose spar that swung wildly with each wave. Amidships, others pulled on lines, their movements coordinated by shouts I couldn't hear over the wind. Father's warehouse managers moved like that during cargo emergencies. No wasted motion. Every hand knowing its job.

The hold hatch banged open. Kael emerged first, the Hunter team's leader taking in the deck with a single sharp glance. Behind him came the Dwarf—stocky, bearded, built like a boulder with legs. Kael pointed toward the mainmast, shouted something to the Dwarf, and they split—Kael moving to coordinate with the crew, the Dwarf heading to anchor a cargo net that three sailors couldn't hold steady.

Near the port side, three crewmen were fighting with heavy netting that covered crates the size of wardrobes. One of them spotted me standing there.

"You! Help us with this! Move!"

I ran—or tried to. The deck pitched. I grabbed a line to steady myself, made it to where they struggled.

"Pull!" the lead sailor shouted. "Together! Now!"

I grabbed the rope where indicated. Soaked hemp, heavier than it had any right to be, fibers rough enough to tear skin. I pulled.

The crate shifted maybe an inch.

"Harder! Put yer backs into it!"

I threw my weight into it. The rope dug into my palms. The crate moved another few inches, but not enough. Not nearly enough.

One of the sailors swore. "Ain't workin'! We need—"

I dropped the rope and pivoted, grabbing at the crate's binding instead of the securing line. This time I dug deeper—the way Ricardo had trained me to, pushing past the point where my body said stop.

And dragged.

The cargo moved. Six inches. Then a foot. I dragged it toward the securing point while the crew stared.

"How the—?" one started.

"Help me secure it!" I shouted over the storm.

They moved. The four of us locked down the crate with proper netting. Then the next one. And the next. The men had stopped questioning and started pointing me wherever heavy freight needed moving.

That first stretch lasted maybe an hour. Pulling lines, wrestling cargo, securing netting with the crew who'd been doing this for years. My shoulders burned. My hands were raw. But I didn't tire—not like the sailors were tiring. Whatever Ricardo's training had built in me kept my muscles fresh, my movements fast, my balance steady even on the rolling deck.

Across the deck, the Dwarf had abandoned cargo work to help the crew secure the mainmast rigging—his strength and low center of gravity perfect for the job. A sailor slipped; the Dwarf caught him one-handed without breaking stride. No sign of the others from the Hunter team.

And then it was back to work.

~~~

The storm didn't stop. Not that day.

When the crew I'd been working with rotated out for rest, I went with them. Nobody told me to—I just followed their pattern. Two hours below, warming up in the corridor outside our cabin, eating hardtack and drinking water that tasted of salt. Then back up when they went back up.

By evening, the worst had passed—or so we thought. The rain eased. The wind dropped enough that conversation became possible without screaming. The First Mate rotated crews, sent exhausted sailors below to sleep in shifts.

During one of the lulls, Gustin was on deck, clinging to a mast, soaked and miserable. He'd come up on his own sometime during the day, tried to help with lighter tasks. The seasickness combined with the storm had defeated him.

"Come on," I said, grabbing his arm. "Below deck. You're going to fall overboard."

"I'm—" He lurched as the ship rolled. "I'm fine."

"You're very green. Even for a Green. Let me help you down."

Half-carrying him below took effort. Got him into his bunk. Found a bucket in case he needed it.

"Sorry," he muttered. "Not much use in a storm."

"You tried. That's what matters." I grabbed a relatively dry shirt from my pack. "At least you're consistent. Your family name isn't lying."

He managed a weak laugh despite looking like he might die. "I hate you."

"I know." I tossed him the shirt. "Stay here. I'm going back up."

"You don't have to—"

"I know."

But I went anyway. Because the sailors needed help and I could provide it. Simple as that.

~~~

The storm came back harder the second day.

Dawn brought fresh waves, fresh wind, fresh chaos. Whatever had passed for calm the night before was a lie the sea had told us. I worked with the crew—four hours dragging cargo, two hours collapsed with them in the corridor, four more hours at the lines. Grim-faced and efficient, too exhausted for complaints.

By evening of the second day, the storm finally broke. The wind died. The rain became drizzle, then mist, then nothing. The deck stopped trying to throw everyone overboard.

When I came back down, exhausted and soaked, Gustin was asleep in his bunk. I collapsed into mine without bothering to change clothes.

My muscles ached. My hands burned from rope friction. And beneath it all, a deeper exhaustion—not muscle fatigue, something else. The same hollowed-out feeling I got after Ricardo's worst training sessions, when he'd pushed me past what should have been possible. I'd recover. I always did. But for now, emptied.

We'd survived.

The crew had been counting injuries during rest periods: two sailors down—one with a broken arm from a snapped line, another with cracked ribs from being thrown against the mast. I'd been lucky. Or Ricardo's training had kept me balanced when others fell.

Stolen content alert: this content belongs on Royal Road. Report any occurrences.

My hands were torn up, blistered from hemp rope. But my arms didn't shake like the sailor beside me had. Five years of Ricardo's drills. I'd hated every one of them at the time.

I should have thanked him properly. Should have told him I understood what he was trying to teach me instead of resenting every grueling session.

If I made it back to Conducere, I would.

~~~

I woke to pounding on our cabin door.

"Kid! You alive in there?"

The First Mate's voice. I dragged myself upright. My shoulders protested. My hands were covered in line burns and blisters. "Yeah. What is it?"

"Crew's breaking out the ale in the mess. You're invited." A pause. "Saw ya out there during the worst of it. When the swells were highest and half my crew was just tryin' not to get swept over. Ya kept haulin'. Earned a drink."

Gustin was awake now, looking significantly less green than he had during the storm. "You feeling better?"

"Better than yesterday. What's this about ale?"

"Apparently I'm invited to crew drinks. Want to come?"

"Do I count as crew?"

"Only one way to find out."

~~~

The mess was crowded when we arrived. Sailors packed around tables, passing bottles of something that smelled strong enough to strip paint. The Hunter team sat at one table—the Dwarf with his beard still dripping, Senna looking exhausted in a different way than the rest of us, Ash curled protectively in her lap. I hadn't seen her on deck during the storm. Kael quietly cleaned salt spray off his blade. Yara sat nearby, journal open even now, though her hands shook slightly from Mana exhaustion.

At the head of the room, Captain Ross stood with a bottle raised—she'd held the helm during the storm, guiding us through the worst of it.

"Listen up!" Her voice cut through the noise. The room quieted. "We took a beatin' these past two days. Storm like that, most crews lose cargo, lose crew, lose the damn ship. But we had warnin', we moved to deeper water, and Dawnbreaker held. You all held." She looked around the room, her gaze settling briefly on me, then the Dwarf, then the First Mate. "Even had passengers pullin' cargo when it mattered. Hunters who knew their business. A mage holdin' Barrier over a hull breach while we patched it—saved the hold from floodin'. A beast handler who kept our specimen calm for two days solid. And some kid who hauled crates like he was born to it. Twenty years I've been sailin'—never lost a ship, never lost crew. That's because we listen to our navigator, we prepare, and when it counts, we do the work."

She raised the bottle higher. "To surviving!"

"To surviving!" the crew echoed, and the room erupted.

Captain Ross took a long drink, then disappeared back toward the upper deck—captain's work never ended. The First Mate spotted us and waved us over.

"There he is! The kid who moved cargo like he was half-ogre!" She shoved a bottle at me. "Drink. Ya earned it."

I took the bottle cautiously. The liquid burned going down, tasted like someone had dissolved leather in alcohol. The sailors laughed at my expression.

"First time with sailor's ale?" One of them grinned. "Ya get used to it."

Gustin tried it and coughed so hard I thought he'd eject a lung. More laughter.

"Yer the mage boy, right?" a sailor asked Gustin. "Saw ya tryin' to help during the storm. Appreciate the effort even if ya spent half of it lookin' like ya wanted to die."

"I did want to die," Gustin admitted. "I'm not built for sailing."

"Not built for haulin' cargo either," another sailor said, nodding at me. "But yer friend here? Saw him drag that crate across the deck like it owed him money."

"Owed him money and insulted his mother," another added. The table laughed.

"I was there when he grabbed the bindin' instead of the line," a third sailor said. "Thought he'd tear his arms off. Instead the crate moved. Just... moved." He shook his head. "Kid's got somethin' wrong with him."

"Nothing wrong," I said. "Just five years of sword training."

"That explains the arms." The older sailor, scarred and weathered, leaned forward with a grin. "What kind of blade makes arms like that?"

"Claymore. Eighteen pounds."

Whistles around the table. "And ya swing that thing? Daily?"

"Every morning. Ricardo made sure I could."

"Ricardo sounds like a bastard," someone muttered.

"He is. But an effective one."

More laughter. The sailor who'd seen me grab the bindings raised his cup. "To bastard instructors who make kids strong enough to haul our cargo!"

"To bastards!" the table echoed.

"That's not normal training," the Dwarf called from the Hunter table. He stood, walked over with the slight sway of someone three drinks in. "Torvin. Weapons specialist." He sat down heavily. "Aye, eighteen pounds is a war blade—forged for killin', not for show. Most soldiers' arms give out before their form does. You practice daily?"

"Kata every morning. Maintenance every night."

"Every night?" Torvin raised an eyebrow. "On a ship? Salt air's murder on metal."

"I know. I've been oiling it twice a day since we left Portare."

Torvin nodded slowly, something like approval in his expression. "Good lad. Most warriors neglect their steel until it's too late." He leaned back. "When we dock in Navale, bring it by. I'll check the edge proper—sometimes salt gets into places oil can't reach. No charge."

"You don't have to—"

"Professional courtesy." He grinned, beard braids swaying. "Anyone who maintains their blade twice a day at sea has earned it."

I hadn't thought about it. Five years of Ricardo's impossible standards had normalized what, apparently, wasn't normal at all. Compared to people who didn't spend their adolescence being thrown across training yards by a sadistic weapons master, I was unusually strong. Who knew.

"Professional training," the First Mate said, nodding at me. "Fast hands, good balance. Saw it during the storm."

Kael raised his cup from the Hunter table. "Your instructor taught you well. Held your own alongside hunters and crew."

"Half-ogre." That's what the First Mate had called me. Like it was a compliment.

And it was. I'd proven I could haul cargo, fight weather, work like my body was built for it.

Because it was.

My palms were raw. My shoulders still ached. But I'd moved cargo the sailors couldn't shift alone. Forty-five Mi—barely enough to manifest a barrier the size of a dinner plate. But enough Qi to drag crates across a storm-tossed deck. The academies had tested one and ignored the other.

The conversation shifted to sea stories. Captain Ross navigating through Bouris Bay in winter. Pirates. Storm Leviathans near the Deep Sea's edge.

"We tracked a Frost Drake once," Senna offered, Ash curled in her lap. "Northern Vallis, three winters ago. Thirty feet long, breathing ice instead of fire."

"Did you kill it?" someone asked.

"Client just wanted proof it existed." She scratched Ash's ears. "Sometimes the best hunt is the one where nothing dies."

"What about this storm?" a sailor asked. "Didn't see ya on deck."

"Two days in the hold," Senna said, shaking her head. "Trying to keep Silver—the Marten—calm. Sedatives only do so much when the whole world is pitching—he was pacing like a caged wolf, wouldn't settle. Had to adjust the dosage three times, talk to him constantly, keep Ash close so he had something familiar to focus on." She looked at the fox. "She hated every minute of it. Fire-affinity creature in a damp hold—not her idea of a good time."

So that's where she'd been. While I was wrestling cargo above, she'd been doing her own exhausting work below.

Yara, quieter than the rest, added, "Hull breach on the second day. Seawater flooding into the hold. I held Barrier over the crack for twenty-two minutes while they patched it." She flexed her fingers. "Longest I've ever sustained one. My arms are still shaking."

"Twenty-two minutes?" Gustin looked impressed. "That's... that's really good."

"It's exhausting," she corrected, but smiled. "But the cargo stayed dry. The Frost Marten stayed calm. That's what mattered."

Gustin and I mostly listened after that, passing the bottle, laughing at jokes we didn't entirely understand. Hunters and sailors and mages, all celebrating survival. I wasn't watching from outside. Wasn't counting coins or calculating angles. Just... here.

Sailors drifted toward a corner table where someone produced dice. Sailors' Crown—I'd never played it, but silver changed hands fast enough that I learned the stakes before I learned the rules. Four silver gone. Gustin won two back, grinning like he'd beaten the house. The First Mate cleaned everyone out and tapped another cask of ale.

"To surviving storms!" she declared.

"To surviving!" everyone echoed.

We drank. The mess spun slightly. Gustin was grinning, looser than I'd ever seen him. The sailors joked about shore leave and warm beds.

I leaned back against the wall, the pleasant blur of too much sailor's ale softening everything. For tonight, the sailors had accepted me. My shoulders ached from the work, my hands burned from the hemp, and none of it mattered.

Eventually the drinking wound down. Gustin and I stumbled back to our cabin, both pleasantly drunk, steadying each other when the ship rolled.

"Thanks," Gustin said as we reached the door.

"For what?"

"You know. Storm. Carrying me. Ale." He fumbled with the latch. "All of it."

"Same," I said, and meant it.

He pushed the door open. We collapsed into our bunks, the cabin spinning gently.

I was asleep before I could think about what came next.

~~~

The morning after the storm, I woke to hammering.

My head throbbed—part hangover, part exhaustion from the storm work. Outside our cabin, the sounds of repair work echoed through the ship's corridors. The storm had taken its toll. Apparently the Deep Sea didn't care that we'd paid for passage—it collected its own fees in torn canvas and splintered wood.

The First Mate saw me emerge on deck. "Two, maybe three days added to the voyage. Storm damage. If ya got energy left, we could use hands. Otherwise, stay out of the way."

I appreciated the directness. Ricardo would've just thrown things at me until I figured it out myself.

I helped where I could—holding boards while sailors hammered, carrying replacement cordage from storage. My muscles protested every movement, but the work kept me from counting coins and worrying about Mali. At least manual labor didn't require high Mi values. Very economical of the universe.

By the fourteenth evening, Gustin had recovered enough to resume teaching. We practiced Barrier theory in our cabin—fifteen runes across four sections, the same spell Yara had held for twenty-two minutes during the storm.

"Try forming Section One," he said. "Just the first three runes. See what happens."

He demonstrated first—fingers tracing Force, Amplification, Anchor while murmuring the optimization chant. "TE-TA-PA. Now you."

I copied the pattern, matching gesture to syllable. The array shimmered faintly—visible, stable, a recognizable structure. Then I pushed Mana through it.

Nothing dramatic. No barrier manifested. But something happened—a faint resistance in the air in front of my hand, like pushing against fog. Eight inches across, maybe. Less impressive than my Terra Form. More impressive than my Ignite.

"That's... huh. Actually something," Gustin said. "I mean, it's not a real Barrier, but it's not nothing either."

I stared at my hand. Eight inches of fog-like resistance. Wouldn't stop a thrown rock, wouldn't deflect a blade, wouldn't do anything Yara's had done during the storm. But I'd channeled Mana into something that held shape. My second spell that actually produced an effect—even if the effect was barely more than a stubborn pocket of air.

Two spells now. Terra Form and whatever this was—Barrier's sickly younger sibling. Not much of an arsenal, but more than I'd had two weeks ago.

chapters.content_text:
Chapter 9 - Clear Sailing

With the storm behind us, I drilled the complete Barrier array until my fingers ached.

Gustin had walked me through all fifteen runes before the storm, and we'd reviewed them again during repairs. I'd spent hours drawing the array on paper—four interlocking sections, fifteen runes, each connection precise before I moved on to the next. By the time the repairs were finished, I could sketch the complete structure from memory.

But knowing the sequence and executing it were different things. Terra Form was six runes; Barrier was fifteen, spread across four interlocking sections feeding into the next. At this rate, I'd master the complete spell approximately never.

Section One I could manage—three runes, three syllables: TE-TA-PA. The partial success on Day 14 had proved that, even if my first attempt had looked more like fog than force. But Sections Two through Four required both hands working in coordinated sequence. KA-TI-KI for Shape definition. RE-RA-KI for Maintenance. TE-RE-DA for Resistance. Fifteen runes, twelve syllables—some gestures drew multiple runes, Gustin had explained. The choreography cramped my hands within minutes.

"Again," Gustin said for the hundredth time, watching me trace invisible patterns in the cabin air. "Your left hand is lagging on the Feedback transition."

I reset. Started over. "TE-TA-PA"—right hand through Force, Amplification, Anchor. "KA-TI-KI"—right hand continuing with Concentration, Duration, Stabilization—

"There. You hesitated."

"Because Feedback requires three finger transitions in two seconds." My ring finger cramped in sympathy just thinking about it.

"Which is why you practice until it isn't." He grinned. "Come on, from the top."

By the third evening, I had it memorized. Not automatic like Terra Form, but solid. Could draw the complete array from memory, knew which fingers formed which runes, understood how the sections connected.

"You're ready to try casting it," Gustin said.

"Tomorrow," I said. "After morning Kata practice. Let me sleep on it first."

~~~

The next morning I was on deck early, running through Kata forms while the crew worked around me.

The sea was calm—calmer than it had been since before the storm. The deck barely moved under my feet. I'd adapted my stances to the ship's roll early in the voyage, but today I could almost pretend I was back in Ricardo's training yard.

Halfway through the Wind-Cutting sequence, one of the older sailors stopped to watch. Weathered face, arms like knotted rope from decades of hauling lines. He'd been part of the crew I'd worked with during the storm—I recognized him, and from the way he planted himself with arms crossed, he recognized me too. Sleeves rolled up to show off forearms thicker than my calves.

A couple of his mates noticed him watching, exchanged glances, and drifted over.

When I finished the form and lowered my blade, he swaggered over.

"That real steel yer swingin'?" He was eyeing the blade like he was sizing up competition.

"Sheathed, but yes." I kept the blade covered during practice—added a bit of weight, but safer on a crowded deck. "Eighteen pounds without the scabbard."

He snorted. "Eighteen pounds? That's nothin'. Hauled crates four times that weight up cargo nets." He flexed one arm, casual-like. "Mind if I give 'er a swing? Show ya how a real man handles steel?"

His mates shuffled closer, sensing a show.

"Go on then, Darrol," one of them called. "Show 'im how it's done."

I handed it over, hilt first. This should be educational.

He took it with both hands, tested the weight—then shifted to a one-handed grip, blade extended like he'd seen officers do in parade formations. Rolled his neck. Cracked his knuckles. Made a whole production of it while his mates whistled and stamped.

"Right then." He wound up for a sweeping strike. "Take that, ya scurvy—" The blade came around with decent force. He reset, grinning at his audience. "And that, ya bilge rat—" Second stroke, still strong. Third. Fourth. His form was holding, raw strength compensating for technique.

"Give 'im the two-handed grip, Darrol!" someone called. "Yer wrist's gonna snap off!"

"Don't need it!" Fifth stroke. Sixth. But his wrist was starting to wobble, the blade's weight pulling at the joint. Seventh. Eighth. Ninth—

By the tenth, his forearm was trembling visibly, the blade dipping between swings. He switched to a two-handed grip, managed two more solid cuts, then lowered the sword and shook out his arm, grimacing.

"Gods." He flexed his fingers, working out the cramp. "How'd I do?"

"The bilge rat is definitely dead," I said. "The scurvy might need another swing or two."

That got a roar from the watching sailors. Darrol laughed and handed the blade back, still shaking out his sword hand. "Gods. How d'ya swing this thing for an hour straight? Twice a day? One-handed, no less?"

"Two-handed," I said. "Like you're supposed to."

That got another laugh from his mates. Darrol took it well enough—shrugged and grinned. "Right, well. Still."

He shook his head, massaging his wrist. "Forty years haulin' rope. Loaded cargo that'd break a young man's back. A dozen swings one-handed and I'm shakin' like a leaf." He studied me now, no mockery left. "Yer what, sixteen? Seventeen? What's the trick?"

I didn't have an answer. Forty years of honest labor versus five years of being thrown across training yards. Apparently suffering compounded better than savings.

He clapped me on the shoulder—harder than necessary, probably salvaging some pride—and wandered back to his duties. His mates drifted off too, show over, back to work. Left me standing there with my sheathed claymore and a question that wouldn't let go.

This tale has been unlawfully lifted from Royal Road; report any instances of this story if found elsewhere.

My strength came from Ricardo's training—five years of daily practice with heavy steel. Or so I'd thought. But this sailor had forty years of physical labor. Decades of building muscle, building endurance. His arms were thicker than mine, his grip stronger from a lifetime of rope work.

And his arm had given out after a dozen one-handed swings.

The storm. Moving cargo three sailors couldn't shift. Working for hours without exhausting the way they had. The hollowed-out feeling afterward—not muscle tired, something deeper.

Kael had said something, back when he first saw me practicing. About Qi reserves. Body growing into it.

I found him near the bow, checking equipment with Torvin. He looked up as I approached.

"Question?"

"That sailor who just tried my sword—forty years of hauling rope, and his arm gave out after a dozen one-handed swings." I sat on a crate nearby. "I can swing it for an hour, twice a day. Took me years to build up to that."

Five years ago, I'd managed a dozen strokes before my arms gave out. Now I ran the full kata twice daily. All those years drilling Terra Form—failing at it, obsessing over every failed cast—and I'd missed what was happening with the blade itself.

Kael glanced at Torvin, who had stopped working to listen.

"You said something before," I continued. "About Qi reserves—the body growing into it. What did you mean?"

"Everyone stores Urja in their cells. Passive. Automatic." Kael tested a strap, adjusted it. "Physical labor builds baseline. Those sailors—forty years hauling rope. High storage."

"But I outwork them—during the storm, just now."

"Different." He moved to the next piece of equipment. "Martial training builds pathways. Not just storage. Body learns to channel durin' movement. Sword forms. Combat stances."

"Channel?"

"Active use. Not passive storage." He glanced at me. "Your instructor. Heavy blade from the start?"

"Eighteen pounds, since I was ten."

Kael nodded slowly. "Body grew into it. Pathways formed while you were still developing. Becomes automatic. Don't think about it. Body just does."

Torvin grunted. "Aye, proper way to train. Start 'em young, start 'em heavy. Forges the pathways deep."

Ricardo's endless drills. Forms repeated until reflex. Never explaining why—just pushing harder, demanding more.

"Ricardo taught me to channel," I said slowly, testing the word. "Without ever calling it that."

"Proper instructor." Kael finished with the equipment, straightened. "Most warriors channel durin' trained movements. Automatic. No thought required."

"And during the storm? When I pushed harder than I ever had?"

"Went beyond automatic. Conscious effort." He met my eyes briefly. "Exhausting. Burns fast. But in crisis—three, four times stronger than baseline."

The hollowed-out feeling after the storm. The same exhaustion after Ricardo's worst sessions. He'd been building this in me for five years. Training my body to channel without ever telling me what I was learning.

"Ricardo knew exactly what he was doing," I said.

"Sahash-Dorh Kata." Kael nodded. "Style's designed for it. Sword work and channelin'. Built together."

Five years of hating every drill. Every bruise. Every morning thinking he was just a sadistic old man with impossible standards.

He'd been making me into something the academies couldn't measure. Very sneaky of him. I'd have to be angry about that later, after I finished being grateful.

"Thank you," I said.

Kael nodded once. "Keep practicin'. Reserves still growin'." He paused. "Give it years."

He and Torvin moved off toward the stern. I rose from the crate, gripping my sheathed claymore. The weight was different now. I owed Ricardo more than I'd ever admitted.

~~~

"Ready to try casting it?" Gustin found me on deck an hour later, still processing.

The sea was calm, the morning bright. I had all fifteen runes memorized. Could draw each section from memory. Had practiced the chant and finger choreography until my hands cramped and my voice went hoarse.

"I can try. Don't expect much."

"I'm expecting something, even if it's weak. You've got the technique down. Trust it."

Feet shoulder-width, weight centered, hands ready—positioning like Gustin had taught me. Then I began.

All ten fingers this time, not just my right hand like Terra Form. The array was complex enough it needed both hands working in sequence.

Right hand—Section One. "TE-TA-PA." Index finger traces Force, middle finger Amplification, thumb pressing down for Anchor. Each rune formed in the air, invisible but present. The circuit began to take shape.

Section Two. "KA-TI-KI." Index finger circles for Concentration, ring finger vertical for Duration, ring finger circles again for Stabilization. Three days of drilling and my fingers still wanted to trip over each other.

Section Three. "RE-RA-KI." Feedback, Channeling, Terminus. The Maintenance runes that kept Mana flowing properly. My concentration wavered at the diagonal strokes—Gustin's voice in my head: smoother, don't jerk.

Section Four. "TE-RE-DA." Enhancement, Resonance, Isolation. The final touches that would make the barrier actually resist something.

Eight seconds. Maybe nine. Concentrating so hard I could barely breathe.

Mana flowed into the completed array.

Nothing. The Mana thinned and scattered like water into sand—there, then gone, leaving no trace.

The runes shimmered in the air, the circuit straining to form. But no barrier appeared. Just emptiness where the Force plane should have been.

"Again," Gustin said. "You formed the pattern correctly—I saw it. Try pushing more Mana into Section One. That's where the Force generates—that should strengthen the plane."

Second attempt. Seven seconds this time, the chant and finger choreography becoming more automatic.

I pushed Mana hard into the Force rune. Something responded—a resistance, like the circuit was actually drawing power.

And then—

A shimmer. Translucent, barely visible. Maybe six inches across.

The tiny barrier floated in the air in front of me, a whisper of Force that looked like heat distortion. I held my concentration.

Two seconds. Three. Four.

It faded.

But it had been there. I'd formed a Barrier.

"Marcus!" Gustin grabbed my shoulder. "You did it! That was a Barrier! Weak, but real!"

"That wouldn't block a stick," I said, staring at where the shimmer had been. "Six inches across, four seconds duration. I could defend myself from an aggressive houseplant. Academy-ready, clearly."

"That's incredible for someone at forty-five Mi!" He was grinning. "I mean—even people at fifty Mi struggle with Barrier, at least that's what Corvin taught me. Fifteen to eighteen runes all interlocking—it's not just about having the Mana, you need the channeling capacity to hold the whole structure together. But you did it!"

"A six-inch shield that lasts four seconds isn't useful."

"It's proof you can learn complex arrays. That you're not just someone who got lucky with one spell." He was practically bouncing. "Try again. See if you can make it bigger or last longer."

I tried. Third attempt—six seconds to cast. The shimmer appeared, maybe eight inches this time, lasted five seconds.

Fourth attempt—five seconds to cast. Eight inches, held for five seconds before dispersing.

By the tenth attempt, I had it down to a pattern: Five-second casting time. Eight-inch circular barrier. Five-second duration before my concentration broke.

Gustin's three-foot solid barrier could last thirty seconds. Mine was the magical equivalent of a sneeze—brief, ineffective, and mildly embarrassing.

My arms were fine—no hollowed-out exhaustion like during the storm. I flexed my fingers. Started to form the array again, but my vision blurred at the third rune.

"You look wrung out," Gustin said. "Mentally, I mean. Not physically."

He was right. Muscles fine. Head pounding. Terra Form had become automatic after years of drilling—my body knew those runes the way it knew how to breathe. But Barrier was still new, still requiring conscious attention for every one of its fifteen components. Five seconds of that kind of focus, and my mind simply gave out.

But it was something.

"That's good progress," Gustin said when I finally stopped, exhausted from repeated casting. "You learned a fifteen-rune array in four days and can manifest it. That's first-year academy level work."

"With tenth-year academy level output."

"With forty-five Mi level output," he corrected. "You're working with minimum capacity. Of course your barrier is small and weak. But you're producing it at all." He gripped my shoulder. "When you get to Academia Midur and they test you—show them this. Show them you can learn complex arrays even if your Mi value is at Om Point. That..." He trailed off, then rallied. "That proves you're worth teaching. It has to."

I looked at my hands. Fifteen runes. Four days. It should matter.

But I'd already been rejected twice. Belief wasn't something I could afford right now.

"Come on," Gustin said, breaking the moment. "Let's get food. You've been channeling Mana for an hour straight. You need to eat."

My stomach agreed with him. Apparently magic required fuel. The academies probably had equations for that too.

We headed down to the mess. My hands were trembling slightly—not from Qi exhaustion like during the storm, but from the sustained mental focus of repeated Barrier attempts. Different kind of tired.

I'd learned a fifteen-rune array in less than a week. Could manifest it, however weakly.

The academies would probably still reject me.

But at least I'd tried.
