chapters.content_text:
Chapter 10 - The Light Beneath

After nearly three weeks of grey-blue nothing, the sea woke up. Fish everywhere—schools of silver darting beneath the surface, so thick in places the water shimmered like someone had spilled coins across it. And the dolphins.

They came from nowhere. One moment the water was empty, the next a pod of them was racing alongside the Dawnbreaker, leaping through the bow wake, their sleek bodies catching sunlight as they arced through the spray.

"Look at that one!" A woman at the rail pointed as a dolphin launched itself completely clear of the water, twisting mid-air before splashing back down. "Did you see?"

Everyone saw. The whole ship had stopped to watch.

Sailors paused their work, gathering at the rails with the passengers. Even the gruff Dwarf woman who usually kept to herself was watching, her weathered face creased into something that might have been a smile. Children—I hadn't realized there were children aboard, they'd stayed below during the storm—shrieked with delight every time a dolphin jumped.

Gustin leaned against the rail beside me, some color finally back in his face. For the first time in days, he wasn't gripping the wood like it might betray him.

"This almost makes three weeks at sea worth it." He grinned wider than I'd seen him since we left Portare. "I was starting to think the whole sea was just... water. Endless, boring, stomach-churning water."

"It is mostly that."

"Don't ruin this for me."

One of the dolphins kept pace with the ship right below where I stood, its dark eye visible through the water. When it surfaced to breathe, it chirped—half whistle, half something sharper—like it was trying to say something. It held my gaze for a long moment before diving again.

My jaw ached. I'd been smiling—actually smiling—without realizing it.

The sunlight caught the spray from a nearby leap and scattered into tiny rainbows. The dolphins called to each other in clicks and whistles. Someone behind me laughed—genuine, surprised laughter, the kind you can't fake.

Mother would have cast something. Explained the magic behind the dolphins' coordination, the way they moved as one. She'd always been like that—seeing the world through spell theory.

The thought came unbidden, and for once I didn't push it away.

The dolphins leaped. The spray caught light. Gustin laughed beside me—genuine, unguarded.

For a few minutes, nothing else existed. Just dolphins racing a ship through water that glittered like scattered treasure.

Then they vanished.

All of them. Instantly.

One moment the dolphins were leaping and calling, the next the water was empty. The fish disappeared too—the silver schools diving deep, the shimmer gone like it had never been there.

The sea went still. Silent.

Gustin straightened beside me. "Where did they—"

"That ain't right." An old sailor near us straightened, his weathered face suddenly alert. "Fish don't scatter like that 'less—"

"WHIRLPOOL FORMING!" The lookout's voice cracked across the deck. "PORT SIDE! TWO HUNDRED FEET!"

Captain Ross was already moving. I'd never seen the woman move that fast.

"Hard starboard! Full sail, NOW!" Her voice carried like a war horn. "All hands! Sea Beast hunt in progress!"

The ship heeled as the helmsman spun the wheel. Sailors scrambled for rigging. Passengers grabbed rails, each other, anything solid.

I looked to port.

The water was moving wrong. Circling. A depression forming in the surface, water spiraling inward toward a center that kept deepening. The whirlpool grew as I watched—twenty feet across, then forty, then wider still.

"Below decks!" The First Mate was shoving passengers toward the hatches. "Everyone below NOW!"

Gustin grabbed my arm, pulling. "Marcus, we should—"

My feet stayed planted on the deck. Something else was rising. Beneath the whirlpool, coming up fast, a light approached from the depths—blue-white, massive, like a cold sun ascending.

The whirlpool wasn't random. Something was creating it.

Something was collecting prey.

~~~

The Leviathan erupted from the center of the whirlpool like a nightmare breaking the surface of a dream.

The head came first—massive, scaled, jaws opening wide enough to swallow a rowboat. It surged up through the spiraling water and snapped shut on the concentrated mass of fish the whirlpool had gathered. The sound was like wet thunder.

Then the body.

It just kept coming. Serpentine, dark scales that gleamed like wet iron in the afternoon light, rising and rising as the creature's momentum carried it upward. The visible portion stretched longer than the Dawnbreaker—and beneath the surface, dark coils wound deeper, the body continuing into depths that swallowed light.

But the crystal formations—those froze me mid-breath.

Along its spine, running the full length of its back, crystal formations jutted from the scales. Not a glow. Structures. Jagged ridges of something crystalline, blue-white, catching the light like a crown of frozen lightning. And they were lit from within—pulsing, bright, still active from whatever it had just cast.

The Leviathan's head and neck arced into a dive. The tail whipped up—powerful as a siege engine—and came down with a crack that sent waves radiating outward. Even at this distance, the Dawnbreaker rolled hard enough to throw people off their feet.

Then it was gone. The water surged, churned, and swallowed the creature whole.

The whirlpool collapsed. The light faded beneath the surface, descending, retreating into the depths.

Silence.

Someone was crying. Someone else was praying—fragments of old blessings to sea gods I'd never paid attention to. Gustin had his hands clamped on the rail so tight his knuckles had gone white.

"Gods preserve us," someone whispered. "Gods preserve us."

The First Mate's voice cut through the shock. "Everyone all right? Anyone injured?" She was moving through the passengers, checking, counting. Professional. Steady. "That's it, folks. Show's over. It got what it came for—we ain't on the menu."

People started talking. The SIZE of it. The TEETH. Did you see the waves? Could it have capsized us?

"Did you see the teeth?" Gustin's voice was unsteady. His grip on the rail hadn't loosened. "That thing could have swallowed the whole ship. Just—just opened its mouth and..." He ran a hand through his hair, the gesture shaky. "Marcus, that was a Leviathan. A Leviathan. They're supposed to stay in deep water. What was it doing this close to—"

"The spikes."

"What?"

"On its spine." My eyes wouldn't leave the water where those crystal formations had been. "Did you see them? The crystal spikes. They were glowing."

Gustin stared at me. "We almost got eaten by something longer than the Dawnbreaker and you're thinking about... spikes?"

I didn't answer. The dolphins had the right idea, I thought distantly. My merchant's brain tried to calculate what those crystalline formations might be worth—before the magnitude of what I'd seen overwhelmed the calculation entirely.

Those weren't decorations. They were glowing because it was casting.

~~~

An hour later, we were back in our cabin. The excitement on deck had finally died down—passengers and sailors alike still shaken but returning to routine. Gustin sat on his bunk, fidgeting with the edge of his spellbook. I hadn't stopped pacing.

"You're going to wear a groove in the floor," he said.

"The spikes were lit up." I'd paced our cabin twelve times already, counting without meaning to. "While it was creating the whirlpool. What were those?"

Gustin's fidgeting stopped. He looked up at me, glanced at his spellbook, back to me. A familiar pattern—the one where he wanted to explain something but wasn't sure he knew it well enough.

"You mean the crystals on its spine?" He ran a hand through his hair. "I mean... that was its core. Had to be."

If you spot this story on Amazon, know that it has been stolen. Report the violation.

"Its core."

"Crystallized Mana." He shifted, sitting up straighter—teacher mode, the way he got when explaining spells. "When you have enough Mi—above the Om Point threshold—your Mana can crystallize. That's what lets mages cast. The core concentrates and stores Mana, channels it through spell arrays..."

"I know the basic concept." I didn't, not really—not in any detail. "Where does the core form?"

"The heart. Internal." Gustin tapped his chest. "That's where Mana naturally concentrates in most creatures. The crystallization happens inside, around the heart. You can't see it without..." He made a cutting gesture. "You know."

"But that thing's core wasn't in its chest."

"No." Gustin frowned, the realization settling in. "No, it wasn't. The whole spine was glowing. I saw it too—I just didn't..." He trailed off, then shook his head. "I don't know. Corvin never mentioned anything like that. Beasts have internal cores. That's what he taught me."

"So why was the Leviathan's core external? On the outside of its body?"

"I..." Gustin spread his hands, helpless. "I don't know, Marcus. Maybe it's a Leviathan thing? Maybe they're just different?"

"Different how?"

"I don't know." He exhaled, frustrated—not at me, at his own limitations. "Look, Corvin taught me about crystallization, about cores, about spell theory. He didn't teach me Beast biology."

I stopped pacing. The pieces connected.

"The Frost Marten."

"What about it?"

"Yara told me some Beasts crystallize along their spines instead of their hearts. She thinks the Frost Marten might be one of them—said the markings on its back could indicate core location." I was talking faster now, thoughts connecting. "Different species, different biology, different core structures. I already knew that. But I just saw it work. The Leviathan's spine was glowing while it cast that whirlpool. External core, actively channeling."

Gustin frowned. "Okay... so Beasts can have external cores. We knew that."

"But I watched it function. Same as an internal core. Different location, same result." I met his eyes. "If external cores work just as well for Beasts—"

"Marcus." His voice sharpened. "Where are you going with this?"

I didn't answer directly. "Yara's the Beast researcher. She'd know more about how external crystallization actually works. The mechanics of it."

He stared at me for a long moment, something wary in his expression. Then he stood up, grabbing his spellbook out of habit. "Come on. Let's go find her."

~~~

We found Yara in the cargo hold.

She was checking the Frost Marten's enclosure when we climbed down the ladder. A temperature gauge rested in her hands as she adjusted the preservation array, her attention fixed on the readings.

"I'm working," she said without looking up.

"The Leviathan's spikes," I said. "The crystal formations on its spine."

"I said I'm working."

"They were glowing while it cast and stopped after." I hadn't moved from the base of the ladder. Gustin hovered behind me, quiet. "Gustin says cores are supposed to form internally. In the heart. But that thing's core was external—growing through its scales."

Yara paused. The temperature gauge hovered over the enclosure.

Slowly, she turned to look at me. Really look. Like I was a specimen under examination.

"You're at Om Point, aren't you." Not a question. "Forty-five Mi. Exactly at the threshold."

I didn't answer.

"Most people ask if it could have eaten the ship." She set down the gauge, crossed her arms. "You watched it cast a spell and want to know how."

"I watched it hunt using magic. I want to know what I saw."

She was quiet for a moment. Then she sighed, turned back to the Frost Marten's enclosure, and resumed her work—but she kept talking.

"Most Beasts have internal cores. Heart-based, usually. Picture maybe half a pound of crystallized Mana concentrated in the heart." She adjusted something, checked a reading. "The crystallization happens internally. You can't see it without cutting the Beast open."

"But Leviathans are different."

"Leviathans are different." She moved to another section of the enclosure. "Their Mana crystallizes externally. Along the spine. Those spikes you saw? That's the core structure. Not inside the body—outside. Visible. Growing through the scales."

I stepped closer. "The glow—"

"It was channeling." She glanced at me. "Using the crystallized Mana to power that whirlpool spell. When a Beast casts, you can sometimes see the core light up—internal cores glow through the chest, external ones..." She gestured vaguely. "Well. You saw."

"So Mana can crystallize externally." I was thinking out loud. "Outside the body. And it still works."

"For Leviathans, yes. Think of it like..." She paused, searching for words. "A regular Beast has a gemstone locked inside a box. You know it's there, but you can't see it. A Leviathan has the gemstone growing on the outside of the box, in plain view. Different location, same function."

Behind me, Gustin made a small sound of understanding. A merchant's analogy. Father would have approved—right before telling me to stop wasting time on things that couldn't be sold.

"Has anyone tested alternate crystallization for sentient races?"

Yara stopped working.

When she turned this time, her eyes narrowed. Her hand paused over the tools, fingers going still.

"That's a very specific question."

"I'm curious."

"You're desperate." She set down her tools. "I've seen that look before. Usually on students who've been told they can't do something and refuse to accept it."

"Has anyone tested it?"

"Crystallization experiments for sentient races are dangerous." Her voice had hardened. "Forcing Mana into incorrect pathways causes damage. Internal scarring. Circulatory disruption. Death." She stepped toward me. "Whatever you're thinking—"

"Marcus." Gustin's voice was quiet behind me. A warning.

"I'm just asking questions."

The lie hung between us. We both knew it was a lie.

Yara studied me for a long moment. Then she shook her head, turned back to her work.

"Asking questions is fine. Questions are how we learn." She picked up her temperature gauge again. "But there's a difference between asking questions and doing something stupid because you don't like the answers you've been given. The Om Point exists for a reason. Thousands of people have been tested at forty-five Mi over seventeen hundred years. None of them developed functional cores."

"In their hearts."

She paused.

"In their hearts," I repeated. "That's what Wizard Om tested. Heart-based crystallization. But if Leviathans can crystallize externally—"

"Leviathans aren't human." Her voice was flat. "Their biology is fundamentally different. Distributed nervous systems, different Mana circulation patterns, different everything. What works for them doesn't translate to sentient races."

"How do we know if no one's tested it?"

"We know because people have died trying things exactly like what you're suggesting." She turned to face me fully. "Marcus—I don't know your story, and I'm not asking. But whatever brought you here, whatever you're hoping to prove, don't let it kill you. There are worse things than being at Om Point. One of them is being dead because you couldn't accept your limitations."

"I understand. Thank you for explaining." The words came automatically—the same tone I'd used when Father's business partners told me I'd make a fine merchant someday.

Yara's jaw tightened. She watched us climb the ladder, one hand still half-raised as though she'd meant to say something more.

Back on deck, Gustin grabbed my arm before I could head for our cabin.

"Marcus." His face was troubled. "What she said about crystallization experiments. The deaths. You're not actually thinking about—"

"I'm thinking about a lot of things."

"That's not an answer."

I pulled my arm free, gently. "It's the only one I have right now."

He stared at me for a long moment. His jaw worked like he wanted to say something else. His eyes flicked to his spellbook—the worn leather one he studied every night, the one that would get him through Academia Midur's doors—then back to me.

"Just..." He exhaled. "Don't do anything stupid. Please."

"I'll try."

His hand tightened on the rail. He didn't ask me to promise.

~~~

That night, Gustin fell asleep within minutes—exhausted from the day, finally getting the first peaceful rest he'd managed since the storm. His breathing was steady from the upper bunk. The Leviathan sighting had drained whatever energy the dolphins had given him.

I wrote until the lamp oil ran low.

Merchant's habit. Father had drilled it into me for years: Note things down. A merchant can't remember everything. Write it while it's fresh.

He'd meant cargo manifests. Pricing fluctuations. Trade routes and competitor weaknesses.

I used his training for something he'd have called a waste of ink.

~~~

OBSERVATIONS - Sea Beast (Leviathan hunting)

Whirlpool spell to collect fish. MAGIC. Active casting.Ship distance: ~150-200 feet (safe, barely)Size: 100+ feet visible, more below surfaceCrystal SPIKES along spine. Not internal. EXTERNAL.Spikes glowed while casting. Stopped glowing after dive.
The core wasn't inside it. The core was OUTSIDE. Visible. Working.

GUSTIN SAID:

Cores = crystallized Mana. Form when Mi is above threshold.Normally internal. In the heart.Can't see without cutting open.He didn't know about external cores. Corvin never taught him.

YARA SAID:

Most beasts: internal cores. Half pound crystallized Mana, in the heart.Leviathans: EXTERNAL crystallization. Spine spikes = the core structure."Gemstone outside the box, not inside."Glowed because channeling Mana through the structure.Different biology. Distributed nervous systems.

~~~

I tried to sketch the spikes. The result looked like a child's drawing of angry grass. I crossed it out. Father would have called it a waste of good paper.

~~~

External.

The Mana crystallized EXTERNALLY.

It worked.

It CAST A SPELL.

Has anyone tried external crystallization for humans?

Has anyone even ASKED?

QUESTIONS:

Om Point says 45 Mi minimum for heart crystallizationWhat if that's only true for INTERNAL cores?What if there's a different threshold for external?Yara says Leviathan biology is differentBut the PRINCIPLE is the sameCrystallization can happen outside the bodyIt can still functionIt can still channel
What if

~~~

The writing got messier here. My hand wasn't steady.

~~~

45 Mi isn't enough for heart crystallization.

Everyone agrees. Two academies. 1,700 years of research. The threshold exists.

But what if the threshold is LOCATION-SPECIFIC?

What if 45 Mi is only the minimum for hearts because hearts are where humans naturally concentrate Mana?

What if external crystallization requires LESS because it doesn't have to form inside the body?

What if

What if

~~~

Mother taught me one spell. One. She died before she could teach me anything else—before she could explain why some things were possible and others weren't.

What would she have said about this?

~~~

Father would say I'm wasting ink.

Father isn't here.

~~~

The ink had dried unevenly where my hand had smeared it. The handwriting deteriorated paragraph by paragraph—neat merchant's script at the top, barely legible scrawl by the bottom.

Someone desperate had written this. Someone grasping at observations because accepting the alternative meant his father was right.

The academies had rejected me. My father had assumed I'd finally accept it. Everyone said forty-five Mi wasn't enough.

And here I was, in a ship cabin in the middle of the sea, writing theories about external crystallization because I'd watched a monster eat fish and couldn't stop thinking about the light in its spine.

Maybe I was delusional. Maybe this was what giving up looked like when you weren't brave enough to actually give up—pretending you had ideas when really you just had desperation.

But I'd already run away from home to chase one impossible thing.

I closed the journal. The lamp flickered, nearly out.

~~~

Sleep didn't come easy.

I lay in my bunk, listening to the ship creak around me, thinking about what I'd seen.

Somewhere beneath us, the Leviathan was swimming. A spine full of crystallized power it had never trained for. No academy. No meditation. No one telling it forty-five Mi wasn't enough.

Just existing. Just being what biology made it.

Meanwhile I had one spell, eight years of practice, and a threshold everyone agreed I couldn't cross.

In the darkness, my hands rested on my chest. The same hands that had traced rune patterns all day without conscious thought. The same hands that moved through the Kata—through Terra Form—in half a heartbeat, even if the earth barely rippled in response.

The Leviathan's Mana had crystallized outside its body.

What else might crystallize, given the right circumstances?

I didn't have an answer. I didn't even have a theory—just fragments and desperation and the memory of light in the water.

But I had questions now.

That had to count for something.

chapters.content_text:
Chapter 11 - The Final Leg

We docked at Deepwatch the next morning.

I hadn't slept well—theories chasing themselves in circles, the same desperate questions filling page after page until the lamp oil ran out. But the port was right there, and practical matters wouldn't wait. Merchant's habit: deal with what's in front of you first.

The port was Esparre territory—a transit berth on the outer harbor, much like Saltcrest had been. But where our first stop had been grey stone and cold efficiency, Deepwatch felt alive. Colorful awnings stretched over market stalls. The air carried warmth and spice instead of salt and survival. Ships from half a dozen nations crowded the berths, flags snapping in a breeze that actually felt pleasant.

"Six hours, ya got," the First Mate announced. "Evenin' bell, we sail without ya."

Gustin and I went ashore.

The transit district bustled with more variety than I'd seen anywhere. Humans haggled at food stalls. A pair of Elves examined cargo manifests near a warehouse, their movements precise and unhurried. And on the docks themselves—

"Is that an Ogre?" Gustin's voice went up half an octave.

It was. Nearly eight feet tall, grey-skinned, hauling crates that would have taken three men to lift. He stacked them on a cart like they weighed nothing while a human merchant checked items off a list.

"Two of them," I said, spotting another further down the dock. "And Orcs."

Green-skinned, broad-shouldered, working the ropes with practiced efficiency. They called to each other in a language I didn't recognize, laughing at something as they secured a ship's mooring lines.

More races in one transit dock than I'd seen in my entire life in Conducere. Deepwatch was a crossroads, and it showed.

We found food—skewered meat that actually tasted like meat, not salt-preserved survival rations. Two silver for both meals.

"Want to practice?" Gustin asked, eyeing a quiet stretch of pier. "There's time."

We found a spot away from the bustle. Gustin cast his Barrier first—seven seconds, three feet of translucent shimmer. Solid. Controlled.

I cast mine. Five seconds. Eight inches. Same as two days ago.

"Still faster than me," he offered.

"Still useless." I let the pathetic shimmer fade. "Very economical progress toward inadequacy."

Gustin's expression tightened. He looked away, toward the Ogre loading another impossible stack of crates.

"Have you thought more about it?" he asked quietly. "The Leviathan, I mean. The external core."

I'd thought about little else. My journal was filling with messy questions—external crystallization, spine formations, what it might mean for someone who couldn't crystallize internally. What if the Om Point threshold was location-specific? What if forty-five Mi wasn't enough for hearts but might be enough for... something else? The same desperate logic circling, no closer to answers.

"I've thought about it."

"And?"

"And I don't know anything more than I did yesterday." The Ogre heaved another crate. Raw strength, no magic required. "Yara said Leviathan biology is fundamentally different. Maybe she's right. Maybe external cores only work for Leviathans—different biology, different rules." I shrugged. "Very convenient for them."

Gustin was watching me with that expression he got when I pushed too hard during training. "Marcus... you know this might not lead anywhere, right? The Leviathan was—it's a Beast. What works for them doesn't necessarily—"

"I know." I cut him off before he could finish. Believing something didn't make it true. Neither did desperately wanting it to be true. "I know."

"We should head back," I said. "Don't want to miss the bell."

~~~

The wind was at our backs.

Three days of it—steady, pushing us south and east faster than Captain Ross had expected. The Dawnbreaker kept the coastline in sight, sailing in deeper water but never losing the dark line of land on our port side.

"Makin' good time," the First Mate announced on the second morning. "Wind holds, we'll reach Navale half a day early."

The coastline changed as we traveled. Rocky Esparre shores gave way to something different. Greener. Scattered growth along clifftops thickened into proper forest. By the third day, the land was a solid wall of green.

Ancient forest—trees so tall their canopies formed a continuous ceiling above the shore. Growth that had been there since before humans built cities.

"Regalis," Gustin said, standing beside me at the rail. He'd been talking more than usual these past few days—questions and half-finished thoughts filling the silences. "Aldric told me about it once. The ambient Urja is supposed to be... different here. Richer. Because of the trees."

"Different how?"

"I don't know exactly. He said you could feel it. Like the air wanted to fill you up." He drummed his fingers on the rail. "Maybe it helps with crystallization. More Urja available means easier conversion, I think. Or that's what he said, anyway."

The air wanted to fill you up. Poetic. I wondered if it would bother trying with someone at the Om Point.

Though if external crystallization worked differently... if the threshold for forming cores outside the body was lower than inside... richer ambient Urja might actually matter. My journal questions circled back, the same desperate logic I'd been chasing since the Leviathan. No answers. Just more variables.

Aldric. Gustin's surrogate father, the village chief who'd studied at Academia Midur decades ago. The man who'd helped Gustin crystallize his Mana before this journey began.

"What else did he tell you about Regalis?"

Gustin's fingers kept drumming. "That the Elves run everything. I mean, obviously—it's their kingdom. But he said they're... particular. About humans. About anyone with lower Mi values." He glanced at me, then away. "They don't say it outright. They're too polite for that. But they have opinions."

"Opinions."

"Strong ones." His fingers stopped drumming. "Aldric said to be respectful. Keep our heads down. Don't give them reasons to notice us."

Sound advice. The kind father would have given. Don't make waves, don't draw attention, let the deal close before anyone looks too closely.

The forest-covered coast slid past. Somewhere in there, Mali waited. Academia Midur. Answers.

Or rejection. Again.

~~~

We reached Navale at sunset on the fourth day.

The harbor was massive. Not just large—I'd seen large harbors. Portare was large. This was something else entirely. The docks stretched in every direction, divided into sections I couldn't count. Commercial berths. Passenger piers. A separate area that had to be naval vessels. And beyond all of it, the mouth of the Regis River—wide enough to swallow three ships abreast, the waterway that would carry us to Mali.

"That's..." Gustin's voice trailed off.

"Big," I finished. "That's big."

Ships from every nation I'd heard of and several I hadn't. Human traders. Dwarven cargo haulers with their distinctive broad hulls. Sleek Elven vessels that looked more like art than transportation. And everywhere—everywhere—people working.

On the passenger piers, officials directed traffic—some with hand signals, others with actual magic. Levitating luggage. Illuminating pathways with conjured light. Using spells the way I used my hands.

And on the cargo docks—

"More Ogres," Gustin said. "And Orcs. Lots of them."

They were everywhere. Grey-skinned Ogres towering over everyone else, some pushing nine feet tall, hauling cargo that would have required cranes anywhere else. Father would have calculated the labor savings in his head—one Ogre replacing four dockworkers, the economics obvious. Green-skinned Orcs working the ropes and rigging with coordinated precision, shouting to each other in a language that wasn't Common. Half-breeds I couldn't quite categorize, their features blending human and something else.

A woman walked past our disembarking passengers, three packages floating serenely behind her. She wasn't even looking at them. Just walking, packages following, like that was boring.

"Aldric said the magic would be casual here," Gustin murmured. "I didn't think he meant... that casual."

"I could do that," I said. "If the packages weighed less than a copper coin and I had two minutes to prepare."

He laughed—nervous, sharp. I wasn't sure if I was joking either.

The Dawnbreaker bumped against the dock. Sailors threw lines. Somewhere above, Captain Ross shouted final orders.

"We're actually here." Gustin pulled out his acceptance letter, stared at it like it might vanish. "I didn't think—I mean, I knew we'd make it, but seeing it..."

"Different."

"Very different."

An Orc dockworker—seven feet tall, arms like tree trunks—grabbed our mooring line and secured it to a cleat in one smooth motion. His eyes swept over us, past us, already focused on the next ship.

Royal Road is the home of this novel. Visit there to read the original and support the author.

Kael's team was busy near the cargo hold—they'd need hours to offload the Frost Marten and arrange transport to Mali. Senna caught my eye across the deck and raised a hand. Ash chittered something from her shoulder that might have been farewell. Torvin was already shouting at dockworkers about handling procedures. Kael just looked at me for a moment, then gave a short nod. Good luck, it seemed to say. Or maybe don't die.

Three weeks of shared meals, a storm survived together, and that was goodbye. Hunters had work to do. So did we.

I shouldered my pack, felt the familiar weight of the claymore against my back, the fine leather of Father's satchel at my hip. Forty gold, five silver, six copper. An eight-inch Barrier. Knowledge I couldn't properly use.

And Mali was three days away.

~~~

We stepped onto the dock and into overwhelming sensory chaos.

Not the architecture. Not the magic. The sound.

Elvish. Everywhere. A flowing, musical language I didn't understand—dock officials calling instructions, merchants haggling, passengers greeting family. They spoke to each other in their own tongue by default, switching to Common only when a human or Dwarf addressed them directly. Even the signage was Elvish first, Common second, if at all.

"Namaskāra," Gustin murmured beside me. An Elf nearby glanced at him with mild approval.

"You speak Sylvanic?"

"About five words. Aldric taught me the basics before I left. Hello, thank you, goodbye, please, sorry." He grimaced. "Namaskāra, dhanyavāda, punarmilāma, kripayā, kṣamā. That's my entire vocabulary."

Five words more than me.

The architecture matched the language—buildings grown rather than built, with walls of shaped living wood and roofs that curved like tree canopy. Street lights glowed without fire, powered by ambient Urja that I could almost feel pressing against my skin. The air smelled like forest and something else. Ozone, maybe. Charged potential.

"Paper currency," Gustin said suddenly, stopping at a notice board near the dock. "I forgot—Aldric mentioned this. They use paper money here. Dir, I think it's called."

"Paper money?"

"Backed by their treasury. He said the exchange rate was... something silver to ten of them? I don't remember exactly." He squinted at the notice, which was written in three languages. "There. One silver equals ten Dir."

I filed that away. Currency complications. Because surviving in a foreign city while attempting the impossible wasn't challenging enough.

We pushed deeper into the port district. The crowds were thick, the streets curved organically instead of following rigid grids, and I kept getting distracted by the constant magic.

A food vendor heated skewers with precision thermal spells. No fire, no fuel—just focused heat exactly where he wanted it. Probably more efficient than charcoal, if you didn't count the years of training required. Children nearby tossed light constructs back and forth while their parents ignored them—street games that would have gotten me laughed out of any academy testing room.

Eight inches. I could produce eight inches of shimmer that might stop a moth.

"Aldric said Academia Midur has been run by the same Archmage council for centuries," Gustin offered as we navigated through a market square. "Elves live so long, they just... stay. The same professors teaching the same curriculum for generations. I don't know if that's still true—he studied there decades ago—but..."

"Consistent."

"Or stagnant." He caught my look. "That's what Aldric said, not me. He said the Academy was brilliant but set in its ways. Traditional methods, traditional standards, traditional rejections for anyone who doesn't fit the pattern." He shrugged, uncertain. "At least, that was his experience."

Traditional rejections. Something to look forward to.

An Ogre passed us carrying a crate that had to weigh four hundred pounds. He navigated the crowd like it was empty space, people parting around him automatically. His expression was focused, professional. Just another worker doing a job—one that happened to require the strength of five normal men.

"We should find Lorenzo," Gustin said. "Get the lodging sorted before it gets too late."

I'd been eyeing a side street that looked interesting—market stalls, exotic goods, the kind of place where you could learn things about a city. "The trading house can wait an hour. We're finally somewhere interesting."

"Marcus." Gustin's voice had that edge to it—the one that meant he'd already calculated three steps ahead and didn't like the odds. "We should find Lorenzo first. Get the passage sorted. Then we know where we stand."

I wanted to argue. Explore first, logistics later. But he was right. We needed to know what we were working with before we could afford distractions.

"Fine." I pulled Maria's letter from my satchel. "River District. Let's go."

We asked for directions twice. The first Elf we approached responded in flowing Sylvanic until Gustin managed "Kripayā—please, Common?" Then she switched languages with the faintly condescending patience of someone accommodating a child.

"River District. Follow the main road to the second bridge, then left along the waterfront."

The second time, Gustin just opened with Common and saved us the awkwardness. But I was starting to understand something: if we were going to survive here—really survive, not just pass through—we'd need to learn their language. Another item on the list of things I wasn't prepared for.

A commotion ahead stopped us. Not a fight—fights had a different sound. This was sudden silence spreading outward like ripples in a pond, followed by sharp Sylvanic commands.

The crowd parted. Four Elves in uniform—living-wood badges that glowed faintly against dark tabards—strode through the gap with the unhurried confidence of those who knew no one would challenge them. City guards. Had to be.

One of them raised a hand toward a man backing away—human, by the look of him, dressed like a dockworker. No dramatic gesture, no drawn weapon. Just a casual flick of the wrist.

The man stopped—not by choice. His body jerked against invisible bonds, arms straining, legs fighting to move. Panic twisted his face as he struggled against something he couldn't see or break. Caught like a fly in amber.

In Lorisfort, this would have involved six guards, a chase through three alleys, and at least one overturned vegetable cart. Here it took three seconds and a gesture.

I didn't see an array. No glowing lines traced in the air, no geometric patterns forming. No staff, either—the guards carried nothing but those small sticks holstered at their belts. How had they cast?

Another guard approached the restrained man, spoke something in Sylvanic, then switched to accented Common. "Unlicensed implements. Possession of restricted magical tools without Tower certification." She made a pulling motion, and a concealed bag floated out from under the man's coat. Inside, I caught a glimpse of polished wood—staffs, maybe, or scroll cases. The kind of thing the Mage Towers apparently cared about.

Then one of the guards swept the crowd with something—not sight exactly, but something denser. The ambient magic, already thick enough to taste, suddenly pressed in like a physical weight. My lungs forgot how to work. The air itself felt too full, too heavy, drowning me in something I couldn't see or name.

The guard's eyes found mine. Held there. Flicked down to the claymore on my back—then dismissed it. Steel wasn't what they were looking for.

Whatever they were looking for, I apparently didn't have enough of it to be interesting. Story of my life.

The pressure released. I gasped, and Gustin steadied me with a hand on my shoulder.

While I'd been recovering, one of the guards had clamped manacles on the suspect's wrists. The invisible bonds released—I saw his body sag with sudden freedom—but by then it was too late. Two guards flanked him, hands on his arms, and marched him away. He went without further struggle. The crowd resumed its flow as if nothing had happened. Just another day in Navale.

"How did they cast without an array?" I asked once we'd started walking again. "I didn't see any staffs, either."

Gustin shook his head. "I... don't know. Aldric never mentioned..."

Now that I was looking—really looking—I started noticing things I'd missed before. Some Elves carried staffs, yes, the traditional kind. But others wore bandoliers across their chests, or belt holders at their hips, each holding half a dozen thin sticks no longer than my forearm. The guards had those too. I just hadn't registered what they were.

"Those little sticks," I said slowly. "The guards were holding them when they cast."

Gustin looked where I was pointing. An Elf woman passed us, seven or eight of them arranged neatly at her waist like a carpenter's tools. "You think that's how...?"

"Has to be." I didn't know what they were called, or how they worked, or why everyone here seemed to have them. But I'd seen the guard flick one of those sticks just before the spell hit. No array. No incantation. Just point and effect.

Another thing I didn't understand about magic. The list was getting long.

~~~

Castelli & Sons Trading House was larger than I'd expected—two stories of living wood architecture with warehouses attached, positioned directly on the river docks. The sign showed a merchant ship beneath three stars.

Inside was controlled chaos. Crates being inventoried. Ledgers updated. Three clerks—two humans and a half-Elf woman—working at different desks with the efficient speed of those who knew exactly what they were doing.

Father's warehouses looked like this during peak season. Same organized disorder. Same merchants who could sort a stranger's worth in three seconds flat.

A man maybe forty-five years old looked up from a shipping manifest. His eyes moved over us—quick assessment, sorting categories. Two young men, travel-worn, clearly not customers with real money. Merchant's evaluation, merchant's dismissal already forming.

"Help you?"

I stepped forward with our letters from Maria. "Lorenzo Castelli? Maria sent us."

The dismissal paused. He took both letters, broke the seals, scanned them quickly. His expression shifted twice—once at Maria's name, again at whatever she'd written about me. When he looked up, the wariness had softened but not vanished.

"Maria's cousin." He studied me more carefully now. "She mentions you've come a long way. Marcus, yes? And..."

"Gustin." Gustin straightened slightly. "I'm expected at Academia Midur."

"Expected. Good." Lorenzo led us to an office off the main floor. His desk was organized with Elven precision—everything in stacks, nothing out of place. He gestured us into chairs that had seen better decades. "Maria says you need lodging and river passage. Academy testing."

"That's right."

"Both of you?" His eyes found mine. Held there. "Without an acceptance letter?"

"Walk-in testing."

A long pause. The kind where someone decides whether to waste their time on you.

"I tell everyone who comes through here the same thing," Lorenzo said finally. "Walk-in testing at Academia Midur is... possible. Technically. But their standards for walk-ins are higher than for accepted students. They're looking for reasons to reject you quickly. Makes their paperwork easier." He leaned back. "Why should I help you waste your time and my contacts?"

Because my father said I couldn't. Because two academies already told me I wasn't good enough. Because I've spent eight years proving I can do what everyone says is impossible.

None of that would mean anything to a merchant I'd just met.

"Because Maria thought I was worth helping," I said. "And you trust her judgment."

Another pause. Then something shifted in his expression—not quite approval, but the grudging respect of one merchant recognizing another's gambit.

"Fair enough." He pulled out a small strongbox, counted paper notes I'd never seen before. Thin, with intricate patterns that caught the light. "First things first—you'll need Dir. Local currency. How much silver have you got?"

"Plenty. But—"

"Convert some now. Two silver will give you twenty Dir—enough for meals and small expenses. The rest..." He paused. "Get a bank account in Mali if you're staying more than a few days. Better exchange rates. Pay in foreign coin here and merchants will rob you blind."

He handed me the paper notes. Light in my hand, almost insubstantial. Twenty Dir for two silver. I added them to my purse and subtracted from my mental count.

"River passage." Lorenzo produced a slip of paper, wrote quickly. "Captain Eryndor, the Whisperwind, River Slip Seven. Dawn departure—and I mean dawn, not five minutes after. Elven city, Elven schedules." He handed me the paper. "Give him this. Family rate—six gold each instead of eight or ten. He's reliable."

Six gold. Twelve total for both of us. Manageable. And a rate we never would have found on our own.

"Lodging tonight." He marked a map, slid it across. "Greenwood Rest, three streets from here. Human-owned, fair prices. One gold each for rooms, or share one if you're watching coin. Tell Mina I sent you."

One gold for a shared room. One gold saved was one gold closer to surviving whatever came next.

"We appreciate this," I said. The words felt thin for what he was giving us—not just logistics, but the kind of connections that gold alone couldn't buy.

"Maria wouldn't send you if you weren't worth the trouble." Lorenzo walked us to the door. "I've seen stranger ambitions succeed. When you make it—tell Maria. She likes knowing the people she helps actually get somewhere."

When, not if. Merchant optimism or genuine belief, I couldn't tell. But he'd earned the benefit of the doubt.

~~~

The Greenwood Rest was exactly what Lorenzo had promised—small, clean, human-run. We split the room—five silver each. Mina took our coin and handed us a key without questions.

The room was modest. Two beds. A window looking onto a quiet street. Elven light-globes providing soft illumination without fire or fuel.

Gustin collapsed onto his bed immediately. "It doesn't move."

"What?"

"The bed. It doesn't move." He was grinning at the ceiling. "Do you know how long it's been since I slept on something that didn't move?"

I sat on my own bed. He was right. Solid. Stable. No pitch, no roll, no constant adjustment to the ship's rhythm.

Weeks at sea. Storms and dice games and spells I couldn't cast. Questions I couldn't answer—about external cores, about thresholds, about whether what worked for a Leviathan could ever work for me. Progress that felt like standing still.

And now—solid ground. A bed that didn't move. Mali three days away.

I counted my remaining coin. Forty gold, five silver, six copper this morning. Minus two silver for food at Deepwatch. Minus two silver converted to Dir. Minus five silver for my half of the room.

Thirty-nine gold, six silver, six copper. Plus twenty Dir in unfamiliar paper that felt like it might blow away if I breathed wrong. Father would have hated paper money. Too easy to destroy, too hard to verify.

Tomorrow I'd pay six gold for river passage. That would leave thirty-three gold and change when I reached Mali.

Thirty-three gold to survive in an Elven city while attempting the impossible.

Gustin was already asleep, exhaustion winning over anxiety. His acceptance letter lay on the bedside table, carefully smoothed.

I stared at the ceiling—solid, unmoving, blessedly stable.

Three days to Mali. Dawn departure. Questions without answers.

But tonight, I'd sleep on ground that didn't move.

That was enough.
